text:
Aroma: lightly leather, earthy and roasty.
Appearance: golden amber
Taste: Very light sweetness and slightly salty
Body: medium body, creamy, average carbonation

Im fairly new to specialty beer, but this one satisfies my preferences in alcoholic beverages across the board. I enjoy Syrah and Sauvignon Blanc wines; full-bodied bourbons; and stout and Belgian influenced beer. Its like a perfectly blended mixture of all of these and is my current favorite.

Draught. Pours a nearly clear yellow-gold with a small white head. Aroma is vanilla, oak, raisins, yeast, spice, light bourbon, some coconut, toffee, and earth. Taste is coconut, vanilla, some bourbon, some oak, a hint of honey, and Trappist-like yeast. Fairly sweet.  Lightly bitter. Light-medium body. Soft carbonation. Slick, smooth mouthfeel.

Starts with the well-known sweetness of a Belgian tripel, but then finishes with a sudden bold, sour woodiness or resin. Mild yeasty, sour aroma. Very fine, scant head and rather carbonated for a tripel. Definitely does not seem like 11% ABV, goes down way too nicely. Really interesting tripel take overall.
(Tap) hazy, bright yellow colour with a small white head; brief aroma of honey, then slight sourness and woodiness; thick palate; balanced flavour with a long, light bitter sweet finish

Poured from 750mL bottle (bottled on 11/02/16). Clear yellow with full bubbly white head. Yeast and coriander with mild wood, finishes with a smooth bourbon flavour, alcohol mostly hidden. Very smooth, well balanced. Not a traditional abbey tripel by any stretch, but still quite good.

Draught at Beer Hall SF. Hazy yellow color, white head. Bitter taste with citrus, yeast, a bit of hops, toffee, earthy notes, ripe fruits, oak and grass. Bitter finish with citrus, yeast, earthy notes, ripe fruits, oak, spices and grass. Exquisite tripel.

picked up a bottle at Costco for $17.99 (bit expensive for something aged for only 8 weeks/ not disappointed though). Poured a hazy gold with less than a finger of head. Citrus and tropical fruit aroma. Strong bourbon and vanilla flavors with a malty/hop finish. Very well balanced Tripel.

Bottle into a tulip glass. Pours a hazy straw yellow with a quick-dissipating white head. Lemon, spice, and Belgian yeast on the nose. Mouthfeel is medium-bodied with a slight harshness from the carbonation. Good tripel flavors week a slight woodiness. Not bad, but very little bourbon flavor.
Klassisch kräutriger Tripelmann mit zartem Strong Ale Verlangen. Alles richtig gemacht, allerdings auch kein outstanding Ausreißer. 0,1/Tap. TAPHOUSE München. ca. 3 Euronen.
Hazy light golden in appearance with a white head. Lemon, spice, crisp, earthy flavors. Pepper

Bottle sample at a tasting at zvsns place. Thanks Alon. Golden with white head and lots of particles. The aroma has lots of wood, yeasts, vanilla and flowers. Sweet flavor with notes of yeasts, wood, bourbon, flowers, vanilla, alcoholic, a bit lactic, bitterish. Medium to full-bodied. Great.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2017 Appearance: Bottled 3/9-2016. Quite hazy yellow, some white head.
Aroma: Fruits, slight funk. Slight wood.
Taste: Lots of fruits, yeast and spices. Vinous and warming. Slight barrel?
Bought: Total Wine and More (Sterling), 750 ml, $18.99
Info: 6/1-2017, 70/100

Bottle; pours hazy yellow with a white head; aroma of fruits, honey, vanilla, wood, yeast, and spice with a hint a bourbon; taste is similar with fruits, vanilla, honey, and yeast with hints of bourbon and wood; finish has a light some spice and alcohol warming; very good

Sampled on draught at The Side Door, Chicago. This version is billed as 11% ABV. A clear champagne/straw colour and a rich malty aroma. The texture is thick and creamy. Some Bourbon in the taste. Lots of boozy alcohol, and some vanilla bean, banana and dried fruit flavour. Good, bitter finish. I would expect a slightly more spiciness for a beer made with Belgian yeast in this style. An extremely well-made and enjoyable beer.

Bottle sample at a tasting, thanks Alon. Hazy yellow with a huge head. Aroma of wood, vanilla, Brett, wine, yeast, spices and overripe fruits. Sweet, spicy, vanilla, fruity esters, bourbon, oak, finish is mild bitter. Medium-bodied, oily and creamy. Strong and boozy but complex and balanced.

Draft at First Draft in Chicago. Slightly hazy golden pour. The aroma is yeasty esters, oak, bourbon. This is a spritzy, alcoholic triple with grassy hops, lots of fruit, and just a hint of bourbon and wood, not really much. Pretty standard.

Bottle, 650ml. Sparkling golden, small creamy offwhite head. Complex aromas of citrus, Belgian yeast, spices, wood, light tart. Medium bodied, fizzyish carbonation. Thin and bone dry, yet creamy. Harsh alcohol flavors and finish.
Wonderful beer that has a finish of Bourbon with every aftertaste. 75 characters, blah blah blah

Medium, cloudy blonde with a medium white head. Aroma is simplistic with malts leading the way; some subtle light fruit sweetness & spice in the back. Flavors are what youd expect from a standard tripel (malt backbone, bananas, fruit esters, white pepper) and not much more despite its time in barrels. Medium body & moderate carbonation. While being approachable and very drinkable, it lacks complexity. Instead of 8 weeks, it really shouldve stayed in bourbon barrels for 8 months. Its too expensive for what it is; falls short when compared to other non-BA tripels in lower price points!

Backlog, Bottle, Pours orange golden with a 2 finger medium head, nice lacing. Smell and taste are bourbon, sweet malting, vanilla bean, banana and misc dark fruits. Medium bodied with easy going booze. Finish is lasting and warming from the percentage and the whiskey. A very drinkable barrel aged trip from Allagash

Tap at Munich Tap House, 15th November 16. Pours a rich amber, soft foam head. Aroma is big and bold, sweet, bourbon, liquor, barrel. Taste is complex, wood, liquor, vanilla, sweet and bitter. Really good.

Bottle. Light moppy, herbal, wood, a few esters. Hazy green, white lace. Fine barrel notes on the foreground, light peach, a hint earthy, fresh wood, moss retronasal. Medium light mellow body, light sparkles, very pleasant.
Hazy golden appearance with a bourbon aroma. Belgian malt body and a bubbly finish. Bourbon is a bit too strong with this one.
Bottle: Light delicate aroma, full body with a sweet finish. It takes out all the things of a Belgian that I dont prefer (high yeast, banana flavors). This was tasty.
Hazy yellow, medium head, aroma of wood, coconut, caramel, toffee, sourness, fruitiness, chocolate, flavor of wood, coconut, caramel, toffee, chocolate, nice, medium bodied.

Bottle courtesy of Håkan. Fairly clear golden pour with a small frothy white head. Heavy bourbon BA nose with caramel, vanilla fudge, charred wood and toasted coconut mixed with hints of toffee, baked pears, hay, minerals and bourbon alcohol. Sweet and tiny bitter taste. Round boozy mouthfeel. Heavy pear and bourbon alcohol finish. If it wasnt for the baked pears I wouldnt even have guessed triple. Very heavy bourbon character. Nice for what it is but I had hoped for something more Belgian.

2015 edition consumed oct of 2016. hazy yellow some floaters, lingering creamy palate. aroma husky old hops, apple juice malts. tastes boozy borbon laced nectarines, grassy euro hops. rock candy sugar. some bretta funk sneaking up. toothsome and sweet.

Bottle to tulip
Consummation: Oak, muted bourbon, hint of sour, caramel, malts, yeast...so smooth 
Adjunct: Aroma of bourbon, wood, carrot, apple cider, light sweet yeast; as I said before, so smooth, silky, and a bit boozy, but not what would be expected for this ABV; clear, but not crystal, light amber with a frothy white head that falls pretty quickly to a thin white ring, with active effervescence

Une bière blonde orangée, avec une belle mousse, et un peu deffervescence. Au nez, on sent beaucoup la levure, qui me rappelle un peu celle des saisons belges, plus quune triple. On a une sensation dalcool également, quon attribue sans doute au vieillissement en barriques. En bouche, on retrouve la base de triple assez sucrée, intéressante, avec vraiment un arriere-goût sucré qui me rappelle le sirop dérable. Jattribue sans doute cette présence sucrée au bourbon. Lalcool, pour une bière à 11%, me semble tout à fait inexistant, la rendant impressionnante à ce chapitre. La bière nest pas tout à fait complexe, mais est une réussite pour sur.

Great stuff. Light golden opaque, 2 finger head. Lively carbonation. Barrrels are not strong in the aroma but add a nice complexity to an already great flavor. As far as tripels go, I would put the base beer up against any of them. This version ups the ante for me.

Pours a hazy amber from a bottle with a pillowy white head. Aroma of green apple and vanilla. Flavor adds a surprising coconut note into the mix. A heavy-hitter with some alcohol burn, but mostly this is a creamy beer with a big mouthfeel. Good beer.

Sample at Bobs Bar during the "Mike Langley GTFO of Columbus Bottle Share" on 08/29/2016. The beer pours a clear pale golden color with a medium white head that diminishes gradually to a film. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of yeast, bourbon and malt. Full-bodied with flavors of bourbon, oaky vanilla, fruity yeast and malt. The finish is mildly boozy with a bourbon and yeast aftertaste. Pretty good all around.

On tap at Chickies and Petes on Packer Ave. this one is all Belgian followed by all bourbon, so much so I couldnt get past the bourbon, but Im not down on an 11% beer and I did drink 5 of them, so hope that helps you.
Draft. Pours a hazy goldenish color. Aroma and taste are fruits, yeasty, sweetness, and bourbon.

Bottled February 2016. The vanilla, banana, coconut and clove aromas are consistent from pour to swallow and the 11% alcohol is warming and well hidden; kudos. A bit sweet but it finishes abruptly and cleanly. True to the style there is a bubbly light mouthfeel however there is slightly soapy texture (if you were a kid back in the day and you said something you werent supposed to, you know what I mean). Excellent but a bit expensive. Next time I think I will pair it with food.

8 oz draft. Slightly hazy orange color with a very small bubbly white head. Aromas of funk, spice, yeast, a hint of alcohol, various fruits. Banana and apricot, spices, peppery, a bit of bourbon on the finish. Medium body, effervescent and slick mouthfeel.

Slightly hazy pale color with white head. Aroma is floral and perfumey with a touch of bourbon. Taste starts like a typical Belgian tripel, yeasty and sweet but on the aftertaste you get the bourbon barrel. Medium body and carbonation. Not bad at all but I think the flavors dont combine as well as expected.

Mycket trevlig arom fylld med jästiga estrar, pepprig krydda, lite alkohol, vanilj och kokos men helt utan sötma. 
Grumligt gyllene brygd och ett litet men stadigt och tätt skum med lång halveringstid. Smaken är överraskande söt och därtill med inslag av säd och en rejäl alkoholdos. Vaniljen återkommer och lyfter nu fram fattonerna av ek och en aning ljus frukt. Kroppen är halvfyllig, och vätskan har en oljig viskositet. Fint avvägd kolsyra. I eftersmaken växer en mild beska fram, parad med en något otrevlig syra. En oväntat ljus och därtill mycket bra komposition.

750 mL bottle shared by ebone1988 for the fucking book. The pour is a darker golden yellow color with a thick white head that falls down to a cap leaving a good soapy lace. The aroma is not too bad. There is a nice banana and spice blend up front with a decent yeastiness on the back end. Its pretty plain and light, and there isnt any barrel here. The flavor is, well, not good. There is a permanent marker, spice, yeasty bit happening with a metallic malt and a light bourbon. Its also quite woody. This is better than the first time I had it, but not good. The mouth feel is a little heavy with a soft carbonation and a spicy bourbon barrel and yeast on the finish. Im not a fan of this at all. Tripels can blow me.

Bottle shared with koleminer20. For the book. Aroma is funk, wet grass, barnyard, slight banana, maybe a little woody. Appearance is darker golden, off white head, hazy. Taste is woody, spice, funk, banana, bourbon, barnyard, permanent marker. Mouthfeel is medium body, light carbonation, dry, woody metallic aftertaste. Overall, better than I remember but still not good.

Very big beer. Takes the balance right out of the Tripel with punches of coconut and vanilla. Still extremely smooth, but the flavor profile is much more in your face. Strong boozy notes, but lends a warming smoothness.

750ml bottle. Slight haze yellow golden color with a white head. Wheat lemon grass aroma. Oak vanilla spice clove yeast bourbon finish. Medium body. Triple up front with a vanilla bourbon finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2016/06/18 - Pours a hazy deep gold colour with a thick, foamy white head that lingers and leaves ample lacing. Aroma is yeast, wheat, banana, bubblegum, tart pear, lightly spicy hops, oaky-vanilla, honey and a hint of bourbon. Taste follows nose; pear, honey, citrus and light spicy hops up front, followed by wheat, oaky-vanilla and bourbon. Mouthfeel is medium to full and silky with soft carbonation and a moderately sweet, boozy, slightly warming finish. Smooth, balanced, mellow, delicious. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From 750 ml bottle thanks to Alex. Light hazy golden orange color with off white head. Yeasty and malty aroma, light spicy, fruity, wood notes, light alcohol. Sweet and light bitter taste like aroma, fruity and wood again, sweet and tart citrusy fruity, more bourbon and wood notes than the aroma, vanilla too. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.

Large corked and caged bottle served into a tulip glass. Bottled March 2015. Beer is a clear golden color with a fairly thick white head which dissipates slowly leaving lots of thick lacing. Aroma is mostly grain like with some dry fruit like pears, maybe some banana. Taste is medium sweet with faint bitterness and notes of light dry fruits such as figs, oak and honey. Light carbonation and medium bodied beer. Some oak like flavor as well as smoothness is noticeable from barrel aging. I like Tripels and I love barrel aged beer. Together this is a great beer, Great flavor and pretty smooth. Very enjoyable. Impressed.

July 22, 2015. On tap at Great Lost Bear. 
Clear pale golden with a small white head. Aroma is sweet malty,toffee, some bourbon, vanilla, grape, honey, almond, orange and spice notes. Taste is medium sweet with toffee, bourbon, orange and almond, light bitter with a grassy and spicy notes, smooth warming finish with toffee, bourbon, vanilla and spices. Medium bodied, soft to average carbonation.

Pours a bright hazy yellow with thick white head. A unique aroma of wheat, yeast, citrus, and hints of bourbon. A strong taste mostly of wheat, yeast, citrus, vanilla, and spices - but just a hint of bourbon on the back. A dry yeast and grain aftertaste.
Bottle shared by PinkZambia Clear straw color. Nicely muted Belgian yeast flavors and a touch of oak and barely a hint of the bourbon. Seems to mellow everything out. Very drinkable and tasty.

Bottle shared at a tasting at our place. Thanks Yael Tamuz for the bottle! Hazy amber with a white film. Some vanilla, black pepper, peach, hints of wood and lots of yeast in the nose, bitter, alcoholic, but delicately so, then sweet. Full-bodied and complex, interesting, hints of sweetness in the finish.

Poured into sample glass at brewery: Pours golden with a decent white head. Aroma of bourbon, oak, sugar, vanilla, and booze. Taste is more of the same, really sweet. Heavy body, too much booze and residual sugar. Not great but not bad for a bourbon aged triple. I was expecting worse.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2016 Rerate (24/12/16), many thanks Alon, smallish creamy head, hazy lightish orange color, aroma of vanila ice cream, bourbon and whipped cream, fruity vcoconut flavor with woody oaky vanila notes and a nutty hint, light mellow sourness and sweetness. Everything is very nicely integrated and beautifully balanced, highly enjoyable.
At a tasting (31/03/16), thanks, small creamy head, very cloudy orange color with yellow taints, bourbon aroma with vanila, slightly charred wood and sour bread, a bit alcoholic, flavor of bourbon, vanila, coconut and wood with a hint of nuts and alcohol, not too heavy for the ABV. Nice but a bit too bourbony. (8,3,8,3,12)

Un bière qui appartient à un style qui ne me plaît habituellement pas. Celle-ci par contre, cest autre chose! Blonde, dorée, profonde, mousseuse et vivante. Le simple fait de la contempler me met en joie! Très chênue, notes vineuses, beaucoup de pomme verte, un important baril et des notes alcoolisées dun bourbon chaud assumées. Très facile à boire malgré un sucre résiduel important, il faut se méfier de ce look gai et invitant qui monte rapidement à la tête...

Bottle sample at a tasting at kerenmks place. Thanks kerenmk. Bottled 1/14. 11%. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, cookies, fruitiness, malt, caramel, and an alcohol note. Sweet flavor with bourbon, vanilla, some fruitiness, caramel, a bit of alcohol. Medium-bodied, rounded. Nice.
Bottle (750ml $20): Light golden with white head. Sweet aroma with light bourbon. Medium carbonation and medium body. Taste is sweet tripel. Yes.
Aromas of apples, dough, honey. Taste is sweet with subtle tartness. Very enjoyable.

Pours hazy golden, lingering white head. Sweet nose, Ill accept the suggestion that its bourbon, otherwise Id suggest its high alcohol malt sweetness. Easy in the mouth, bourbon predominates. Low to moderate carbonation. Finishes a bit sweet, bare hops. Essentially, it comes off as a boiler maker made with good ingredients.

I am in love (lust, perhaps) with this beer. While I havent kept track, Ive probably sampled by now beers from around the world numbering in the thousands. And as it currently stands, Curieux is my personal favorite. If I could easily afford to drink this nightly, I would. What do I like about it? Everything! It pours a golden-orange color, leaving a mid-sized creamy head that leaves behind a gorgeous Belgian lace. The aroma is of a tantalizing Belgium-meets-Kentucky essence, making one very curious to discover what Curieux tastes like on the tongue. And how does it taste? Luscious!!! There is a creamy texture to it that lingers on the tongue. You taste a smokiness from the bourbon barrel aging and the exquisite harmony and balance of the malt and hops of this tripel from what has been one of the best (perhaps THE best) brewer of Belgian beers outside of Belgium. I feel like I am drinking an Old Fashioned made with high-end bourbon and at the same time Im drinking a Duvel-level brew. I taste white pepper, coconut, blood orange, butter-and-brown-suga- glazed bananas with pecans, and a lingering oaky tobacco smokiness -- all hitting my tastebuds in the right degree. On second thought, I lust for this beer.

Pepper, orange, notes of banana and oak is present but not overpowering. Appearance is a cloudy yellow with a white head. Flavor has notes of lemon and light pepper. Bourbon flavor is present and balanced with the beer. Mouthfeel is medium light with medium high carbonation. Overall, it's a well balance bourbon barrel aged tripel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This was worth every penny I spent to have it on draft. I dont think Ive enjoyed a beer this much in a while. It was like a re-awakening for me. Theres an undeniable bourbon aroma first and foremost. It sweet, smokey, full of vanilla, banana and clove. Super aromatic and delicious. Taste is a big punch of bourbon, pipe tobacco, clove, banana, and oak. The whole beer is very well balanced and everything works in perfect harmony. Nothing overpowers or takes away from anything else. I really enjoyed this, and would not hesitate to pick up a bottle every once in a while for a special occasion. Definitely recommended. Cheers!
Pours hazy blonde with a quick white head. nose is all oak and whiskey with just a hint of sweetness. whiskey comes out strong on the front and fades to a more familiar tripel sweetness.

Pours a light amber color wIth a bourbon beer aroma. Taste is dry, with a light sweetness, almost a dissolved sugary flavor which hid the alcohol content well. Dry finish and aftertaste, the bourbon barrel flavor subtly mixed well with a good flavored triple.
Significantly boozy flavor over a thick tripel. Counters the sticky sweetness well. Keeps it dry. Nice.

Clear amber body, medium white head. Aroma ofwood, vanilla and caraml. Similar flavours. Overall it feels like Im drinking bourbon with some carbonation and low alcohol (for a bourbon). I was hopping to taste a better blend between beer and bourbon. The barrel took over the beer, it felt unbalanced : no beer flavor or aroma.

I expected something great when I bought this, and it didnt disappoint. Curieux pours a beautiful golden brown and smells like citrus and oak. How does it taste? Like scotch...if scotch could be beer. It has a sweetness to it thats followed by somewhat of a creamy finish, but after youve swallowed it, it has oaky notes that make you think you just had a sip of scotch. Absolutely fantastic stuff.

Bottle pour into tulip glass. Aroma is yeasty with oak and bourbon. Appearance is hazy gold, no sparkle, 1/2 finger width white foamy head with fair lacing. Taste is bourbon/oak, mildest underlying Belgian yeast and fruity esters. Palate is light with thin texture, no carbonation, finish is long oak and bourbon dominant. Overall, Id appreciate it more if the oak and bourbon was a little less dominant that other aspects could shine through.

On tap at the Saloon in Napa. Very slightly hazy, yellow pour with a sticky white head (I would finish this rating but BV is busy geeking out with the bartender about how amazing this is. #ratebeerwifeproblems - mrs bvery).
The subtle flavor of bourbon comes through at the back end of every sip; a tiny bit citrusy

Best beer I?ve had. A triple aged in Jim beam Bourbon barrels. Could it get better?? Every thing you get in an amazing triple plus the sweet oak flavor of bourbon. You can smell it and you can taste it, and just the right blend. Love it!!!

Allegashs trippel is the tofu of US Belgian-style trippels, in that it takes the taste of whatever is brewed with it. In this case, Jim Beam oak with a Begian Trippel back. Crisp, aromatic, and expensive. One of the best beers in America, one that I have treated myself with on countless paydays. Awesome!
Tap @ bells 30th, Aroma malts, citrus, orange, vanilla...taste is orange peel, yeast, bannana, oak, and vanilla, tart, very good
Smells like fresh squeezed orange juice. Taste is similar, orange and spicy notes as well. No overpowering whiskey flavor thats all too common in barrel aged beers. This is very good.

Probada en Dive Bar, Upper west Side, Manhattan. Tripel estilo belga añejada en barriles de Jean Bean por 8 semanas. Predomina el sabor a whisky con toques de vainilla y coco. Excelente Tripel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet candy. Flavor actually has more spice from the yeast than sweetness from the bourbon barrels

Keg, The Gaff, Waltham

Loads of coriander and clove and Jim Beam on aroma. Taste is lemons, coriander, clove, citrus zest and bourbon and oak. Super drinkable.
Bottle: thanks to my brother, full, complex, malty, yeast, bready. Food Pairing: Brie cheese.
Clear golden, light white head. Oakes caramel and molasses, honey. Decent bit of bitterness, sweet. Big alcohol, medium body, oily. Long finish. Good.
Pours a medium golden color with two fingers of white foam. Notes of spicy yeast, sweet toffee, coconut, vanilla, cream soda, light citrus, some booze.
A pretty nice offering....good blend of Beligan yeast, oak, vanilla, candy sugar, some dark fruit. Medium bodied with a slight booze burn. Good stuff.
At Rockwells. Quite complex. Sweeter than some other tripel due to strength. Barrel aging adds boozeyness. Serving: Tap

Bottling January 29. 2015. Belle robe dorée et impeccable tête avec une dentelle. Le nez révèle des parfums de pain mielleux, de fruits jaunes, de noix de coco, de vanille et dépices. Lalcool et sa présence enveloppante rappelle les plus grandes du style. En bouche, le bourbon complimente les saveurs de base. Un bel équilibre puis-je dire. Au palais, le plaisir est réel. Le pétillement confortable et le corps douillet rendent lexpérience des plus agréables. En finale, japerçois des notes douces balancées par un alcool chaleureux et fruité.

Poured from the tap into a pint glass.
Aroma-Hops and yeast
Appearance- A nice gold color with a small white head
Taste- Hops and a bourbon back end, very nice
Palate- A medium bodied beer with moderate carbonation
Overall- An outstanding beer, very well made

Appearance: slightly opaque golden, with a short, creamy white head and slightly syrupy legs. Aroma: belgian yeast character is strong, followed by booze, vanilla, some citrus, and pie crust.  Taste: 	bourbon, vanilla, lemon, light banana, tamarind, maybe even some coconut, with prominent yeast.  Finish: most flavors fade except for vanilla, bourbon, and yeast, then a mild astringency comes out. Notes: Beers this hyped seldom seem up to it. This was a very good, very creative beer. Glad to have tried it. Alcohol was well-hidden. Bottled 21 March 2014, had in early June 2015.  Bottle from Westover Market in Arlington, Virginia.

Hazy orange color with small white head. Flowery grains, some spicy Belgian yeasts, some sugary Bourbon wood. Taste is sweet, grainy, flowery, boozy, a bit of a burn, surprisingly low carbonation. Certainly a good beer, nice Barrel character which is not too strong, but does not live up to its reputation.

Golden color quite some foam. The smell has a boozy touch and a lot of whisky nose but with a fresh touch. The taste is very actively carbonated and has its yeasty and sweet malty character, but still got an underlying whisky note that becomes stronger in the aftertaste and carries a boozy note through the whole beer taste. A little heavy, but definitely a good beer.
Pours a hazy gold. Aroma is slightly lacking, not a huge amount on it. Flavor is bourbon soaked caramelized bananas. Pretty tasty.

Draught @ Allagash Brewing Company, Portland, ME
Pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, wheat, yeast, vanilla, oak, floral and alcohol. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with a long warm, wheat, yeasty, vanilla and oak finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft

From my backlogg: 

Bottle in London 2014. Hazy golden beer with an white head. Malty bready fruity aroma. MAlty bready yeasty hoppy flavour.

Appearance: Mildly hazy straw colored body, thin white head with poor retention.
Aroma: Very light, hints of tart citrus with light bourbon and coconut.
Taste: Odd but enjoyable, very balanced mix of grapefruit, lemon and orange with coconut and bourbon on the finish.
Palate: Medium bodied, moderately carbonated.
Overall: Good beer, I enjoy the balance, but the flavors clash.
Tap at some queens bar. Nose is sweet bourbon and yeast. Tastes of Jim beam, yeast, red fruit, bready, slight booze. Smooth palate. Quite delicious.

As close to perfect as you can get. I figured this brew to be a quad or Belgian Strong Ale. Very rich and complex flavor and high end of the spectrum malt / gravity experience and mouth feel. This is a tremendous blonde strong ale with a sophisticated complexity created by layering in oak whiskey barrels. One of my favorites all time!
Smell is mild bourbon, Belgian yeast, and some mineral. Taste is the same with a good amount of malt and some dryness at the end. Medium body and carbonation with mild foam.
Wonder bourbon and smoked wood in the nose. Slightly yeasty with strong bourbon and wood flavors. Wonderful stuff. Must. Buy. More.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2016 Medium amber, cloudy, dense lace. Full body, delicate but assertive flavors, rich mouthfeel, high heat, long palate. Moderately sweet and bitter, crisp acidity. Fruity, orange juice, yeasty. Delicious. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sweet, sugary citrus hovers above complex but understated bourbon and vanilla notes as this brew lingers on a creamy oak note. Heat doesnt show through at all, but this lingers with some overwhelming sweetness.

Bourbon barrel is faintly present in this beer but it seems to work well. You get a bit of coconut and vanilla in the smell along with the standard tripel aroma of belgian yeast, bready malts, bananna and a hint of citrus. Tastes of coconut, bananna, yeasty flavors and some dry maltiness. Good carbonation, you get a bit of the barrel in the finish but otherwise its dry. 
Great beer, the barrel has a small presence in the taste but it really makes the rest of the beer shine, most of the time the bourbon cloaks the characteristics of the base beer but in the case of this it really seems to enhance some of the sweeter flavors

From 750ml, bottled May 30, 2014. 11% ABV, poured into 12oz Belgian tulip glass

Aroma: Big oak, a little funk. slight sweetness

Appearance: golden/orange, hazy, white head

Taste: light sour, medium sweet, medium bitter

Palate: light body, lingering bourbon/sweet/bitter finish

Overall: Not bad for a barrel aged beer. The bourbon isnt overpowering, but its still present. Im not a fan of bourbon barrel beer that tastes like bourbon, but this is really smooth and nice. A tad sweet. The aroma is very powerful oak. You can really taste their tripel underneath with its belgiany spices.

Poured into pint glass. Nice color. Aroma was faint of sweet alcohol. Definitely recommend 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Golden pour 1 finger white head. Aroma is bourbon, bread, plum, clove and Belgium yeast. Taste is malts, plum, raisin, spice and some caramel. Complex and thicker mouth feel. Bourbon and sweetness are little strong. Overall pretty solid beer. I?m sure aging would make this even better.

On cask at the Porter Beer Bar in Atlanta. Poured into a tulip. Golden orange in color with haze and a velvety white one finger head. Temp was just right. Aroma was bubble gum, candied sugars, sweet nectars, and desert sweet breads. The taste was similar with the bubblegum, dark candies, cotton candy, sweet biscuits, and doughnuts. Velvety mouth, very smooth and balanced, not overly sweet. Full body, buttery, and slick.
UPDATED: MAR 17, 2015 Had this on tap at S/S Grille. While I did not hate this beer, I did find it to be a bit overly sweet and boozy for me to truly love it. Decent though.

A richer, more complex Allagash tripel. Pours a clear light orange, little head. Nose is yeast, banana, bubble gum, honey, clove. Taste is the same, fairly sweet with a little bourbon and oak. Fairly mellow, almost soothing. Wonderful.

A decent slightly belgium style beer. Little fruity but nicely balanced with hopps and male. Had this at hub 51 in Chicago.

On tap at Steins Beer Garden. Aroma of bourbon, booze, and spice. Taste in s awesome. Caramel, Belgian spice, pleasant long-lasting finish. Love it.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2015 On tap at Burial. As expected. Great tripel with tons going on but my 8oz pour was plenty. Nice hazy mostly golden but slightly orange pour with thick white head that stays put. Taste is yeasty, spice, clove, fig, raisin, with subtle bourbon. Nicely done with the barrel againg and blending -allows other flavors to come through. Smooth and somewhat slick/ buttery mouthfeel-flirting with syrupy. Sweetness lingers a bit too long. Boozy, but doesnt burn. 
Maine trip- interesting to taste at taproom next to tripel.  Sweetness noticeably less.  Tempered nicely by Jim.  Better finish than tripel. Nice and dry.
A little more orange than yellow, aroma of vanilla and banana, taste is light bourbon, woth oaky tannins contributing excellence to the dry, creamy, finish.
Straw pour, white head. Light aroma of bananas, flavor of banana, cloves, figs, yeast, and alcohol.
Spicy, Clove, vanilla aroma. Woody bourbon barrel taste, crisp champagne like head, with a light mid mouth Bourbon hit. Likely a top 10.

Pours a fairly clear, light orange color. Sweet, caramel malt, oaky, light bourbon, and a hint of a sweet tart note. Sweet, malty, Belgian yeast character, spicy phenols, vanilla, oak, and bourbon and some alcohol heat in the finish.

Draft at Mikkeller. Pours clear gold with foamy white head. Aroma of fruit, honey, bubblegum; somewhat floral, but mostly sweet and fruity. In the mouth this is thick, syrupy sweet, really overbearingly sweet/syrupy. Im surprised -- this is hard to drink. My companion for the night is able to finish both a triple ipa and an imperial porter while Im still staring down the last ounce of my $8.5 250ml pour, unwilling to let it go but really not looking forward to finishing it. Overall: Boozy sweet sticky beer thats hard to drink, and not even remotely enjoyable at any point.
Arômes sucrés venant du bourbon. Très doux en bouche, équilibre parfait des saveurs dorange, bois, sucre et alcool qui réchauffe la gorge.

750 ml bottle. Pours a slightly veiled golden with a resilient, thick and creamy white head. Aroma is lemon, wild yeast, vanilla, wood, orange. Flavor is lemon, vanilla, wood, oldish, dusty, liquor. Finish is very oldish, dusty, woody, boozy. Medium body, average carbonation.
A splendid belgian tripple, with oak, and bourbon notes that linger on the pallet, the color is a touch hazy but nothing to cry about. Worth every penny.

Bottle. Hazy light amber kiquid with light to mediu off-white head. Aroma of wood, coconut, bourbon, light banana, light caramel and spice. Taste is light sweet and light bitter with notes of light coconut, wood, light grain and light banana. Medium bodied with medium to high carbonation. Pretty nice.

On tap in a snifter at new Binnys tasting room Willow St. location. Pours cloudy gold, very nice. Flavor is sweet, mildly spicy, bright wheat. Absolutely no alcohol burn. Outstandingly well balanced Tripel, although not a lot of the "bourbon barrel" taste comes through.

Bomber aged a few years - vigorous pour, medium head that dissipates quickly. Has a light grapefruit look to it. I detect a light fruit (peaches) flavor along with a sweet candy flavor. The alcohol is hidden and it kinda snuck up on me. Medium body and dry.
Maybe the best bourbon barrel aged beer I've tasted. My favorite Allagash beer so far. Strong but excellent taste.
Hazy orange color. Wood, citrus and alcohol in the aroma. Full bodied. Malty, boozy and buttery. Great beer.

Great tasting bourban barrel aged ale.

Bottle pour. Cloudy golden brown with a large creamy white head. Oak and bourbon aroma. Smooth medium body. Bourbon and no flavor, but not an overly strong alcohol taste for the percentage.
On draft at Yardhouse in Dedham. Good, cloudy light orange color with a frothy white head. Oaky aromas and flavors. Some fruity sweetness. Very tasty. I wish it wasnt so expensive.
Hadnt had this beer in a long while but boy is it good. The tripel and the bourbon really play well together. Still light and lively but with solid coconut and oak notes throughout. Just fun.

4 oz draft pour at ChurchKeys Allagash 5th Anniversary event. Hazy golden brown with off-white head. Aromas of bourbon and spices. Tastes of bourbon, herbs, spices, citrus. Medium body with a dry and warm finish.

Bottle shared at the RBESG 2014, grand tasting 09/08/2014. Thanks to Colin. Orange / golden coloured pour with a mid haze, with a loose white head. Palate is semi full body, highish carbonation. semi sweet.

Man. Hitting the lottery on beer picks today. Another fantastic one. Orange foggy pour from 22oz bottle at home. Vanilla and lemon aroma. Sweet honey candy and slight bourbon taste. A ton going on in this beer. So good.

Aroma: intense, bourbon, caramel, grain and bread malts. Appearance: hazy, pale gold. Taste: medium sweet. The aroma wasnt much. I definitely picked up a lot of the sweetness. However it wasnt until I tasted it that I realized how complex the pantheon of flavors truly is: the undertones of chocolate and nuts and coffee, combined with the smokiness of bourbon makes for a lovely sipping beer. bottled Dec 2011 - drank April 2012; cloudy gold-orange color; musty, funky aroma; a fantastic Belgian inspired beer; spicy, dry, and a bit fruity with very subtle hints of oak and bourbon; very complex and extremely smooth - especially for a beer that weighs in at 11%abv; a warn, dry finish - similar to the finish on a fine bourbon

Aroma of oak, bourbon and Belgian yeast. Flavor is a not sweet and very rich with hints of raisins and caramel. Perfectly balanced!

Flavors tend more yeast-driven than the barrel-derived aromas, with esters plumbing the banana, tropical, and bubble gum depths. Sweet but thin, and profoundly intoxicating.

[5653-20130816] Bottle. Mild wood barrel notes in the aroma. Slightly hazy, pale orange body with a quick foamy white head. Mild bourbon-soaked wood flavour. Full body. Good, mild. (7/3/8/3/15) 3.6

Bourbon-matured beer since 2004, tasted in the later version of 11% ABV. Regular, off-white, not very stable head, colour clear orange blonde. Interesting aroma of pineapple, honey, white grapes, cider, banana, pepper and obvious but not overpowering bourbon. Soft fruity taste with mild carbonation, bit vinous, some candi sugar, sweetish caramel malts, spicy and woody accents, finish warm alcohol (generating a dryish effect) and aromatic hops, but the sweetness from the onset also lingers. On tap at Whole Foods. Pours a translucent and light copper with a fluffy, tan head that fades to light lacing. Aroma is Belgian yeast, citric spice, bourbon, vanilla, oak. Flavor is same with banana sweetness, spiciness from yeast and bourbon intensity in the finish. Having had this several times before, Im more aware of the curious combination of tripel and bourbon. Solid, but certainly curious.

It is as described but not that exciting for our group overall . Very drinkable.

Bottle shared by DrewFace. Pours a fairly clear golden color with medium sized white head. Light booze in the nose along with some perfume and spiciness from the base tripel. taste is initially sweet but dries out nicely. A compliment of spiciness without being to phenolic, fruity esters, and a subtle booze character from the barrel all seem to work well together.
Bottle share thanks to DrewFace. Pours a golden yellow with white head. Aroma is a mix of wine and tartness. Taste is a mix of wine, boost malt. Interesting beer.

Pours a fairly clear, light orange color. Sweet, caramel malt, oaky, light bourbon, and a hint of a sweet tart note. Sweet, malty, Belgian yeast character, spicy phenols, vanilla, oak, and bourbon and some alcohol heat in the finish.

Dotée dune robe dorée assez claire qui mousse bien, le bouquet de cette bière est aguichant. Les céréales mielleuses, la levure épicée et lalcool sont en parfaite symbiose. Cette harmonie se répète en bouche, mais le côté bourbon est un peu plus présent sans toutefois aliéner les autres saveurs. Relativement facile à boire malgré son haut taux dalcool.

Poured from a 2010 bottle into a snifter. Aroma is very subtle but fruity. Appearance is a clear medium yellow with a small white head that dissipates quickly. Taste is semi sweet with light bread fruit and white wine. This beer aged well and to me is better than more fresh bottles. Palate is good with nice carbonation. Overall a good brew.

ivory white head disappears with some lacing. yellow colour. aroma is spices, curacao, coriander,clove, reminds me a lot of witbier, yeast, slight vanilla. taste like aroma and boozy with slight wry aftertaste. medium body and carbonation.  bottle @ cantillon quintenssence 14

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2014 750 mL bottle supplied by Michael last Saturday; many thanks! Paired rather nicely with some bacon-and-cheddar sliders (with blue cheese and caramelized onions), which were served outside on a gorgeously sunny afternoon. WillRunForBeer was there. So was my dog. To long-stemmed tulip, it pours a gleaming, amber-orange with which an off-white head 1 ½ fingers in length stood. Aromas of expired lemon juice, earl grey tea, persimmons, autumnal leaves, candied ginger, satureja, noble hops, and sesame seeds. Tastes the same with the addition of red kuri squash/nutmeg, bourbon oak, sun-dried multigrain chips, banana peppers, farmhouse yeast, and pilsner malt. Mildly spicy, showcasing notes of yeast, sweet malt, unripe fruit, and bourbon-soaked oak. I absolutely had a fun time with this.

I split a 750ml bottle with a friend. We each poured it into tulip glasses. It was bottled on 1/24/14 (thanks to Renee for the bottle!).

Appearance: Glowing orange hue. Mostly cloudy with some visible carbonation. Pours to a large, beige, foamy head which retains and laces fairly well.

Smell: Strong bourbon and alcohol/phenolic character. Definite Belgian yeast esters as well.

Taste: Im a big fan of Belgian-style Tripels, though Ive never had one that was aged in bourbon barrels as is the case of Allagash Curieux. Barrel-aging can be a wonderful addition to a strong stout or barleywine, though Im not sure its ideal for a Tripel. Theres a constant back-and-forth between the base brew and the bourbon character from the Jim Beam barrels. An interesting contrast between banana, clove and raw malt against an astringent, earthy character of wood and vanilla. Theres distinct crushed black pepper in the palate here, too. A consistent presence of dry, tingly spiciness. The alcohol also comprises a major flavor component which has a slightly buttery taste with strong heat and dryness on the finish. Id probably prefer the regular Allagash Tripel to this, though Curieux is certainly interesting to say the least.

Drinkability: It probably goes without saying that a big 11% ABV Belgian-style Tripel aged in bourbon barrels is going to be a full-bodied brew in every way possible. Theres plenty of effervescence initially, though it does calm down to a soft mouthfeel with a creamy texture. Its difficult to drink Allagash Curieux in more than a sip at a time, though a beer like this is best enjoyed via a slow, savory delivery anyway.

Golden with a gods pale head. Aroma is apricot, marmalade, bourbon, vanilla, honey. Medium-full bodied, creamy mouthfeel, sweet on the palate with a hint of spice. Flavours are apricot, honey, bourbon, orange marmalade.

On tap. I am not a huge fan of Tripels, and even one so highly rated as this, I was not a fan of. It had a great look to it in the goblet, and nice sweet fruity aromas. It tasted far too sweet for my liking almost undrinkable. All I got was fruity liquid bubblegum, which was too much to handle. I found it very curious though for a Tripel, a nice change from others.

Pours the classic golden hazy look of a Tripel. Aromas are pretty good, dominated by the bourbon but enough of a fruity presence as well. Flavors are more of the same with the yeast balancing nicely with the harsh bourbon bitterness. At first sip you think its going to be boozy but the sweetness of the yeast saves it and mellows it out. Interesting beer. I cant say its better than their normal Tripel but its pretty good.

On tap at Cannery Row Beer co. Unusual but really interesting. Has the look of a cloudy wheat but the flavours dont really confirm to any readily identifiable style, rather an offbeat mix of spice, aniseed, boozy notes, fruit. Hard to place but this is the appeal.

Draft at Quintessence. Sweet bourbon like nose without any beer characteristics in the aroma. Mildly hazy golden blonde with a huge off-white frothy head. Too much bourbon in this. Tastes like mellow JB, but I cannot taste any beer besides the overwhelming Jim Beam. You could accomlpish the same results if you barrel aged busch light...
tap. golden with small head. lightly sweet. woody with very nice, mild spicing. subtle, but lots of wonderful underlying flavors.
Pours a nice gold color with white head. Aroma - caramel, honey. Taste is very smooth with vanilla, caramel, spices, oak, dark dried fruits (raisins, plums).

Clear golden colour, white head. Malty aroma, light hops, hint of vanilla, caramel, yeast. Malty flavour, light citrus, yeast. Light boozy finish, caramel, yeast. Rather nice brew.
(from 37.5cL bottle @ Cantillon Quintessence)

Clear amber body with light white head. Aroma has caramel, light bourbon notes too. Taste is light caramel sweetness, bourbon bitterness with long lasting in the after taste. Pretty balanced on the wood. Body is full, light carbonation.
I thought this beer was going to be strong and aggressive. It was really smooth. Malt, bourbon, vanilla flavors all present none standing out but together they outstanding. Excellent.
At quintessence. Hazy golden colour with white head. Malt, spiced, fruity and citric aroma. Sweet, malt, spices, fruity, citric, wood taste, with some bretts. Medium body.

Honey copper color, with a fluffy big head. Aromas of spice, yeast, bourbon and wood. Buttery malts, caramel, hints of spice and warming bourbon, evolving slowly on the palate in a very pleasant way. Also a wooden note comes up, body by itself isnt too huge, despite the unique mix of flavors. That leaves some space for mild belgium yeast, to smooth out the mouthfeel. Long yeast finish, with an underlying touch of bourbon.
Blonde dorée. Très sucré. Mielleuse. Beaucoup de bourbon. Noix. Boisé. Fruit tropicaux. Mangue. Cerise noire. Épicé. Anis. Girofle. Muscade. Légère chaleur d'alcool. Excellente.

750 mL bottle from Total Wine, Chesapeake, VA (bottled February 7, 2014). Yellowish-orange pour with a frothy off-white head. Aroma of light citrus, Belgian candi sugar, and a hint of oak. The bourbon barrel aging lends an extra layer of complexity as the vanilla and oak share the stage with the orange peel and sweetness reserved for the base tripel beer. The finish provides warmth from both the high ABV as well as the flavors. Pricey, but a great beer.

Bottle shared at Huny Day. Yellow pour with a white head. Biscuit aromas. Yeast and fruity notes. Good body and mouthfeel.

Pours a clear gold with a white head and lacing. It has a great oaky aroma with some bready yeast and a bit of bourbon. The flavor is gold malt and bread up front with a slightly spicy finish over a medium body.

This has been on my list of beers to try for some time now. I had this on draft years ago, and I believe the keg was infected. 

The appearance is translucent and light copper with a fluffy, tan head. The aroma brings an odd combination of Belgian yeast, citric spice, bourbon, vanilla, oak. Not off-putting, just unusual. Certainly an interesting brew. A lot going on, though I must say, I would prefer any of the better tripel beers to this. While the barrel-aging is well executed, I dont believe it adds to a beer of this ilk. There are some flavors that just naturally clash, and perhaps bourbon and tripels were not meant to be united.
Hazy yellow colour. Belgian yeast floral aroma and taste along with bourbon notes.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2015 750ml bottle shared in wine glasses. Hazy yellow with a thin white head. Some lacing. Aroma is of coconut, alcohol, vanilla, wood, spices, and some citrus. Taste is alcohol, bitter wood, coconut, vanilla, malt, and spices. Light body, thin texture, soft active carbonation, dry finish.

Excellent reserve from Allagash. Fruity with a nice 11% ABV. Blonde pour that just knocks your socks off.

A sweet phenolic aroma with golden color slightly cloudy. Taste of bourbon with a slightly phenolic palate.

Poured from a bottle. Clear golden color, medium frothy head. Not much of an aroma. Sweet bourbon flavor with a nice malt accent a nice finish.

Very sweet aroma, Im not that jazzed about the appearance. Too light in color. Nice bourbon taste, like youd expect in a much darker beer.
Bottle - Honey, grass and some wheat. Cloudy gold with a thin head. Herbal, honey and some pale malt sweetness. The barrel is soft as us the yeast profile.

Old review from 09. On cask at Julians/Providence Appears a hazy honey color - nice light off white head. Smell is little bourbon, some sweet malt, some oak. T - Light bourbon. some vanilla, oak, sweet malts. Alcohol lingers a bit too. Medium body. Light and subtle carbonation. Very nice. Very smooth and enjoyable. I enjoy cask beer and this one was a real treat.

A stellar happy hoppy beer. Expensive but a thick taste without that light sweetness so often associated with trippels.

Caramel pour with plenty of white head. Aroma of yeast, alcohol, dried fruit. Flavor is more of the same with spice and more delicious yeast. Amazing.

Bottled August, 2012. Not much on the nose, a little apple. Taste is muted, sweet and apple-y, almost no hops. Pretty nice, but missing something. Text on label says this well age very well. I strongly suspect this wouldve been better fresher.

Slightly hazy yellow pour with a nice white head. Lots of white lacing. Belgian spiced nose. Taste is nice - exactly what you expect from a big triple. Hints of wood and bourbon on the finish, but quite subtle.

75cL bottle poured into a goblet. A barrel aged tripel ... this one had me curieux ... sorry about that =). I spent quite awhile diving into the aroma on this one. Theres the banana, clove, and doughy smells one might typically expect from a tripel, but then, in equal portions theres a strong bourbon, wood, and seltzer water smell up front. The bourbon, wood and seltzer fade though by the time your into the first couple sips. This is replaced by a faint buttery caramel note with biscuits and even a bit of nuttiness. Its a golden-yellow beer (starts clear, but becomes hazy by mid bottle) with a beautiful creamy white head that retains throughout and leaves an abundant coating of lace around the glass. Its a good balance between a roasted bitterness and grape sweetness with maybe a very mellow touch of sour. Its a relatively light body for a tripel - probably a medium body in the grand scheme of things - with a creamy, yet light texture (if that makes sense) - the soft, but abundant, carbonation really helps out in this regard. The tongue is greeted by bready, doughy notes with some sour grape sweet/sour flavors. A roasty, but sweet, bourbon flavor rushes in shortly thereafter to dominate the palate for a while and warm the swallow quite nicely. The roasted bourbon quality (is that redundant?) sticks around and makes an appearance in the aftertaste too, but this turns slightly burnt and more like sweet caramel with a touch of astringency. The aftertaste lingers for awhile and evolves into an umami-like cheesiness with some nut-like tastes and a very faint hint of metallic (but nothing off-putting)

A lovely golden Belgian strong ale aged in oak bourbon barrels for a mild, sweet and boozy flavor, but not overbearing. Not much of an aroma to this one, but it redeems itself with a great mouthfeel and a distinct burn from the abv. Great beer by all standards.
Gyllengul öl med lättare vitt skum. Lätt surhet i doften, trä, jäst och en blommighet. Detta återkommer i smaken tillsammans med en trevlig örtighet.

Bottle from a shop in Cali but can't remember where. Big cork and caged bomber. Pours a beautiful clear golden color with a tall fluffy white head. Not a lot of aroma to speak of, some sweet pears, banana, honey, yeast, and a hint of bourbon for sure. Heavy oak up front flavor with some light vanilla and coconut. This fades into honey and light sweet fruits and banana midpalate and down the throat and leaves an oaky vanilla honey flavor on the palate for a while. Slick palate with adequate carbonation. On the heavy side for the style as expected to stand up to bourbon barrels. Overall this was an interesting treat but I don't think I would go for it again.

Bottle. Pours hazy orange with a white head that lingers. Smells of wheat and bourbon over mild carbonation. It's a boozy wheat Belgian ale. The complete opposite of the styles I like. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a stained golden with big carb and head. Aroma is big belgian spices with a nice touch of oak. Taste is a nice balance of sweet spicy triple and a touch of bourbon.

2011 vintage so it's about two years old. Pours a thick golden orange. Aroma is sweet and oaky. Mouthfeel is very thick. Taste is sweet vanilla oak bourbon. Overkill for me but if you like barrel aged beers you'll like this. Note: I've had this on tap and didn't taste early the sweetness or bourbon. I liked that a lot version a lot better.

This beer is very well balanced and surprisingly smooth for the high alcohol content ,its very nicely hidden. The nose was sweet like honeycomb and vanilla , the appearance was golden and was a pleasant beer to drink and enjoy, just be careful this one can creep up on you !! Enjoy!!
On tap at Riverside. Poured hazy yellow with thin white head. Aroma of sweet funky fruit. Med carb and bod. Sweet malty fruit. Meh

Bright, honey-golden body, topped by a low snowy white head. Pleasantly rounded aroma of orange marmalade, oak, bourbon and caramel. Maybe a whiff of something hoppy or herbal. Much of the same flavor wise. A nice orange-fruitiness is there at first. Medium malty, slightly sweet, with fine barrel notes and suggestions of whisky and toffee. Not more than medium full, soft and gentle in the mouth. Light sparkling carbonation. This beer has matured to be a gem. Balanced, light vinous, gently warming, flavorful and fresh-smelling. Awesome!

Gold pour. Nose is Oak, vanilla and a ton of caramel here. Taste is the same....big caramel, oak, vanilla, bourbon, lighter fruits. Booze is fading a bit (2012 bottle) but still lingering. Definitely a sipper.
This is an excellent american tripel. I didnt really get any of the barrel aging, but it has a great, crisp flavor. The belgian yeast spicyness dominates.

Nice aroma with some vanilla, oak and fruity yeasty smells. Complex flavors some sweets with nice fruity oaky vanilla tastes. Really nice beer. Would have again for sure.

Growler. With Brian. Has an interesting aroma that I can't place. Alcohol hits hard and not hidden well. Not much bourbon which is disappointing. Not great but not bad.

Caramel, pears, honey, bourbon. I love this! Great head retention. Soft palate. Well hidden abv. Lacks the wild yeasty funk that normally turns me off of this style. One of the best beers Ive ever had.
Light, cloudy with big, white, fluffy head. Light citrusy aroma...even a bit sour. Taste really brings out the bourbon with a hint of oak. Slightly floral as well with a mildly spicy finish.

Nice aroma of vanilla, alcohol, and light fruit. Medium mouthfeel, with the alcohol well hidden, although creating a nice warming sensation on the palate. Very nice.
(from notes)

Easy to get your hands on bourbon barreled aged beer. One of the first of this kind that I tasted and thought it was great until I got my hands on some of the others out there. Tastes great and will do if you are unable to land some of the heavy hitters.

Fruity ester aroma with yeast. Pretty champagne color with golden highlights. Lighter palate with good carbonation considering this has been aging for two years. It tasted like a tripel with hints of oak and bourbon. This was not as strong as I expected. Pleasing and well-crafted.

This has a lovely apple scent, like a cider, but not nearly as sugary. There is a hint of the bourbon just behind it. There is a thin but heavy white head that does not leave much on the glass. The brew is a cloudy yellow, again similar to apple cider. The taste is hearty and somewhat sweet, but not overpowering. It tastes lighter than the 11% abv would suggest, and has a dry finish. The aftertaste is light and pleasant. If someone were to give this to me and not tell me the abv, I would go for several of these and find myself heavily and happily inebriated.

Aged barrel adds great flavor and character. Family enjoys as well. Excellent finish!

This beer pours beautifully. It comes into the glass with a golden honey color and about two and a half fingers of head. The taste has subtle Bourbon notes but nothing over powering. This beer is decent but not even close to being worth the price tag.

Pours a nice golden color with a medium white head. Aroma is vanilla bourbon and wood. Taste is heavy on the oak and light on the bourbon. Overall another winner from allagash.

solid but I was hoping for more jim beam taste. the aroma is missing as i love my bourbon aroma. The tripel is nices done though but not worth the price of adminssion

An amazing brew. Refreshing, delicious and damn expensive! I would highly recommend this beer.

750 ml bottle poured into a brandy snifter. Hazy blonde with a white head of foam. Aroma is strong vanilla and oak and bourbon. The Tripel is completely covered up. Tastes like diluted bourbon. Heavy body and medium carbonation.

February 1, 2013 bottling. 750 mL bottle from Binnys Beverage Depot in Chicago, served in a snifter. Pours slightly hazy golden with a medium tall, frothy white head. The head mostly remains and leaves a small amount of fine lace. On the nose, there are notes of honey, caramel malts, flowers, Belgian style yeast, toasted oak and bourbon. The flavour is moderately sweet with honey, caramel, delicate spice, oak and perhaps a hint of pepper towards the finish. Hops are very subtle and subdued by the aging process. The finish is long, malty and somewhat floral. On the palate it is medium in body with a smooth, milky texture and average carbonation. Overall, this is a nice tripel-style ale with lots of oak and a touch of bourbon. I suspect it would age well, with the flavours harmonizing with time. 2013-07-21
Pretty simple. Lean aromas. Palate of apricot jam and honey. Quite one-dimensional. Very similar to Dominus Vobiscum Tripel.
Tap at Mikkeller Bar, San Francisco. Colour is clear deep orange with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Belgian yeast, fruits, some sweetness, hints of alcohol and malts.
Overall this is a nice beer out of a style thats not my favorite. The barrel and bourbon are light and not too forward. Sweet and lightly hopped with syrupy sweet malts.

The oak to bourbon ratio was way too far to the oak side. The oak dominated the flavor. It did improve as it warmed, but never to a great level. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from West. Thanks!

A: Light straw color with a lazy white head and decent lacing. 

N: Bourbon, esters, pilsener malt, hay/straw, and some apple. Some tangerine. Very funky, which Im not sure is intended. Biscuit/cracker.

T: Heavy on the taste of bourbon with an underpinning of Belgian yeast and sweetness. Lots of bread.

M: Lighter than expected with a slightly watery texture. Alcohols hidden. 

O: A beer thats really all over the place. I dont dislike it, but its not something Id feel the need to buy again, either. Bourbon doesnt really blend with tripel, IMO.

FROM NOTES: August 8, 12
Poured on draft at The Trappist into an Allagash tulip. 

A: Aroma has some upfront fruits. Banana, pear other lighter fruits, vanilla spice and a little graininess. A touch of bourbon. 
A: Pours hazy light gold with a minimal white head.
T: Belgian spices at first along with some candy sweetness. Woody oak and bourbon flavors follow with a decent alcohol burn. 
M: Medium bodied with good carbonation and very crisp. 
O: Phenomenal example of a golden Belgian triple. The barrel aging takes the edge off and gives the beer a super smooth profile. The price tag sucks, but it is worth it.
Thanks rbrazell. Milky straw with white head. Aroma of Belgian yeast pineapple fresh cut wood. Taste is slightly boozy but in a good way. Lots of wood and Belgian esters. Good stuff.

Bottle from J's. Hazy golden pour with a frothy white head. Learhery earthy funk, oak, sourdough, fruity yeast, light spice and candy sugar in the aroma. Nice lively body with the above mentioned flavor that leans in the sweeter side and phenolic oak finish. Pretty solid.

A: Mildly Hazy Golden Straw Hue, Passes Most Light, White Head Ring, Decent Lacing

S: Tropical Fruit, Apple, Pears, Mildly Boozy

T: Tropical Fruit, Pears, Nectarines, Apple, Mildly Boozy

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Boozy, Mildly Sweet

Overall, even though it is bourbon barreled, you dont get a lot of bourbon because it gets masked by the fruit flavor.

2013 bottle enjoyed last night with the wife. pours gold with a tingly white foam head that leaves a gentle lacing trail. nose has strong biscuits, light wood, grass. taste has a quick nod of bourbon before being washed by malt and booze burn. wood lingers on the finish. body is big.

Very pale golden; light Haze. 
Sweet aroma with Bourbon barrel. The Bourbon barrel is more obvious in tasting and approaches, but does not exceed, a reasonable level. Still, a bit more Bourbon flavor than I would prefer. Good thing this is a blend of BB and fresh ale. 
High ABV is partly hidden but there is some inevitable warming. Medium-light body with ample carbonation.

March 2013 bottle, hopefully the 2nd bottle survives 5yrs for an update. 
Initial oak aroma and a pleasant pears/light fruit yeast ester. 
Strong alcohol flavor, but not easily identifiable as "bourbon". Smooth almost creamy mouthfeel.
Nice clear pale ale color, with a clean white head with light lacing.

Tap at the Haymarket Brewpub, Chicago. The 11% version. Poured a slightly hazy medium amber with a broken thin white head. The aroma is rich oaky and alcoholic. The flavour is strong bitter with a creamy caramel malt bourbon alcoholic silky smooth palate. Given the ABV I was expecting liqourice and boozy alcohol but it wasnt there... just that silky smooth bourbon palate. This beer is packed with flavours and nothing dominates. Perfect.

*25.4 oz. bottle March 1st. date* Look: Brilliant golden honey amber, what was a 1 finger white head turned into a white ring around my glass. Smell: Bourbon, wet hay, spicy, honey graham crackers, faint alcohol, subtle flowers. Taste: Like the aroma yet much richer. Vanilla, subtle hints of coconut, nice fruity pear esters shine through the overall bourbon characteristics, nice hints of flowers in there with a honey wheat bread sweetness, no alcohol heat or flavor is detected, lemon zest in there as well, there is a nice bitter bite to it as well. Feel: Medium-full body, tight active carbonation. Overall: Man, this ale is a hit for me. 11% ABV is not even a presence in the flavor, very devilishly. The malt sweetness gives a little to let you know it is a big beer. Im very impressed on how flavorful this ale is and yet it is delicate at the same time. A lovely combo Balanced and Dangerous! The bourbon isnt overdone and the Tripel components are just right. Recommended.
Fruity lightly sweet smell...Slight banana taste...not a great flavor though...slight spice...

750mL bottle. Pours an orangey amber, big white head, nice retention. Nose is vanilla, booze, coriander and clove -- nothing hits you over the head though. Mouth is medium bodied and fruity with clove, cidery notes, bourbon barrel, vanilla and Belgian yeastiness. Again, nothing hits you over the head, this is extremely well-balanced and easily my favorite beer from Allagash.
On tap at Matteo's. Pours a hazy pale golden color without any head. Mild bourbon flavors. More mild than I remember from previous bottled vintages. Mild sweetness.
Draft at the Paris Club. Hazy orange with a white head. Mild spice and sour. Creamy and really good.

Pours clear amber from a 750 cc bottle. Aroma is coriander, vanilla, and sweet malt. The flavour delivers what the nose promises with mild hops and subtle sour notes. Well balanced. Wow I love the bourbon barrel infusion!

On Tap. Soft aromas of vanilla, clove and light bourbon. Bright golden appearance with a thin foam. The age is definitely present on the palate. Light bourbon notes with a strongly balanced herbs, vanilla, belgian yeast, cinnamon and orange peel. The alcohol is there but it kind of hides behind the fruity flavors.

Not as great as i had hoped... didnt get much bourbon flavor at all.... poured into an allagash glass out of a 7 month old bottle... personally id buy the triple or triple reserve before i ever buy this again
Bottle. Nice smooth flavor. Hints of oak but I didnt get a lot of the bourbon flavor. A little spicyness and some Belgian flavor. Excellent overall.

Aromas of orange, clove and oak. It has an opaque orange color with a fluffy white head. The bourbon really comes through on the taste, which gives it not only the flavor but also a bit of the mouthfeel of bourbon. Its honestly a touch too harsh on the bourbon for me, but to the beers credit, it is what it says it is. If you already like Allagash White and youre also a bourbon fan, this is the beer for you.
Tasted at the Fayetteville Foam Festival. This was a great beer. Big full flavor. Oaky and bourbon. Earthy. Very nice beer.

Thank you Kerry for the chance to try this fantastic beer. 

Pours a hazy yellow with a creamy head of bone white foam that fell luxuriously to a thick ring and left plenty of handsome lace. Body of the beer glows with promise and is the soft pastel color of golden sunshine. 

Nose is the definition of complex. Its sublime with bourbon, oak and tropical fruit to tempt. Theres a tartness and some mild yeast with a slight breath of alcohol. Picks up some earth as it warms and a touch of pepper. Light banana and clove emerge with a touch of vanilla. 

Taste follows the nose and unfolds like a symphony. The ripe fruit is sticky and sweet. Almost candied. The bourbon lays quietly underneath oaky and deep. The alcohol warmth and the pepper bring out the fruits so well. The woody quality and the vanilla accents the malt which is smooth and long and has earthy tones as well. The honey sweetness of the malt and the and the bourbon create a sensual mouthfeel that is strong and a little heavier than the usual tripel. The bourbon lingers int he aftertaste with a hint of smoke and the candied fruit. 

This beer continued to unfold throughout the drink and the fruits were varied and splendid. Pear, pineapple, apple, orange, apricot, mango. At one point I beheld coconut. There was a slight sour that gave an immense drinkablility to all the rich sweetness. The buttery smooth malt and the rich bourbon were the perfect compliment and added a depth that resounded. Lingered a touch hot in the aftertaste like bourbon and like sweet  candy. 

Captivating, expansive and radiant.

It is one outstanding beer that you can be proud to server your best friend, your best client, your boss, or your future father in law. It is a pleasant beer for sipping, tasting, drinking, paring with any and all healthy or unhealthy foods.
Great tripel that is casted in barrels from Jim Beam. Great aftertaste of the fine whiskey. Just a wonderful experience.
Tap at Upper West restaurant, holy cow, amazing tripel, super strong and rich and sweet.

On tap @ Rattle N Hum. A cloudy bright honey colored one with a small quickly islandy and sidesticking just off-white head. Smells really nice. Floral with Belgian yeast, grape zest and it has this sweetness thats hard to put in word. Almost like plums mixed with cucumber, banana, green canned apples and wood. It has a good oily mouthfeel with a gentle prickling carbonation level. Lovely flavors with lots of Belgian yeast, a little alcohol tone - not as much as I thought though and it has this grape/white wine touch written all over it. It also feels kinda gliding in the mouth and really vinous this. Light eastery and fruity tones towards the finish. Perhaps even a little swift of vanilla, but I could honestly not tell that this has been barreled on those barrels it actually has been barreled on. Really liked it though! 21.06.2013

Hazy straw color with white head, but not much of it. I was hoping for so much more on the aroma, Im not getting anything really upfront, but faintness of vanilla, honey, citrus. The flavor is interesting, very mellow, somewhat sweet, definitely picking up notes from the bourbon barrel. I taste almost no presence of the 11% ABV, except some warming and starting to feel it as its more than half way gone, but its not on the tongue. Overall a nice Tripel, just wished there was a little but more on the nose and tastebuds, but still well balanced.

Soft aromas of vanilla, clove and light bourbon. Bright golden appearance with a thin foam. The age is definitely present on the palate. Light bourbon notes with a strongly balanced herbs, vanilla, belgian yeast, cinnamon and orange peel. Overall, this caught me off guard. I dont know what I was expecting, but this wasnt it. Not to say that this isnt delicious. I just didnt expect it to be so smooth and well balanced. The alcohol is there but it kind of hides behind the fruity flavors. Id give this an A rating.
September 2011. Corked and caged bottle. Pours golden yellow with a white head. Aromas are buttery with spice and light fruit and some oak. Flavors are spicy and acidic, but very balanced.

Light bodied and oh so sweet. Reminded me of a triple with a dose of honey or sugar. Really tastes more sweet than sour surprisingly. On tap. Not terrible. Great appearance, ok taste

Draft. Pours hazy dark gold. Tastes sweet, dry, like alcohol, caramel, molasses. Light body and medium carbonation. Smells like wheat, citrus, grapes, fermentation.
On tap at Unos Hamilton during Philly Beer Week. An excellent American-made Trippel with nice barrel aged vanilla and oak notes. Always loved this one.

From bottle to tulip. Aroma of sweet grain and perfume. Pours a hazy orange with white head. As it warmed, aroma picked up some vanilla from the barrels which was very nice. Citrus and bread flavor with slight astringency.
Bottle shared at Proof (I think...). Saisony, light funk in the smell. Buttery, oak, sweet, white wine. Belgian yeast. 7.2

Pours a hazy yellow from the bottle with fluffy white head that dissipates to light ring of lacy head. Aroma of yeast, vanilla, oak, citrus, odd mix. Tastes like a saison with vanilla and oak over the citrus and yeast. Weird, good, slight boozy burn on the way down but deceptive.

Pours hazy amber with a medium white head. Aroma is lemongrass, coriander, lime, apricot. Taste is lemongrass, peach, coriander, caramel, bitter almond, vanilla. Aftertaste is slightly earthy with oak tones.

Hazy amber/gold color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of yeast, vanilla, caramel, & some bourbon; Flavor of sweet woody malt, yeast, oak, fruit, some hops, and spice; Warm bourbon/booze finish; Nicely balanced; Different - pretty good.

750ml bottle [Thanx David!]. Hazy dark golden colour with huge, frothy, fairly lasting, moderately lacing, white head. Fruity aroma with a green apple note, hints of wheat cereals, backgroundish notes of oak and vanilla. Taste is initially fruity, apple again, hints of wheat cereals, a touch of yeast, matching notes of oak and vanilla. With time going by the fresh fruity note decreases and turns the beers character in a more matured one, the BA notes gain more weight. A perfect example of improvement through BA by supporting and complementing the genuine beer without overpowering. Really unique!
Pours dark. Smells and tastes sweet, rich. Very complex ale. Some yeast, not too much oak coming through, bourbon essence works. Finishes lighter than expected. Good not great though.

Bottle at 16 Tons Taphouse, part of WBBF. Pours a cloudy golden color, not much in aroma, perhaps some spice and lemon zest. Body is lively and spicy, orange zest, lingering citric bitterness. FInish displays an oaky character, but not much Bourbon. Good but Im not as floored as I should be.
Clear gold with little head; aroma of bourbon Flava is of same and graininess feel a bit flat; finishes long and semi dry with notes of bourbon and oak

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2013 Poured from a bomber.  Excellent Belgian taste with bourbon notes.  What I really enjoy about this beer is that the bourbon is a supporting, not leading, role.  Bourbon mellows the beer out, but doesnt dominate.  Nice oak and vanilla flavors come through as well.  Top notch beer.

Draft at Prohibition. Pours a lightly cloudy amber with off-white head and blanket lace. Nose of bourbon, vanilla, oak, honey, sweet malt. So much delicious bourbon flavor, almost overwhelms the beer but it just taste so good.

Westmeisters Birthday Beer Tasting Extravaganza Beer #9.  Finally started getting to the big stuff around 6:30 p.m.  This was paired with a brownie trifle, which worked well.  Pours the color of an oxidized pear with a bright white head.  Sweet malty flavors mix well with bourbon.  Has a slightly oil palate.  Unlike IPAs (see: Doom), Tripels appear to do well with bourbon barrel aging.  Would buy again.  Bottle - Westmeisters House - Bottle

A - pours clear dark straw with high white head. Nice retention with spotty lacing. S - simple quiet aromas. Light yeasty notes, Belgian yeasts, floral notes, light citrus, strange bourbon hints. Astringent and alcohol ending. M - light medium body. High carb fluffy feel. Alcohol burned end. T - strange mismatch of flavored. Citrusy tripel and bourbon. Fresh orange, floral notes, belgian yeasts. bourbon, vanilla, oak, alcohol.  The flavored just don't meld. Like two different beers. O - interesting attempt but unsuccessful. Too dichotomous. 3.2

Vintage 2011... Crazy bourbon front taste followed by the triple deliciousness. Strong and tender...

750ml bottle, thanks to DanielCoor for sharing. Bottled April 2011. Totally hazy yellow / orange color. Thin white head, decent lace. Smooth, bigger body. Nice bourbon barrel / vanilla aroma. Coconut, banana, some tropical fruit. Big body - smooth, lighter, crisp carbonation. Very creamy and smooth. Nice long smooth aftertaste, great balance of bourbon flavors and fruity tripel flavors. Some oak. Light bitter taste. Less sweet. Alcohol well-blended, just a little warmth that buzzes on the palate. This is super, super good. Never thought that a bourbon barrel aged tripel could work this well.

Complex flavor. Lighter than expected with a nice bourbon taste in the background. 

alcohol, resin, smoke, white foam, clear, pale, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, light body, thin feel, lively, astringent,

Bottle from total wine sterling. December 20120 vintage. Has been resting in my fridge ever since. Pours golden with a few inches of white foam. Nice bourbon notes on the nose. Lots of apple and pear on the tongue with just a hint of bourbon on the finish. Time has mellowed this a bit as theres little alcohol burn going down. Nice!
On draught at Beer Revolution in Oakland.  Golden orange, opaque, almost no head.  Zesty, yeasty, dry and bitter.  Decent, with a boozy kick.  Has a bit of some extra to it.

Poured from a large bottle into a small glass to sample at a beer tasting.  The aroma had a citrus-floral blend with light grapefruit, touches of honey and grainy, and a slight oak character.  Its body was mostly clear with a slightly hazy gold color that had a large foamy white head with great retention, lacing, and cling.  Its taste was a good sweet fruity and floral blend with some citrus notes, a touch of sour, and notes of pine, candy, and oak.  It had a lively, fizzy body, and was somewhat wet, with a full mouthfeel and average carbonation.  Thanks for sharing, Eric.

Pours pale amber withy a frothy little head that fades to a film in a minute or so.
Aroma is malt, whiskey-like booze, and spiced apples.
Flavor is a complex tangle of malty sweetness, bright hop bitterness, with an dry, booze finish.
Medium body, mild carbonation.
Very nice!

Corked bomber. Pours a lovely hazy golden amber with a good head that fades slowly. Aroma a pungent, tangy well-balance sweet scotch. Flavor a big hit of scotch carried by a finely effervescent medium body. Tapers almost imperceptibly to a slightly citrus finish. Overall a stunningly unique beer with a very high drinkability factor.

Pours slightly cloudy medium lazy carbonation, dark straw medium white bubbly head. Aroma quiet oak bourbon, smoke. Mild start of flowery hops evolve to grass hop bite that rolls into bourbon bite with smoked oak prevalent in finish. Minimal aftertaste if anything oak. The aroma really aids the flavor which seems like it would otherwise be more powerful overall.

This is the best Belgian I have ever had and I have had my fair share. Very smooth, nice bourbon flavor, with a Belgian finish. I felt like I was sipping on a glass of fine bourbon, every time was bliss. Bought two more bottles to age, cant wait to taste it.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2013 This is an incredibly delicious beer. Im not going to go on about Its attributes. Its a beer a beer lover has to have. I love it. I havent had a handful of beers in Its class. One of the worlds best beers.

Maybe I just hit lucky with the timing - drank this at home on Xmas Eve - was given to me as a present. Quite simply, it was stunning - I cant fault anything whatsoever about this beer - as close to beer nirvana as youll find. Get yourself a bottle as my words simply wont do it justice....

Pours a lovely translucent yellow golden color with a quickly dissipating pure white head. A lot going on with the bouquet. Bubble gum, vinegar, olive, and green grape. Mouthfeel is nice. Medium-bodied, wet, and with just the slightest bite of carbonation at the finish. I get the bubble gum right away. Theres a bit of tartness, but it is very mild. Everything about the flavor of this beer is mild. I know its been aged in bourbon barrels, but I get a hint of Chardonnay. It finishes with a very pleasant oaky vanilla. Very good trippel.

Draught. Pours a hazy dark golden color with a moderate white head. Nose has some light sweet ctirus in there and almost no bourbon notes. Taste is a tad sweet with some fruitiness coming through. Very smooth.

Bourbon flavor dominates this nice brew from one of my favorites. Hazy amber color. Roasted aroma. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Smooth and flavorful. Golden color, full head.  A little alcohol on the palate. Not much aroma. 

Beer Buddy App, PokegamaCreek

Uploading ok ratings that were missing comments. Big boozy ale. Bourbon barrel comes through both with bourbon sweetness and some woodiness from the barrel itself. Awesome. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Mother of pearl, this beer is the master of subtlety, with beautiful malt and hop profiles and subtle bourbon, woody oak notes. Delicious, not to be missed.

Pours cloudy gold with a medium white head.  Aroma is Belgian yeast, grass and bourbon.  Taste is sweet with with very trace amounts of bitters, the bourbon seems to have rounded it off.  I really enjoy that the bourbon is present but not overpowering.  Medium bodied with a smooth texture.

Oh my god this is good. Pours a honey yellowed hued with a big white tight head that hangs. Bourbon Bourbon oak. Rich caramels. Awesome. Really good beer . 11% ABV but drinks like a 7 or 8. Hops are there but earthy English if any. Bitterness-not really. Great carbonation. Very nice. really GOOD beer very well balanced, that is unfortunately not available anywhere near me.. So upset.
