Similar to Allagashs Yakuza Belgian triple, but far better.  Pale, clear yellow, mild aroma.   A mildly fruity start finishes with a big, vanilla/bourbon finish that makes it both smoother and stronger than the Yakuza.  I really enjoyed it.

From the start let me say: Great Beer...!!! Thanks to Jennifer Mejias for the bottle. Poured cloudy golden just a little of white head. Aroma Sweet malts, fruits and bourbon. Taste, it shines, very complex very well balanced; is sweet, fruits, bourbon, bit of malts, citrus and a bit of yeast flavor... nice refreshing finish, not too dry, again great beer.

Not very good...severely disappointing. Had it at NOC NOC during SFBEERWEEK 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This beer has complex spicy aroma. A white color gives it a beautiful look. It has a sweet complex fruity flavor. Very well put together. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2014 A very, very good beer. Pours a nice slightly cloudy golden color, a little boring. Smells strawberries and wine. Taste is great, sweet, a little of the bourbon comes through. Nice refreshing aftertaste. Had on tap at noc noc.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Rich and sweet with generous spices, potent bourbon barrel flavor balances the richness, low hops.

Pours a very hazy, golden color with a decent sized white head.  This beer is very livey.  The yeast is very prominent in the nose, as I get mostly aromas of banana bread and dark fruits.  There is also a bit of the bourbon noticable, but not overbearing.  Very heavy bodied beer, and the yeast flavor sticks to your mouth.  Not overly sweet, and there is a bit of the bourbon burn on the back of the tongue.  I found this to be an excellent representation of the style.

A nice foam head that dissipates in my glass. The scent has yeast, fruits, and a slight sweet bourbon smell. I taste oak, yeast, citrus, sugar, and a mild bourbon flavor. There is some carbonation that affects the taste. The finish is pleasant with a dryness that fades. Overall this is a tasty brew.

2013.01.30 - Allagash Curieux - 750ml bottle in goblet glass.  Bottle marked "Bottling September 2011".  I've had this bottle for over a year and never felt in the mood to drink it.

Pours a slightly cloudy golden yellow.  White head is fed by moderate carbonation but disappears pretty quickly.  A white rig around the edge persists.

Aroma is pretty bland to me.  As it warms I feel like I can get some I whiffs of booziness.

Mouthfeel is pretty light.  Carbonation seems right on the money to me.

Taste is nice.  Sweetness on the front end, spicy and perhaps a bit bitter on the back.  Just the faintest alcohol warmth.  Alcohol well hidden for 11%.  This may be a great representation of Tripels but I'm not much a a fan of the style to make such a judgement.  This is one of the better Tripels I've had, for what that's worth.   Probably not worth the price of entry (to me), though I do not recall the purchase price.   To my limited knowledge/taste: no banana ester such as Merry Monks, plus a nice boozy warmth from the barrel aging.  Underlying taste is vaguely in the ballpark of Weyerbacher Seventeen, with pepper replaced by alcohol warmth.

Aroma 6/10, Appearance 3/5, Taste 7/10, Palate 4/5, Overall 15/20

bottle; hazy orange with small white head; Aroma-bourbon, spices, herbs, alcohol, woody; taste-medium sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, oily feel, average carbonation, long finish, warming alcohol feel. Really good

Wow! Très oak, très bourbon, très sucre résiduel, très blonde et très bonne... Javoue quà laveugle, jaurais juré que la robe de cette bière était brune. Jaurais perdu 20$ sur un tel pari, mais jaurais certainement pu me consoler avec quelques autres gorgées de cette bière prisée.

Reviewed 1/6/2013. Portion of a 750mL bottle poured into a Duvel tulip.

A: Pours a cloudy light gold color betraying strong carbonation behind the hazy body. The head is a one finger white shade that retains itself nicely for 11%. Also, it never fully fades away.

S: The bourbon influence is moderate here. It really comes across as oaky more than anything, though you do get subtle vanilla and coconut qualities in the aroma. The tripel qualities that pop up are very neutral - not really sweet, but not bitter smelling, either.

T: Sweeter than the aroma. The base tripel comes through more strongly here, as well. Initially, theres a neutral oaky tannin quality (which pops up in the finish as well), while most of the tripel flavors appear in the midtaste. Tons of candied sugar occupy the aforementioned middle of the palate. Finish is a combination of bread-like malt, spicy yeast, and oak tannins, while the bourbon contributes a subtle presence throughout. Im amazed how well the booze is hidden given its dryness. While that disappointingly doesnt give it the dangerous drinkability it could have, it really gives it a sense of finesse. Sure, a sliiight heat is evident, but this isnt hot at all - if you told me this was 7%, I would have believed you completely.

M: A bit heavy and sweet - but when the booze is hidden this well, it doesnt really matter. Dry at first, but the syrupy nature builds up after a while. Healthy carbonation tries to aid drinkability some, but the thick, sweet flavor renders this a slow sipper.

O: I dont know if its better than La Fin Du Monde, but its really damn good regardless. The booze is hidden (almost) so brilliantly I cant help but applaud - especially given its BA roots. Is it worth $18-20? Not really, there isnt quite enough Holy Shit Quotient in the flavors here. Then again, Im not a massive fan of the style. Having said that, its an excellent choice for those who love tripels and bourbon barrel aging.
By far on of my favorite beers of all time. This is my go to for special occasions or meals.

S: Unique blend - spicy Belgian and musty hay. Orange and coriander. Some creamy bourbon vanilla and oak.
A: Pours a rich hazy gold with a substantial pure white frothy head.
T: Odd mixture - tripel with creamy vanilla and oak. 
P: Medium, slightly syrupy 
O: Wanted much more, just didn't blend well

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
750 ml cage and corked. Light gold with a slight hazy pour. Bourbon yeast and oak aroma. Strong oak, vanilla and dark fruit. Very enjoyable

Bouteille 750ml, courtoisie de Hogtownharry ou Blankboy. de couleur dorée-ambrée et voilée. Nez de levures fruitées (agrumes, traces de cerises) et  légèrement épicées (poivre),  boisé (fût de chêne), moyen de pain, léger dalcool liquoreux doux, avec des notes de biscuits et de houblon floral ainsi que des traces de vanille. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture légèrement liquoreuse etaux notes crémeuses. Léger goût de levures fruitées aux petites notes terreuses (léger dagrume, faibles notes de raisins verts, de pommes et de cerises) et légèrement épicées (poivre) avec un goût boisé (fût de chêne, qui reste présent en arrière-goût toute la gorgée) avec des traces de vanille lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût malté de pain avec des petites traces de sucre brun et de de céréales fraîches. Parallèlement, lon retrouve un goût dalcool liquoreux moyen-doux réchauffant  qui mène à une finale légèrement sèche et légèrement amère de houblon herbeux. Post-goût moyen-long et moyennement sec, légèrement amer dalcool doux, légèrement  boisé avec des notes de houblon herbeux et de fruits (zeste dagrumes, traces de pelures de pomme).

Bottle @ CPK! Cheers to the guys for opening this! The pours a medium amber color with a small head. The nose is leather, dried orange peel, some herbs. Rich honey comb, and notes of dried aromatic wood. The taste is more wood, dried cranberry and orange. Some marmalade, mild citrus. White grape. Slightly hot profile. Hints of allspice and cinnamon. Complex flavors. Full body, slightly syrupy. Overall, not bad stuff!
Curtis and sour smell the taste is the same but then you get a alc hit...you def feel the alc. It has a light head a a mild cloudy appearance. Drinking the 1.6 gallon bottle for nye 1 of 50 12/31/12

Aroma is sour and citrus, and a little boozey. Appearance is golden, cloudy, minimal head. Taste is sour with a full taste of bourbon. Palate, body is medium, texture a little thick and oily, flat of carbonation, finish is long. Overall an excellent beer I would recommend to anybody!

Pours a hazy golden orange with a fizzy head that quickly dissipates.  The aroma is a delicious candied and dried fruit with subtle hints of vanilla and bourbon.  The taste and mouthfeel starts with a light fruity bitterness "pop" on the back of your tongue from the carbonation with a sweet bready malt base.  Hints of citrus and apple with mild oak, vanilla, and bourbon on the finish.  The presence of alcohol is noticeable with each sip.  Overall a very good beer but i was expecting something a bit heavier with more smokey characteristics.  Very drinkable for the high ABV.

Pours a nice golden hazy color with a white head that lasts a decent whie. There is an aroma of fruit, malt, alcohol and oak bourbon. Flavor is malt forward with notes of the fruit and the bourbon oak. Heavy sweet overall that finishes with a harsh bitterness. Body is medium, with decent carbonation. Overall a delicious beer.

Mmmm, Bretty. Plenty of head and lace, good retention. A stronger aroma would be nice; what's here is good. Spicy on the tongue, prickly carb. Bright, lemony citrus left and right. Really tasty, and somehow remains refreshing & drinkable despite the 11% ABV. Another winner from Allagash.

Pours light gold with a thin white ring of head. Smells of cloves and honey with some vanilla and oak barrel. The taste is sweet honey, clove and belgian yeast. Pretty tasty but not quite worth the asking price in my opinion.

Tap. Pours hazy golden yellow with a small white head that dissipates with nice lacing. Aroma is yeast, honey, a bit of wood and spice. Flavor is yeast, tart lemon, wood, but mostly the astringence rather than the flavor, strong honey and a bit of spice. Lightly sweet, medium strange bitterness that is not tied to any particular flavor; just present. The astringence and to some extent the bitterness fade after the beer airs for 10-15 minutes, but it was fairly offputting to me. Unique? Probably, and thats a good thing.
nice sweet hoppy aroma,yellow,clear, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, creamy, soft carbonation, nice sweet fruit hoppy finish.
Bottle. Pale yellow with white head. Lactic aroma, spicy yeast, some grassy notes. Taste of spicy Belgian yeast, milky, creamy, lemony. Dry finish. Not my bag but its ok

In bottle for #3000. Pours a blonde colour with a fair white head. Aroma of candy sugar, lemon, bourbon, oak and caramel. Similar flavours with mild carbonation and an oily mouth-feel. Nice with lingering candy sugar and oak again.

From 75 cl bottle shared at home.  Cloudy brownish gold with a thick white head.  Spicy and fruity nose.  Some conventional tripel notes - cardamon and orange peel - but with a soft oak overlay.  Very nice

Pours pale yellow with a big white head.  Nose is spices like corriander, cloves and nutmeg, some bready character there as well amonst the caramel apples, light citrus and vanilla.  Taste is mostly sweet with a decent bitter backbone for balancing.  Body is heavy and the mouthfeel is sticky and coating, long finish.  Wonderful.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2012 Aromas of peaches, apple cider, and citrus fruit.  Appearance is cloudy/translucent, almost opaque and the color of dried apricot.  Tastes like dry peaches, apples, and tropical fruit, reminiscent of viognier, spicey, and a little boozey at the end.  Prickly and bubbly on the palate, with a dry, spicey, warming finish.

Draught @ The Trappist, Oakland. Rated on 19.10.2012.
Pours a hazy pale yellow colour with a white lacy head. Aroma of floral hops, mandarin orange and honey. Flavour is quite rich with malts, coriander, caramel, lemon, strong sweet fruits, wood and subtle bourbon notes. Medium bodied, soft and smooth mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Extremely fruity finish where bourbon comes through and smoothens. Pleasant.

Cloudylemon yellow with sticky white lacing. Strong corriander and lemon aromas.  Palate is huge- almost overwhelming with the corriander. Some lemon flavor in there but everything is masked by corriander.
2011 bottle-Pour is dark golden with an off white head..Nose is big bourbon with vanilla,spice, oak, fruits..Taste is fruits, oak, bourbon, vanilla, cherry, sweet..palate is vanilla and oak

Form bottle: Poured a deep yellow color with frothy head. You can smell the bourbon upon pouring with a yeasty follow up.  Taste is bourbon followed by yeast, wood tannins and a little sweet malt. I did not get a lot of fruit from this. More wood and earth. A little over carbed and fizzy.

Low drinkability. Dark yellow coloured and hazy. Has a white head, medium duration. Acidic notes in the aroma, vanilla, oak, red wine. Sweet and acidic flavor. Creamy, acidic texture. Soft carbonation.

Bottle @ HenrikSoegaard tasting. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity, yeasty and a little bourbon. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 280912
Bottle. Frothy white good mostly lasting head. Dark yellow colour. Moderate malty and light hoppy aroma. Moderate malty and bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate.
Bottle, 11%. Clear deep golden with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, bourbon, yeast and vanilla. Flavour is malt, yeast, bourbon, vanilla, wood, medium sweet, fruit, hop and a little bitter.
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are yeast, fruits, notes of bourbon, malt and hops. Some alcohol as well in the finish. Not a classic tripel.

The best Bourbon Barrel beer I have found. The bourbon flavor is not over done. The nose is a mix of Makers Mark and Wild Turkey. The Taste is an excellent blend of spice and malt. The bourbon just shaves the edges off the hops and blends so well.

Careful, this is a true high gravity beer. I swear it ferments a little more once consumed.

Bottle, August 2011 vintage, 11%. Slightly sweet aroma with hints of resin.  Hazy beer with a thin white head. Medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, soft carbonation. Overall a tasty brew that does not drink like an 11% beer.

Draught @ Beer Revolution, Oakland

Pours golden yellow with a foamy white head. Aroma of fruits, wood, spices, hints of oak and vanilla. Taste is fruity and spicy with some malty notes and hints of vanilla, wood and oak. Finish is sweetish with some spicy vanilla notes and fruits. Alcohol is quite well hidden. Tasty, complex and enjoyable tripel.
Pours murky yellow orange with thin white head and some small lace. Aroma is citrus, whiskey, oak. Taste citrus, yeasty, clove, some sweetness, long tart sticky with alcohol warming finish.

Jan 2012 bottle.  Light gold with 1 finger white head.  Aroma is sweet and fruity, tropical fruits, banana, pineapple, etc.  Flavor is a bit blah, I get some barrel notes for sure, but not a whole lot of the tripel.  The beer is super smooth, light carb and good body.  This is a dangerously drinkable beer but the wow factor just isnt there.

This has got to be the smoothest 11% beer I have ever had the pleasure of drinking. Its not cheap, but it is definitely worth experiencing. A perfect brew. Had it with some french fries - simply sublime.

Big thanks to GT2. Smells very boozy. Almost too much - it overpowers a lot of the merits this beer has. Actually preferred the Alllagash triple. Pours pretty clear blond, durable head with lacing. Theres a good hoppy presence behind the alcohol here. Some banana as well. The price tag I saw in an American store recently seemed overpriced for this though.

Cloudy yellow orange in color.... Citrus aroma... Flavor is sweet and citrusy up front, with oak and spicy hop notes on the finish... Not very overpowering like you would expect from a beer aged in bourbon barrels...  Pretty solid

Received in trade. Pours murky orange/golden with a finger of white fluffy head. Smell is soft, fluffy, oaky, and maybe a hint of tart and funk? Some of the gum/clove come out with the Belgian yeast, but seems a bit subdued. Taste rich smooth vanilla. Very powerful. Oak and Belgian yeast mixed very well, no tartness, just the best parts of a trippel, but stronger and heavier. Interesting experience.

Color is a hazy orange brown.  Looks like it could be a cider.  Head dissipates pretty quickly so drink up.  Caramely malts and floral hops with hints of honey and wet leaves on the nose.  Its mildly sweet and not overdone like a lot of trippels can be.  The bourbon oak is not there in the beginning but as the finish rounds out it comes on nicely with vanilla and burnt toast. The heat of the 11% alcohol of my bottling flirts coyly with the idea of Bookers or Knob Creek.

On tap @ Stags Head.  Poured a hazy golden with a medium white head and excellent lacing.  Aroma includes oak, Belgian yeast, banana, vanilla, and bourbon.  Taste is complex, but well-balanced blend of tart, sweet, and oak with notes of bourbon, vanilla, and dark fruit.  Enjoyable smooth finish with flavors lingering after each sip.
12.  What an awesome treat.  The barrel meshes so well with the fruitiness of this.  I might have a bias because of all bourbons Jim Beam is probably my favorite.  Just an outstanding treat.

Golden pour, ample head, typical Belgian triple aroma. Tate is gelgian triple with subtle notes of oak and bourbon. Barrel is very much in the background, but works well with this beer. Maybe the nicest tripel Ive had, and certainly the most distintive.

Bubbly golden yellow with small white head.  Aroma yeast, citrus, spices, maybe a little wood.  Medium body, off-dry and some carbonation but not too much alcohol.  Flavor is lemony and yeasty, there is a little of the wood and bourbon but not a whole lot.  Its a very good beer, but I dont know, maybe was expecting more at least in the way of complexity based on the price.  And not clear that the oak really added much.

Tasting at the brewery tour.  Pours a nice gold with a moderate white top.  Aroma of sweet bourbon, belgian yeast and straw grains.  Taste is a nice dosage of the trippel *spoiled* with the sweetness and boozieness of the Jim Beam bourbon.  The bourbon is very present but not overpowering.  Great, great beer

Bottle (750 ml). Clear golden with a small persistent white head and nice lacing. Aroma of bourbon, spices, malt, wood and belgian yeast. Taste is about the same with slight bitterness at the end. Warming alcohol. Superb balance! Overall, this is a really good beer!

Poured with a Orange/copper color, The head didnt retain well.  That this was a well rounded beer (loved the mouth feel).  The alcohol, while present in taste, was an after thought, hardly noticeable.

Pours a hazy pale yellow. Aroma of currant and pepper. Taste is complex. A slight tinge of tartness up front is quickly replaced by a smooth sweetness that transforms into vanilla notes that then turns peppery. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.  Last beer while at OBX.  Poured a very slight hazy light orange color.  Fizzy head ended ubruptly.  Aroma did not let me down.  Nice oak bourbon notes on the nose that dominate, then followed by mellow beglium yeast and slight orange notes.   Medium body.  Ave carbonation.  Good mouthfeel.  Wow, this is great.  One of kind - a belgium trippel almost perfectly blended with JIm Beam Bourbon barrels.  Well done.
12oz draft pours a hazy golden color with a nice white head.  Aroma of vanilla, pear, bourbon.  Full bodied, alcohol while hidden, smooth finish

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2012 Bottle from local beer store. As tripels go this beer holds its own. Add in the bourbon and wow! The bourbon is not overwhelming at all. Very well balanced beer. Will most definitely buy again.

Pours a clear amber with a small white head.  Smells of dough, leather, caramel, hay, hint of floral.  Taste is a little sour, then bitter and sweet - hint of fruitiness and alcohol, oakiness, vanilla.
Poured from the tap as a cloudy, golden color.  A fine beer that should not be passed up if you happen to stumble across it.
The bourbon barrel aging on their tripel brew comes across as overly sweet more than anything else.  Tastes boozy, says the girlfriend.

Pours a Orangish gold, super thin head. The nose hits you with a cidery/woody thing going on Some grapes and alcohol. Alcohol, lemon, yeast, sweetness, burbon, grape skins. The burbon is really well balanced. This stuff rocks. Really smooth body.

Pours a golden yellow with a thick white head. Aroma of bourbon is muted, with hints of cereal and grassy malts. Stronger taste of bourbon is overriding, faint tones of citrus fruits. Long astringent finish. The alcohol melds with the bourbon flavor.
An excellent tripel, perhaps my favorite.  The Aroma and appearance arent anything to write home about, but this is one of the smoothest, most well-rounded tripels Ive had.  Deceptively drinkable.

Il y a des bières qui saméliore avec le temps passée dans le tonneau de chêne. Ce bois ne doit malheureusement être une bière pour la bière. Le bois doit améliorer la bière pas en devenir son ennemie. Ici malheureusement le bois domine tout, il prend toute la place. Une mince trace de fruit transperce tout ce bois et surtout ce bourbon. Dommage une bière mangée par la barrique.
Deep yellowish in color with a hint of orange. Thin off white head. Strong, distinctly Belgian. Very full flavor with a wine-like quality, yeasty, tart, and punchy. A great tripel.

01/2012 bottling, 750ml. Pours a hazy amber-orange with a frothy white head. Aroma is mostly of lightly toasted malt and yeast, with a touch of floral hop and citrus. Taste is mostly sweet and midly bitter with a touch of sour. Mouth feel is on the light side of medium bodied with a silky texture. Lively carbonation and a heafty alcohol bite that brings out the bourbon barrel influence. Finishes with just a touch bitter and sour, but with a sting and woody sensation, again really highlighting the barrel aging.

On tap 4oz. sampler at Judges Bench in Ellicott City, MD. 

Clear, pale yellow with amble head and very good lacing.  A visually appealing beer. 

Aroma of Belgian yeast, coriander, white pepper, spice and light sweet malt. 

Taste of light fruit, lemon, yeast, vanilla, spices and light sweet malt and oak. Bourbon is there but fairly subdued.  Complex, with new facets opening up continuously. 

Medium/light body and above average carbonation.  Wonderful light, foamy, spritzy mouthfeel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tried the December 04 vintage.  Nice orange/amber appearance.  Not much going on in the aroma.  Bourbon taste is more subtle than other barrel aged beers I've tried but you can tell it's there which is nice.  Carbonated on the mouth but nice smooth consistent taste, especially for an ABV this high.  Solid, but would have liked a little more action from the oak barrel aging.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap. Pours hazy gold with average, creamy white head; short retention and some lacing. Aroma is oranges, floral hops, straw and biscuit malt, Belgian yeast, and spice. Flavor is malt dominate with supporting citrus esters and faint hops; dry finish. Medium body and carbonation with high warmth.
Bottle. Aroma is fruity varnish, champagne, some wood. Flavour is medium sweet, loads of vanilla and bourbon, fruits, caramel malt, more bourbon, some alcohol. Nice, something different.

Pours a rich golden hue with a light frothy head, with an awesome bourbon forward aroma. Im not a huge tripel guy, but I really wanted to sample this. Half a glass later and I was quite content. The flavor is spiced, rich, boozy. Really smooth though. While its not a traditional tripel, I really appreciated the bourbon in there, which I would prefer to drink over a tripel anyway.

Pours cloudy rich golden yellow with white head. Smells like bourbon and barn yard funk. Taste is sweet, bourbon, cheese funk, and some tropical fruit. Full bodied. After taste is sweet, alcoholic and woody. Good, but Id like to put it in the cellar and see if the bourbon settles down a bit.

Hazy orange to yellow body, fine bubbly head. Wood, dimmed fruit, very well developed. Medium sweetness but great flavour. Solid carbonation. Very well developed. Surprised on the delicate quality. Not generally a fan of oak aging bit this really adds to the standard tripel character. Nice! (Sample from 75cl bottle, thanks Menno!)
Pours a clear golden color with a small white head. Aroma of fruit, esters, alcohol and yeast. Taste is quite sweet with a fruity and spicy finish. Nice alcohol burn as it goes down. Medium body.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2013 Tap @ Gramercy Tavern, New York 15/04/12. Pours hale golden yellow with a medium, white head. Aroma is sour, apple skin, some cherry and red berries, touch of vanilla. Taste is much of the same though sweeter. Sour and sweet with apple skin again, some slight maltiness, tones of cherry and berry. Much too sweet for the style and for the monkfish I had with it.

On tap at The Great Lost Bear in Portland, ME. Pours a lightly clouded golden-orange colored body with a finger-width, creamy and frothy, off-white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a solid lacing. Aroma is fruity and moderately sweet with a bit of a toffee malt as well as a light wood, a touch of bourbon, a hint of vanilla, and a light Belgian yeastiness. Flavor is similar. Sweeter citruses, apples, and a touch of melon with a smooth caramel, light toffee, and smooth vanilla. Wood comes out nicely towards the end with a light bourbon note as this finishes dry from the wood and a light hopping, but smooth and moderately sweet from the caramel, vanilla, and fruits. Lengthy aftertaste following a smooth, medium body and a soft, moderate carbonation. Overall, a solid barrel-aged tripel. Sweet and fruity, but nicely balanced with a smooth vanilla woodiness and light bourbon note. Very soft and easy drinking.

On tap at Sunswick. Pours a pineapple orange with thick white head. Aroma is rich of pineapple and bourbon. I mean, it basically smelled like a pineapple bourbon. Tastes like the real deal. Massive wave of bourbon and coconut. Soft but prominent amount of bourbon lingers. Delicious sweet coconut in the finish. Definitely a sipper but intense and awesome.

Pours a cloudy golden orange with a small white head. Aroma of bubblegum, licorice, Belgian yeast, banana and cloves. Flavour of cloves, licorice, bubblegum, Belgian yeast, banana, bourbon and wood. Nice complexity, dry, lightly spiced.
Tasted in 2009. Clear golden with large fluffy white head. Aroma is of apple, yeast, oak, light hops, and floral. Taste is of oak, pepper, yest and spices.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2013 Draft at Tattooed Mom. Poured a hazy yellow (greenish!) amber with a soft white head that left lots of lace. Crisp honey sweetness with a delicate bite. Lemon zest. Green banana. Fresh oaky favors. Bit syrup but enough sour and bitter to balance it. Fizzy on the tongue. An oddly refreshing barleywine!
Very nice brew!  Pours cloudy yellow with fuffy head.  Aroma i spice and lemon zest.  Very smooth in mouth an finishes clean.  Can not tell this is 11 Abv!
Hazy golden yellow color. Spicy notes, some light candied fruit with some woody touches and alcohol. The taste is of sweet grain with some sour and citrus peel (lemon/orange) and a hint of banana.

Draft at Two Stones... Poured into a tulip glass, nice head. Light blend of orange/yellow color.  Smells nice.. Some spices, flowers... Taste is light and refreshing. I wouldnt of guessed this to be barrel aged.. Light spices, flowers, citrus, yeasty. Body has lots of carbonation. Very tasty and enjoyable.. Hate the price tag...
On tap. A wonderful, intensely flavoured tripel. Spicy with grassy, citrus and yeasty notes and a hint of barrel character. Well balanced for the style; slightly sweet.

It somewhat reminds me of better half...only not as good.  I'm not saying its bad by any means!  Not much aroma, but the taste is well rounded...initial ale taste followed my a nutty vanilla.  Good, but not great.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle pours a clear yellow color with a thin white head. Scent is sweet with notes of fruit, booze and spices. Taste is sweet bourbon, fruit and wood.

Aroma- Sweet, spicy, fruity,some oak.
Appearance- Slightly hazy golden color with a average white head. nice lacing.
Flavor- Nice spicy/yeasty flavor of a tripel. some oak/bourbon. nice sweet/spicy balance.

A golden color with a large white head. Aroma contains some lemons, grass, and whiskey. The flavor contains some strong lemon peel, spices, and good ol jim beam. This beer is too light for barrel aging IMO and especially with discount bourbon. Very strong boozy finish. This is what happens when Belgium meets Kentucky ummm what?
Appearance is a hazy yellow with medium white head. Aroma is rather sweet. Taste is somewhat sweet, but really hits you with that bourbon undertone and alcohol. Overall not great, but not bad.
UPDATED: MAR 3, 2012 good aroma, medium in color and slightly cloudy. not too much head on it. strong flavors and high in alcohol
The soft head of this beer lets you get right to the best part, the flavors from the bourbon barrels.  They bring a complexity to the beer that is rich and spicey.

Bottle @ Dans place, Denver. Pours hazy dark yellow with a white head. Aroma o malt, oak, burnt caramel, bourbon, coconut, yeast. Taste is sweet malty, yeast, sweet caramel,oaky, coconut, bourbon, lemon, orangepeel. Medium  body, soft carbonation. Well balaned and wonderful, the bourbon barrels play very well with original beer. 220212

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2012 Bottle @ Dans house. Cloudy, orangish yellow appearance with a fluffy white head and good lacing. Tangy orange, lemon citrusy, oaky, light bourbon, toffee, somewhat yeasty aroma. Tangy yeasty, orange/lemon citrusy, caramel/toffee, yeasty, charred oaky flavor. Pretty tasty brew.

On tap at Timberwood Grill. Poured dark honey color with fine white head. Light floral, peach and spiced aroma. Flavor is a smooth honeyed bourbon with creamy palate and cinnamon finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Persimmon nose with green apple underneath, oddly tart for a tripel. Hazy amber, medium lacy head. Persimmon and peach flavor. Bourbon is prominent but not overbearing. Weighty and full bodied, but not viscous. Finishes oaky. This is a very multi-dimensional beer. There are sour, sweet, bitter, boozy, light, and heavy aspects to this beer. How Allagash manages to get them together all in one beer without creating a mess is a stroke of genius. It even has made me rethink my dislike of bourbon barrel aging. In imperial stouts it becomes a chore, in a tart well made tripel it is an elegant delight. Game changer.

Hazy golden yellow pour with off white head. Aroma of yeast, peach and lychee. Taste is sweet light fruit, caramel and definate oak whiskey barrel dominating the aftertaste. Nice carbonation and mouthfeel and alcohol burn is overly present.

Bottle for Super Bowl XLVI.  Fairly light, golden and somewhat hazy.  The aroma is fairly robust, creamy though.  The aroma is somewhat whiskey-laden, but wow the beer certainly drinks with a big whiskey kick.  Nicely blended into a smooth golden ale.  Outstanding!  (#4468, 2/5/2012)

750ml bottle. Bottled December 2011.  Picked up at a local grocery store. Pours a clear deep golden hue with a two finger fluffy white head. Very attractive brew.  Lush fruity aroma. Pears & peaches soaked in vanilla and bourbon. Quite a heady aroma.  Same fruits are in the flavor as well as the vanilla and booze. A bit of misc spice as well. Delicious. Full palate with active carbonation. Warming, sweet finish. A little pricey, as all of Allagashs offerings are, at $14.99 a 750ml bottle. Treated myself to this to celebrate my 55th trip around the sun.

Draught at Rattle N Hum, NYC, on January 30, 2012Cloudy golden color, white head. Sweet, malty, honey, alcohol taste. Gut warming alcohol. Smooth mouthfeel, low bitterness. Sweet, malty, alcohol scent, a bit acidic.

Dec 2011 750ml bottle.  Pours a lively crystal-white head that flattens to float a few millimeters thick at the center and covers the body with a half-finger-thick ring around the glass.  Lacing is white and covering.  Body is a hazy amber with sparse, small columns of effervesence. 
Aroma is mild: cereal, banana, and a little earthy.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Alcohol warms the finish very slightly and pleasantly.  Overall body passes the lips lightly, though texture swirls in the mouth thick and creamy.  The only finish is sweet on the tongue and warm on the throat.  A very balanced, mild beer.  Very good as I would expect at $20 for the bottle.

2010 Draft. Cloudy dark yellow with a small white head. The aroma is mostly vanilla, oak, and bourbon, with some lite spice and alcohol. The flavor starts out smooth and sweet, with an almost creamy texture, then lots of bourbon barrel and vanilla. Finishes with banana and warm alcohol and moderate dryness. A little boozy, but pretty good. Tripel aspects are quite muted though on account of all the whiskey barrel.
Draft. Pours yellowish with a big head. Smells of clove, cinnamon, and yeast. Taste is light with a boozy trail. Its an interesting brew. Liked it.

2010 vintage.  Sitting here looking at the numbers, and the more I try this beer the more it grows on me.  This beer has flavour to burn, yet is contrasted by being very smooth and delicate on the palate.  One of the finest beers that I have ever tried, and in stark contrast to the hop monsters that dominate my favourites.

From notes: 4/2011 bottling.  Pours hazy golden amber, with a small, thin white head.  Aroma is yeasty and sweet with mild woody and vanilla notes.  Palate is very slightly thick with a pleasant depth and some astringency in the finish.  Flavor is a touch sweet up front, quickly giving way to a woody note.  Notes of bourbon and vanilla in the finish that become more pronounced as it warms.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2012 (From notes). On tap @ BoHos Hollywood, end of 2009. Served a bit too cold. Golden color, slightly hazy. Nice, firm white head, retaining. Aroma: Medium sweet, some sour fruit/citrus, a bit sweet spices (wood notes came out more when the beer warmed up). Flavor is medium sweet, a bit spicy, hints of vanilla. Strong alcoholfeel, medium body. Wood notes really appear after swallowing. Geslaagd experiment.

Really excited to try this. Bottle, shared. Pours hazy, light orange-gold. Tight, vigorous white head. Nose is heavy with cloves, vanilla, earth, touch of bourbon. A bit heavier on the bourbon when it comes to taste, with more clove, vanilla, slight lemon. Effervescent mouthfeel, great, soft carbonation. Very nice. Unique.

750ml bottle thanks to my buddy Fowler.  2010 vintage.
Dull golden brew with a slight head.  Aromas of grain, oak, and fruit - flavor is fruity with some vanilla and bourbon.  Biscuit malt present as well.

Sankey Cask @ The Porter.  Pours a slightly hazy golden a good finger of white head. The nose offers some bourbon and oak with a sweet vanilla, spice and some banana.  Taste is like vanilla cream and buorbon mixes.  Not at all overpowering and the bourbon is very smooth.  You also get some oak, a bit of clove/spice and caramel malts.   Overall, I really enjoyed the fact the bourbon did not dominate the beer, but melded nicely with the rest of the flavors.  Very good and interesting tripel.

Pours a light golden color with very thin white head. Aroma is bourbon, yeast, vanilla, alcohol. Flavor is clean and crisp with Belgian yeast and bourbon; the bourbon flavor adds a wonderful spicy and vanilla quality. Very glad that I finally got to try this.

Fantastic Triple that has been aged in Jim Beam barrels. Beautiful golden coloring, pours with a very light carbonation and a white head that dissipates quickly. Oaky aroma with a definite bourbon addition, light carmel scenting with a tad bit of vanilla. Drinks wonderfully, the bourbon lands itself nicely on the palate while still letting this already great triple shine through. You can taste the bite of the alcohol, but its by no means a boozy beer. Great vanilla and bourbon aftertaste. A must have in my book.

Pours hazy yellow. Nose is slightly oxidized, fruits, heavy phenols, hops, liquor and wood. Flavor is spicy, barrels, vanilla, caramel, fruits, and slightly stale malt flavors. Medium body. interesting beer.
This cask condition tripple ale is awsome  . Brings more to the table at 11%  .head fades fast .sweet aromma and ever si slight burbon and oak notes well wort the price and deserving of high scores

Given to me as a gift by my friend Nate over 5 months ago for my birthday, enjoyed while watching the Professional on Blu-Ray at a friends house.  This stuff was fantastic.  Appearance slightly cloudy gold with rich off white head.  Aroma of bourbon, light hay, slight maltt, mostly bourbon but its nicely subdued.  Taste is smooth from the bourbon, has a light hay quality, a small crispness, has a wood/barrel aged quality to it, really complex and balances out to a great flavor.  I dont know what else to say, this stuff is awesome.  Kinda surprised this was actually an Abbey Tripel, didnt notice many Belgian notes from this but this blended so well.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2013 This is a great one.  Thanks Reg!  Woody nose, with well blended flavors of triple like fruits and a nice honey sweetness.  Dont think the bourbon really came thru that strong.  Very smooth, with a good mouthfeel.  I would search for this one again.  Clean finish.  First rate was 12/12/11.
750 bottle from Calif.  Would like to add;  Nose has red wine like notes.  This one shows off the Bourbon better.  Such a great beer!
Bottled April 2011 smell of coriander and citrus. Not as strong bourbon as years previous very sparce lacing....light amber in color easy drinking overall

750 ml bottle poured into my Allagash chalice. Clear orange with a rather large soupy white head. Mediocre spotty lacing sticks to a portion of the glass. Big bourbon aroma with the Belgian yeast sneaking in. Coriander, citrus and spices all play a role. The flavor are dominated by the bourbon. I dont think this base beer can stand up to the bourbon. Way to hot. Allagash tripel alone is a wonderful beer, just think the bourbon is too much. Maybe some age will mellow this beer.

750 ml corked and caged bottle. Pours a vibrant amber color with a small head that leaves some lacing on the glass. This beer smells amazing; oaky vanilla, bourbon, dark fruits, and alcohol heat. Taste starts with very dark fruits that eases into an onslaught of bourbon and vanilla. There is slight hop bitterness that allows the complexity of this brew to be rounded out. Mouthfeel is very silky and quite enjoyable. Phenomenal brew cheers!

22oz bottle. Pours a cloudy orange with a white head. Smells of citrus, orange peels and bourbon. Tastes of bourbon and citrus with sine spice and warming alcohol. Texture is syrupy. Body is full. Finish is dry.

750mL bottle, split several ways, pours a cloudy golden / straw with a medium white head. Aroma of Belgian yeast, banana, clove and some spices, accentuated by oaky, vinous notes - little detection of the bourbon barrels on the nose. Flavour of bubblegum, banana, clove, followed by subtle bourbon, licorice and boozy notes. Very complex and heated from the alcohol. Finishes with licorice, bubblegum, wood and alcohol. Very enjoyable, though Im not sure this style really benefits from bourbon barrel aging.

Sampled at the St. Louis RB gathering.  It poured a hazy gold color with a white head. The aroma was of fruit esters, barnyard and light bourbon. The flavor was light sweetness, fruit, barnyard, yeast, vanilla, bourbon and oak with a woody finish. A very good Abbey Tripel.
750 ml. Bottle pour.  Golden color with a decent amount of white head.  A great bourbon aroma and flavor.  The bourbon compliments the beer well.

Bière de couleur dorée légèrement trouble. Les odeurs sont plutôt faibles, tout en étant présentes, que ce soit du côté de la tripel et du bourbon. Le goût, cependant, est très bien équilibré entre le sucre et lalcool, subtil au début, en ce qui concerne le bourbon et en même temps très présent en finale. La palette très reconnaissable du bourbon nous allume en nous laissant une finale très claire, sans être trop prononcée.

Draught at Churchkey. Cloudy pour, the color of a grapefruit rind. Nose holds really superb bourbon notes with vanilla and spice along with good dough and nectary fruit notes. The flavor is the same but surprisingly complex and nuanced; the barrel doesnt overwhelm at all. The first note is the fruit, followed by beautiful sweetness and dark wood presence. Palate is medium to full bodied but drinks so well for the high percentage (assuming its the same as regular Curieux). Excellent. Earlier Rating: 6/2/2009 Total Score: 4Pours a dark gold with a fizzy head. Aroma holds yeast, banana, citrus, and a bit of bready malt. Flavor is superb- banana, grapefruit, and spice- very "in your face" and i think the 11% helps that. Palate is aggressive, but welcomed- one of the best tripels ive tried to date.

An amazing beer. The bourbon comes through in the perfect amount. Unlike many bourbon aged beers, the bourbon compliments the beer rather than dominating the beer. Smells of spice with a subtle hint of bourbon. Pours a beautiful gold. Taste is spicy and dry with a nice bourbon laced finish. Very tasty.

2009 bottle. Thanks mjs.
Hazy golden body, white head. Aroma has raisins, vainilla, bourbon, cereals and alcohol. Flavour has sweet bourbony almonds. Alcohol warmth is very present.

GABF 2011.  Clear light gold with a small white head.  Great aroma of oak, white wine, big blonde malts, and some cereal grain funkiness.  Flavor is blonde malts with some chardonnay oak barrel, a small touch of herbal hops an a bit of citrus.  Good, but nothing outstanding.

Thanks to some kind folks at Darkness Day
Pours a hazy blonde color with a small but well retained head that leaves good lacing on the glass.

The aroma is earthy and fruity with a mild woodiness & some honey. It really doesnt smell very bourbon-y at all. 

The flavor is fruity and kind of funky at first, there is a a mild bitterness all around, I swear I couldnt pick up any bourbon-y flavors on the first few sips, but man once I noticed it the bourbon character became far more dominant, plenty of woodiness, vanilla, light booziness. 

The palate is sharp and mouthfeel is moderately full. 
This was really better than I expected it to be.

I got to try this beer on tap and out of the bottle.  This was poured on draft into a footed tulip glass.  The beer carries fruity aromas of pineapple, candied peaches, musky oak and buttered popcorn.  On the palate, it is appetizingly sweet and creamy with some oaky pear, peach, candied tropical fruit and some taffy.  Sipping this beer is like drinking a very good, unprocessed fruit juice (among other things).  This is an adequately complex beer to begin with, but the barrel rounds out the fruity flavors in the beer and wraps them in an oaky, candylike coating which contributes to its sophisticated nature.  First class!

Bottle, bottled January 2010. Pours a hazy gold with a high, fine-grained white head. Nose has apple, vanilla -- definitely some bourbon notes in there. On the tongue, its big and boozy, with definite sweetness and more apple. Definitely a lot of malic notes in there. Prickly and tight on the tongue. Good now, and I suspect it would be better in a year or two.

My brother bought me this one. Poured into a trappist glass. Pours cloudy tan color. Aroma is bourbon, some oak and vanilla. Very interesting and complex. Flavor is similar. Palate is medium bodied, and finished oily. Very pleasant, and very drinkable. A nice warm bourbon feeling comes back up after swallowing too.

Much thanks to my "beer-belly"-ed friend for this 04 rarity. Pours a reddish brown, bubbly off-white foam dissipates fairly quickly around the rim. You can smell the wood right off the bat followed by dark fruits and vanilla and more oak. First sip is a little sharp, a cold carbonation-a bit more than expected, also a little boozey. Smoothed over after a few minutes caught notes of raisins, currants, malt, toffee, esters, and vanilla infused WOOD throughout and on the finish. Had bourbon-esque flavors but mostly just wood. Alcohol was persistent. Really good stuff!

Bottle poured into a tulip glass. WOW, this is a fantastic barrel-aged tripel. Pours a golden yellow with a small head and lacing all around the glass. Nose is citrus, malty, not a lot of bourbon.....but its there. The taste is citrus, malts, a sligh hoppy bitterness, with a bit of bourbon in the finish. Alcohol is not noticeable at all, certainly for 11% ABV. This is one of the smoothest barrel-aged beers Ive tried. Very good, very well balanced. Definitely a new favorite of mine!

750 ml bottle. From Boston, MA. Courtesy of mjs.
Cloudy deep golden colour with tiny white head.
Fruity sweetness, raisins, vanilla, toffee and quite strong maltiness in aroma.
Yeast, strong maltiness, darkish fruits, raisins, some vanilla sweetness and some mild alcohol in flavour. Fizzy and oily palate.
UPDATED: OCT 23, 2011 Draught, 10%. Vanilla aroma. Cloudy golden colour. Big stable white head. Strong vanilla flavour, cream and alcohol. Quite alcoholic.

(Bottle, bottled in September 2009, 20111022) The beer poured golden and hazy. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had honey, vanilla, raisins and fruitiness. Palate was full bodied and dry with medium carbonation. Flavours were honey, raisins, vanilla, sweetness, malts and low bitterness. Aftertaste had raisins, sweetness and bitterness. Very good trippel and the barrel aging effects werent too strong.

August, 2011 750ml Bottle; Pour is murky medium gold with an average white head in this tulip - retention is fairly nice, actually. Light, spotty lacing is present. The nose comes through with Tripel notes of fruits and grains, but the vanilla earthiness from the bourbon barrels end up dominating. I feel like that represents the flavor profile as well - it doesnt feel quite balanced, but it feels like a great beer, overall. Perhaps with some age... Anyway - there is a fruitiness present here , like peach skins - coupled with fresh grains, bread, vanilla pods, bourbon, and oak tannins - a nice attempt, for sure.

tap at Lord Hobo in Cambridge - The aroma is of alcohol and bourbon. The sweet flavor is dominated by the bourbon. Theres Belgian yeast in there and other flavors subdued by the bourbon.  I dont know if I get an unusual batch that was heavier on bourbon or my palate was odd as I usually like the barrel aging more.  This brew was good but my expectations were higher.

Orange color with a creamy white head.  Head fades fast and leaves a little lacing.  Sweet in flavor.  Taste and smell is bananas with a little honey.  Super strong flavor with a slight alcohol burn.  The bourbon barrel aging adds a hint of after taste at the end.
Split a 750ml bottle. Poured a golden yellow color, thick white head. Aroma was bourbon, vanilla, barrel. Flavor was pretty enjoyable, vanilla, bourbon, woody-barrel notes. Good, but pricey.

On tap at the Crunkleton in Chapel Hill.  Pours slightly hazy golden with a generous white head.  Nose is a tripel leaning toward a Belgian blonde with just the right amount of bourbon barrel.  Orange and light lemon notes, Belgian yeast and mild candied sugars, white pepper and wood.  Taste is similarly well balanced.  Great palate and a lovely experience.

A: The beer pours a slightly hazed golden straw color with a finger of white head.

S: Some bourbon and oak does come through, but its more vanilla and tripel.  Lots of spice notes to it with a nice banana and pear flavor.  Plenty of sweet malt, mostly bread, and a bit of candi sugar.

T: As with the aroma, not the most intense bourbon flavor.  Again, a decent vanilla note, though.  I do get some sweet fruits (mostly banana) and a bit of spice character (mostly clove).  Again, a fairly strong dose of sweet malt.

M: Medium bodied with medium carbonation.

O: Would have preferred a bit more bourbon flavors, but still very nice.

Tap at Paradiso Dupont. Cloudy glowing gold to orange with a small, white head. No lace- poor draft pour. Nose at first is sweetened peach, spicy apricot, and as it warms you are given more and more Jim Beam which displays buttery bourbon and spicy wood. Small vanilla. Liking the nose. Smells better than just straight Jim Beam. Taste is sweet candy, mild alcohol warming, sweet peach. Gets some off seafood/shellfish like flavors in the finish and Im not sure what is up with that. Good stuff nonetheless and I would certainly re-try.

From my Asheville, NC, beer log: On tap. Strong, aromas of Belgian yeast, honey, and bourbon. Bananas, honey and a little buttery in the taste.  Nice little alcohol burn in the back end. Soft carbonation. A nice warmer for the cold weather.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy gold with a nice white head.  Very complex aroma and flavor.  Notes of citrus, malt sweetness, oak, vanilla, bourbon, spices and pepper.  Some yeastiness as well.  Very smooth and the alcohol is very well hidden.  A very good barrel aged tripel.

750 ml. bottle, bottled on september 2010- Pours a hazy yellow orange with a 1 finger bubbly white head. Aroma is brett, cherries, very tart, woody, maybe even some grapes. The taste is mellow, creamy, a little oak, cherry notes, some brett. Carbonation is high, body is medium, sticky texture. Not getting any bourbon, just the wood it was stored in. I had huge expectations, and it did and did not deliver, thats the problem when you go into a beer thinking its going to be out of this world. But thats my problem, this is a beer that is definitely worth checking out.

750 ml bottle into tulip, bottled in June 2008.  Pours hazy golden amber color with a fairly dense 2 finger white head with great retention, that reduces to a fairly thick cap.  A bit of thick lacing clings to the glass as well.  Aromas of big lemon, clove, banana, pepper, citrus peel, honey-like sweetness, white grape, oak, and bourbon.  Surprisingly no real booziness was noticed, and there is a great amount of complexity going on here.  Taste of tons of oak, lemon, clove, banana, vanilla, bourbon, white grape, and yeast spiciness.  Lingering notes of of mainly bourbon, oak, and vanilla; with a bit of pepper, light fruits, and spices as well.  Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a decent slightly prickly mouthfeel that is still very smooth.  No alcohol noticed other than a warming on the finish.  Overall this is an excellent barrel aged tripel.  I would definitely like to try a fresher bottle of this because I hear it is even better while it is younger.

Golden yellow in color. Not as dark as I would have expected. Nice foam. Nose is lovely. Wood and vanilla.  Doesnt seem to be over wooded on the nose. Light fruit as well. Coconut and banana. Lotion. Tastes a little too standard. Surprised and disappointed in the flavors. Still really good. Above average without a doubt. Not worth $20 by any stretch though.

Poured into a snifter. Hazy light orange-golden color with minimal head that quickly dissipated before the first sip. The lacing really shows the ABV.

Smells of smoky bourbon, through and through. Some slight roasted malts, but that may be the overtones of the bourbon co-mingling with the malts.

The flavor one complex brew changes drastically as the beer warms. New layers become apparent as you allow the temperature to take effect. There is a fruity nuttiness and spice to it at first that is well balanced and rounded. As it warms vanilla bourbon definitely comes out with a little banana even. Very interesting to taste.
Tap.  Pours golden.  Aroma of bourbon.  Taste of sweet bourbon.  Sweeter beer.  Thicker mouthfeel.  Not much carbonation.

Let me begin by saying that tripels are not my favorite but this bottle has been aged for about a year now, and i find that it pours with a golden color with a quickly dissipating head. The abv of the beer is kind of overpowering so i really only smell the alcohol content and not the vanilla or coconut.  I find that as you swallow the beer it leaves a very nice vanilla flavor, with a strong bourbon aftertaste.  I find that Curiex is more flavorful when it is closer to room temperature.  Otherwise it is a very solid beer, but the high abv overpowers the other flavors.

Refrigerated 750 mL bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours light orange with medium bright white head.  Good small bubble lacing, medium/heavy body, and medium carbonation.  Taste is yeasty citrus to start off with then bam Jim Beam bourbon (oak and some vanilla).  Alcohiol has a strong presence.  Allagash Tripel is excellent, just get a bottle of that.

a strong aroma and taste of bourbon from the tap @ shortys NYC. Flavor of coconut and that "vanilla cream" character manifests itself in some order. Alcohol apparent like Bourbon. Golden ale. Used to really enjoy Bourbon so... no real wood and likewise on the malt.

(750ml courtesy of JCB!).  Bottled April 2011.   Pours a hazy golden color with pillowy iff-white head.  Active carbonation. Aroma has grass, hay, orange and a hint of wood and bourbon.  Taste is sweet from malts and light bourbon.  A little vanilla too.  Light to medium bodied with oily texture. Smooth finish.  An interesting combination of trippel and bourbon.

Pours a dirty gold and very hazy with a small, resilient white head with strong lacing. Nose is strong and malty with generous bready and sweet fruit aromas, along with some alcohol. Bourbon barrel aging is immediately evident in the flavor, and its too much of a whiskey taste (there is nothing subtle about it). The tripel qualities of fruit and wheat are overwhelmed by the wood. Backside is a little nutty and boozy. I love good beer and I love bourbon, but this is not a good combination. Perhaps the 8 weeks of aging should be cut to two to keep the whiskey to a flirting hint in the taste and not a punch in the face.

750 ml shared with JF A: vanilla some woodiness from the aging, a bit of spiciness. App: hazy blond white head nice lacing. t/p : body is medium with creamy texture. A bit of warness from the alcool. O: nice the wood truely add a little something to that one.
Bottle. Pours hazy light brown, aromas of yeast, banana, clove, lots of bourbon. Dry with some booze, noticeable alcohol warmth. Quite complex, a nice sipper.

750mL corked and caged bottle, May 2011 bottling, c/o Greg on his trip to Maine.  Thanks man!  Pours hazy, dull orange with yellow around the edges and a 2-finger white meringue-like head.  The aroma is sweet fruit; lots of plum, cherry, and some orange, with the oak lending notes of buttered fruitcake.  Some alcohol and yeast are also present.  The flavor is oak and buttery toffee, plum, and mild bitter citrus with cherry stones.  The finish is bitter grassy notes with alcohol and a moderate resurgence of sweet fruit and bourbon.  Medium to high carbonation and full-bodied, creamy as it warms, with a lively and dry mouthfeel.  This one is warming in the mouth, and all the way down.  Really pretty good, nicely balanced.  The bourbon is not overpowering, but rather complementary.  I dig this.  Thanks Kevin!  [762]

Wasnt sure what to expect.  Overall Im not a fan of "bourbon barrel" (insert drink or food here).  I dont particularly like bourbon (I like beer), but I do like Allagash.  Happily, my fears were unfounded.  Spice, citrus, and a little wood in the aroma.  More of the same in the flavor, but in a pleasantly smooth and subtle way.  Even the alcohol (11 percent!) doesnt overpower.  Another really good effort from one of my favorite breweries.

Draft @ Coalhouse Pizza, Stamford, CT. Maybe it is due to its improper glassware (served in a mason jar), but I was unable to enjoy this beer. Too heavy and bready for my tripel likings and there was a very strong tangerine flavor that masked any possible flavor in the beer.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2011 2011 Vintage (11%ABV). Pours hazy golden orange with a small white head. Smells exceptional; hints of spices (coriander) and faint hops and vanilla from the bourbon barrels. Tastes like a smoother Belgian Tripel, with vanilla and some alcohol on the back end. Full-bodied with a smooth texture and present mouth-carbonation, Allagash Curieux finishes with faint sweetness and alcohol burn.

Pours a cloudy light golden color with a thick head.  Aroma is of spices, orange peels, oak, vanilla, and coriander.  Flavor definitely has a bit of citrus, with spices (clove & coriander), vanilla, oak, and nutmeg.  This one seems to be a little bit more champagne(y) than other tripels.  Just slightly over carbonated.  Overall, though, this was a pleasant brew.

From GRBNY.  The aroma is whiskey, fruity, sweet.  The appearance is hazy yellow, white head.  The flavor is whiskey again, malty, fruity.  The finish is a nice booze warming.  Signature of Jim Beam is all throughout this beer.  Medium in body.  Quite good.

Careful, this one will knock you on your ass if you arent ready.  Dark and full yellow, much less head and lacing than a normal tripel.  Extremely smooth and sweet, such as a tripel, but with a lot of oakiness on top.  Its a little thicker than a normal tripel and I strongly suggest letting it warm up a bit, youll get a lot more flavor that way.
Aroma of champagne, sour dough, and lemon.  Pours light orange with a small foamy head.  Heavily carbonated.  Tastes of champagne, sour malts and a little creme.  Tasty and tart.

On tap at The Neighborhood San Diego.  Medium head nice lacing and cloudy yellow.  Aroma of blended whiskey predominates and carries to taste but beer carries it really well and masks alcohol.  Beer base is reminiscent of a spicy Belgian white with coriander and citrus.

Like many bottle conditioned beers, this one takes on a whole different feel from the bottle then it does on draft. Pours a nice gold, with a nice finger of head on it. The aroma is light fruit like pears and apples, with just a hint of alcohol. the mouth feel is smooth a refreshing. So much flavor packed in, yet so crisp. As it warms the fruit and belgian tang becomes very present. This is definetly on of my favorites!

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2013 mondial 2011 in mtl and bottle at home. pours golden blond with a decent off-white head, little retention, strong lacing. aroma is cherries, bretts, yeasty, oaky, fruity and malted sweetness. also, bourbon in taste, bubblegum, alcohol, tons of malts. light to medium hopping - grassy and somewhat citrusy. very belgium bubbly, full bodied.

Bottle pours gives cloudy orange-yellow color with foamy white head.  Aroma of sour light fruits. Taste citrus, orange, spices, yeast with some oak.  As the beer warms the bourbon becomes more apparent but never becomes a strong component  Full  and  slightly thick palate with a lot of carbonation, no stickiness.  Finish oak, slight bourbon, slight hops.  Guess I was expecting more but this is a fairly strong tripel with slight bourbon and oak overtones..  Not bad but will not seek out.

Sample at Mondial de la Bière (Montréal). Cloudy golden body with an average white foamy/creamy head. Good malty/hoppy aroma with herbal, yeasty, and spicy hints. Alcohol is very well hidden. Taste carries herbal, honeyish, and yeasty notes. Ends with a good bittersweet finish.

Bottle sampled at Mondial de la bière 2011. Clear golden with a medium white head with good retention and nice lacing. Aroma is sweet and sour with sugar, pale malt, honey, herbal hops and wood. Flavor is Sweet malt, alcohol, yeast, honey, lots of residual sugar, bourbon, wood, herbal notes, moderate bitterness and a sweet aftertaste. Medium to full body with a sticky mouthfeel.
On tap at the ACBF. Yellow pour with a short head. The bourbon oak really shines through over layers of stone fruit and spice. Very woody and spicy on the palate with a good fruitiness behind it.

Bubbly, burny, yeasty, tasty.  Smells like whisky, oak, and yeast.  Very yeasty, with a tiny bit of Belgian spice underneath.  But, man, how pretty this beer pours out of the bottle.  Dont know why, but I expected it to be darker;  still, the slightly hazed golden yellow color is striking, and the head sits around like a giant marshmallow.  Tastes boozy;  at first, that is.  The subtle Belgian sweetness and oaky finish are masked by the straight bourbon battery that powers this bottle.  Complex, kinda harsh, but worth the burn.  (8/18/08)

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2011 same belgian yeasts, I asked adn there is a specific belgian yeast strain to allagash. Thats why you can taste the allagash flavor. This is very subtle, not to much going on. A little sweetness added from the bourbon barrel aging.
Hazy yellow, very hazy, with nice dense white head.  The head left real nice lacing.  Faint citrus and yeast in the nose.  Spicy, yeasty flavor, not too sharp.  A nice drinkable triple.

Review 6/5/2009
March 2009 Bottling.

So the wife dragged me to the grocery store on a day when we had no kids and I snuck this bottle into the shopping cart. Shh dont tell her how much it cost :)

Pours a slightly cloudy Golden color with a big bubbly white head that sticks around for a while and coats the side of the glass. Smells of Phenolics, oak, alcohol, citrus, lightly fruity, some bubblegum, and spicy yeast. Taste is filled with fruits, oak, alcohol. A bit sweet with a semi-dry finish. Leaves a lingering alcohol hot/sweetness in the finish. Carbonation is high, body is full, mouthfeel is sweet creamy. Great Oak aged Belgianesque brew. Not something I would enjoy often, but great to try.
25 oz cork & cage from @markskar via @joshareed.  Pale orange/yellow pour, fluffy white head.  Oaky, boozy aroma and flavor with a bit of funk.  Dry hoppy finish.

Big, corked and wired  bottle. Bottled february 2007, enjoyed with friends april 2011. Bright, honey-golden body, topped by a low snowy white head. Pleasantly rounded aroma of orange marmelade, oak, bourbon and caramel. Mayby a whiff of something hoppy or herbal.  Much of the same flavorwise.  A nice orange-fruitiness is there at first. Medium malty, slightly sweet, with fine barrel notes and suggestions of  whisky and toffee. Not more than medium full, soft and gentle in the mouth. Light sparkling carbonation. This beer has matured to be a gem.  Balanced, light vinous, gently warming, flavorfull and fresh-smelling. Awesome!

Bottled in February 2011, drunk April 30, 2011.  I was expecting this to be much darker: pours a clear copper yellow with a perfect head of white.  Smells like Kentucky bourbon with hints of spice and melon (watermelon?).  A medium body of delicate complexity that unravels into a palatable array of flavors: bourbon whiskey, vanilla, creamy watermelon, cantaloupe, pepper, hints of clove and a nicely rounded boozy warmth.  The finish is very dry with a lingering of straight  bourbon and vanilla.  A very curious beer that is a little too doused in bourbon for my taste.  Like most pre-used barrel beers (whisky, wine, etc.) I find that whatever sat first dominates the flavor.

Thank you Gully. (December 2008 bottle) Dark honey brown with a good cap. The smell is soooooooooooooooooo good, very different and not what I expected. Wheat, pineapple, pinna colada, vanilla. Yeast, and not a trace of the alcohol.  Taste is spectacular!!! Dam being the DD today I only get half a glass I HATE YOU ALL SO MUCH!!!! I think this is my first liquor aged triple and wow does it work, you taste all the Belgium spices and wheat and yeast and the addition of the bourbon aging does awesome things to this. The bourbon gives this beer an awesome sweet vanilla character, its like drinking a rye and coke but none of the liquor heat shows up. More pineapple, hints of fresh bread a touch of wood but its a struggle to taste that. Lemon and spice are showing up now at the end of my tiny half-filled glass.  So awesome.

Very unique beer. On tap at Threepenny in Montpelier. Flavor at first is almost all bourbon and vanilla--a bit lopsided. But it gets more even as it warms a bit, sweetness mellows a little with a little bit more alcohol coming through.

Dec 2008 bottle. Thanks to Glouporogorourogolorp for this exceptional brew. Poured out a dirty murky dull orange brew as I was sharing this, I got the bottom section of the bottle. Killer aroma. Vanilla, yeast, plummy slight oxidization, endless sweetness, touch of booze, caramel coated apple, some sort of cherry. The taste is also very good but not as good as the aroma. Candy, light alcohol, plenty of muted citrus, buns, orange rind spice, bit of oxidization that does not bother me what so ever. Some boozy inhalations, hits of lightly spicy yeasts, peanut shells on the sickly belch that just crashed out of my mouth, more things. k, im fairy drunk at this point and highly relying on spell check to do its job... unlike last night where spell check was obviously hammered. YOU DO NOT DEFINE ME YOU BASTARD! This was a very tasty beer but i would think that I waited to long... still - highly enjoyable and I know my guests really really dug this beer so it was worth just that much more to me. Dammit.. Im drunk again and I am sick of seeing red squiggles everywhere that need a fixin

Poured a hazy yellow color with a white foamy head.  Lots of alcohol and bourbon in the aroma.  Also some yeasty notes with some banana and orange.  Taste is very flavorful and creamy.  The bourbon is noticeable, but the alcohol is well hidden.  Some malty flavors and fruity notes.  Aftertaste is smooth creamy and fruity.  Overall very interesting, I was worried about what a bourbon barrel tripel would taste like, but I like it!

Pours a very light yellowish orange color.  Very hazy!  Has a pretty sweet white foamy head.  Smells of wheat with some bourbon flavors mixed in!  Some yeast and a bit of orange as well.  Taste is different.  I have never had a non stout beer aged in bourbon barrels.  Little bit of the wheat at the beginning with the bourbon definitely present.  I kinda like.  Intrigues me.

750ml bottle from Julios. 
Appearance : Clear pale amber.

Aroma : Light malt with light bourbon. Light yeast and light vanilla.

Taste : Light vanilla with nice citrusy and malty notes. Light spices. Some wood. 

Overall : Interesting but nothing very special. Nice light wood and light vanilla/bourbon. Nose a bit better than taste.
Oaky, whiskey notes.  Golden in color.  Dull sweetness with excellent...and thats where my notes ended, oops.

The beer is a great dark gold with just a hint of orange. It has a nice bubbly finger head that is white lasting about 2 minutes, then leaving behind a light white filmy head. The lacing is great. 

The aroma is pretty light, wish it was a little more full. There are some light flowers with just the tiniest scent of oak. 

The taste is great the frone end is what you expect of a triple light and hoppy and floral and drinkable. Then at the end it comes burst with more flavor with some really nice oak nots.

The feel is great and nice lasting feel. It is highly drinkable.

This big beer was a draft pour at The Ale House in Amesbury, MA. It came in the glass a hazy gold with fizzy white head and lots of fine lacing in the glass. Nose of whisky and spices.   Medium body and a very smooth mouthfeel considering all that alcohol The flavor is rich and shows some clove. A very drinkable  beer.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2012 On cask. It is fruity and bourbonny, not the best mix for the Tripel but passable. HAd it in bottle alongside the regular recently. It wasnt at odd of a mix in the bottle. Very phenolic still.

Cloudy straw pour with a huge white head that will not die down. Its like whipped cream on top of my beer, and coats the glass like paint, or frosting. Or something that is sticky sweet. Smells like a tripel with a hint of bourbon in there. Bit of a pepper aroma and alcohol mixed in. Tastes of bourbon up from with a nice tripel underneath. I think this would be a fine beer even if it wasnt aged in bourbon barrels. Nice sweet mouthfeel with just a slight burn from the alcohol. Nicely balanced beer.

aroma and color are fairly typical of a tripel, but thats where the similarities end, the taste is more full than most tripels, and the overall body feels more complex. the tight carbonation reminds me of a champagne, phenominal beer, even if its way expensive.

Pours copper with very little off-white head.  Smells like lots of bourbon up front.  Hot.  Nearly antiseptic with peppermint, caramel, bourbon, and oak.  Belgian yeast esters of banana and apple smooth out the somewhat abrasive nose.  Nice, but could dial back the bourbon a bit.

750ml bottle, cask 653 november 2009. Hazy, partly cloudy, no head and light lacing. Not much aroma, spicy, citrus, almost like a wheat beer. great mouthfeel, incredibly sweet, some carbonation, some bitterness on the palate. Very creamy, silky, and delicious. Although not that special at the beginning its very tasty the rest of the way. Will need to get some more.

The Big Hunt, DC tap ($8): Pours a cloudy yellow with a white head. Aroma is a crazy mix of a tripel and whiskey and wood. So there are the fruit flavors really taking second whistle to the oak-aged aspects (in my opinion). This is a unique combination for a beer and I am not positive that it works that well. Ive had other oak-aged beers and they are generally of the darker variety. I must say that some of those I think are hard to drink because of the whiskey flavors, whereas this one is somewhat more manageable. You get the fruit and the yeast here, but for me its mostly an exercise in oaking. There is a synthesis, but I dont think I would want to drink it again, even if I enjoyed it the first time around.

Serving: 750 ml. bottle from a friend. 
The nose is musty with a good bit of oak and a touch of bourbon.  The color is dark gold with a frothy, white head.  The flavor is musty with a touch of bourbon, paper, and alcohol.  A Belgian with a bourbon finish.  Medium bodied with higher than average carbonation leading to a bourbon barrel finish.  An interesting mix but not one I am sure I am a fan of.

Belgian Trippel style. This is probably the most complex beer I have ever tasted. Caramels, vanilla, tobacco, crazy fruity undertones that I cant even identify... and then the finish leaves a nice aged Bourbon taste in your mouth. This stuff is rather strong too, so it has a nice warming effect.  One of my all time favorites.

Reviewed from notes.

Pours a lift caramel color that is somewhat opaque. Nose brings forward a god dose of light bourbon along with some caramel sweetness and bread. Sligt spicing. The taste just doesnt really work for me, with some strange bread and banana interacting with the bourbon. It sounds good, but just isnt very appetizig to me. Mouthfeel is a bit boozy and thin. This one just did not work for me.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-07-2010

Huge thanks to Leo. Wow, this shit smells wonderful.  Almonds, vanilla and rice, in the best acceptation possible. Round and warm, inviting. The last glass develop a little ethylic touch. Remains very elegant. Forget to mention that is golden and very clear. The flavour is sweet, with a quite dry end.

Rate #280. 750 ml bottle. Bottled: April 2010, 690 cases. Poured an almost opaque faded gold/straw with a very firm off-white head.  Fair amount of sediment in my glass. Aroma: sour-ish fruits, bourbon saturated wood, maybe vanilla, Belgian yeast, hops. Taste: Sour fruits, lemon zest, funk/barnyard, strong bourbon saturated wood, maybe vanilla, understated hop profile. Medium but full body, loaded with flavors and very balanced. Overall: unique is an understatement... this is a Bourbon Barrel Aged Triple, and it does have that, but it also had this Saison edge to it. Very complex. I really enjoyed this but I bet 2 or 3 years sitting in a cool cellar would make this even better.
Bottle. Pours cloudy apricot with white head. Nose and taste of honey, toffee, barrel, lemongrass and yeast. Lost of alcohol in the finish.

On tap at the Brick Store Pub. Pours a bright, hazy yellow with a pillowy white head and tons of lacing. The aroma is caramel, vanilla, orange and lemon citrus notes, cloves and other spices. The flavor is very bitter, but balanced well with malts and mellowed with bourbon flavors. The palate is heavy and thick, but very smooth with only a slight bitter finish. Overall, an excellent beer. A simple idea executed perfectly.

Looks like a triple. Hazy yellow with a nice white head. Vanilla and stone fruits on the nose. Some banana as well. With lots of bourbon as well. Flavour is great ! classic triple Flavour with tons of bourbon and wood. Very spicy in the finish. This is the most unique barrel aged beer i have ever had. It is great!

Bottle, withmany thanks to Curly. Pours hazy golden yellow, thin yet persistent white head, spotty lacing. Nose is light bourbon, with traces of banana, confectionary, spice, white pepper, lemon drops, fresh cream, vanilla, smells like a bourbon/lemon meringue pie. It smells like baked goods and brown liquor even more strongly than my grandmother!!! Bourbon comes out to play much more strongly on the palate, with the citrus and spice still present, but rather behind the vanilla/toast/corn whiskey notes. Nice balance between citrus/candy sweetness, and bourbon sourness. Well balanced, but I feel the prettier floral/confectionary  notes are as masked by the bourbon in the mouth as they are accentuated by the borubin in the nose. A double-edged sword. Still a very nice beer. Ive had a few barrel-aged Tripels, but those were soured by and large. This an interesting beer, perhaps not one Id pay $20 for again, but very pretty, and yet with the bourbon very masculine. This beer walks a razors edge, and is generally succesful at it. Good show, Allagash!

Hazed apple juice color with a big fluffy white head that settles down pretty quickly. The aroma takes a bit more time to grasp. I initially get some fruity aspects from orange and lemon peel, with a sugared candy (cherry?) backing. Eventually as I warm up to the beer I get sweet vanilla bean from the bourbon barrels peaking through. This is a peculiar beer that takes some time understanding. Like the smell, the taste first offers a sweet tangy flavor, kind of syrupy. I am wondering where the Bourbon is. Then about half way through as the beer warms up, the Bourbon comes out of no where and dominates the palate. With a complexity of different flavors coming into play, Curieux feels like a delicate sipper, very warming as bourbon and vanilla give rise. I really enjoy the woody essence the barrels give off to interplay with the malts and spicy yeast flavor.

750 ML bottle. Pours a very nice looking hazy gold with soapy white head. Aroma has nice fruit esters, barnyard, light bourbon. Flavor has a light sweetness, fruit, barnyard, yeast, vanilla, bourbon and oak, woody finish. Mouth feel is medium body with fizzy carbonation. Overall, a very pleasant brew and the bourbon notes blend in nicely! Good Stuff!

On tap at the Trappist in Oakland. It pours a bright orange/yellow with a nice white head. The aroma is soaked in bourbon with some tropical fruitiness and a hint of yeasty spice. The flavor is again overpowered by the bourbon unfortunately. Lots of sweet caramel, vanilla, wood and some hints of tropical fruits and hops, but its so cloyingly sweet its hard to notice much besides the alcoholic bourbon influence. Its nice if you like that kind of thing though. Definitely a different experience.

Tap at Stout in Hollywood. Lose is spicy and clean with some bourobn. Lots of bourbon in the flavour profile but eventually it melds well with a solid tripel base. Very smooth and lovely sipping. Quality.

750 ml bottle. Pours a very hazy, dark orange color and topped with a small off white head of foam. The aroma shows notes of bananas, nut, caramel, bourbon, honey, and some bready yeast. The flavor follows with the sweet bananas, honey, citrus fruit, and bready yeast blended nice with the oak and sour mash bourbon. There is a touch of nuts, and the vanilla from the oak really smooths things out. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation that leads to a sweet, warming finish. This is a really nice take on the style, which is normally pretty boring. Good beer.

On tap @ Capones. Rich golden color with a small but pillowy white head. Aroma is sweet, with lots of lemon, orange zest, a hint of spice, smooth oak, and booze. Flavor is very similar. A peppery sort of lemon like a typical tripel, but without the cloying sweetness a lot of them bring. The oak aging really adds a whole new dimension to this beer. The oak and bourbon meld wonderfully with the existing beer flavors. The finish is a touch boozy, but as a regular bourbon drinker, it hits all the right buttons. Awesome!

Pours a cloudy yellow. Very bubbly but the head doesnt stick around. Aroma is yeasty and fruity and woody. Taste is everything at once -- sweetness, tart fruit (orange maybe), and with a strong alcohol kick at the end. Very nice -- not as fruity as a "normal" trippel, maybe more yeasty/bready/malty. Maybe its just me but I cant taste the bourbon that much.

Everything I love in a beer in one bottle.  The bourbon character really gives this brew a push over the top.  And the alcohol content doesnt hurt either.  Just an altogether satisfying experience.   And so rich that you fell like youve eaten a meal.

Straw-blond, silky hopped head. Strong bourbon-woodsy nose--love it. Oaked notes with restrained vanillins as well. Excellent woody quality. The body is likewise woodsy with the presence of oak and subdued vanillins. Well-stated, artfully crated ale. The disparate parts meld together wonderfully and in just the right proportions.
Bottle. Light gold pour, thin white head. Aroma of bourbon, cereals, vodka-like alcohol. Taste is quite woody, lots of bourbon and not much else. Palate is ok. I was expecting much more from this.
On tap at Bilbo Baggins.  This is a very drinkable Allagash beer balancingthe alcohol, fruit flavors like sour cherries and raisens and a nice finish..  ZGolden color with a nice warm finish.

Pale golden pour light white head .... aroma of oak and bourbon along with sweet fruity belgian yeast .... taste of bourbon, spicy/peppery and fruity belgian yeast a nice mix of flavors and a solid tripel with a light oak and vanilla flavor .... dry bitter finish ........ well done and balanced brew

Consider this the great catch-up.  This rating from the previous time I was at Duckworths in Mooresville, a few weeks ago.  This was a well-done beer but Im still not sure Im into the barrel-aged tripel thing.  Lots of whisky present... would have preferred a more subtle integration.  Good to try but I wouldnt go pick this up.

Pours a hazy golden caramel color with a small head and very nice retention. Constant bubbles racing to the top.  Wonderful smell. Im getting your typical Belgian Tripel smell, but with a nice kick of liquor. The hit of liquor almost smells like vanilla. This is my first Barrel-Aged brew, so it really impresses me.
