Taste has a smooth Belgian start, that blends into a Bourbon finish. Not as dry a finish as Im accustomed to by this style, this is almost creamy.  Light body with a nice amount of carbonation that keeps the flavors fresh.  This is a beer that the drinkability is interesting. I would love to drink this all the time, but I dont see it as an everyday beer

Poured on tap into a footed allagash glass. Cloudy pale yellow-orange. Half inch of head that quickly dissipates. Light carbonation and minimal lacing. Interesting rich malt smell, similar to a lager. Also some orange citrus and a bit of coriander aroma. I can tease out some nice sweet oaky notes but not much else. Full bodied on the palate. Coats my mouth with a syrupy texture. Oaky vanilla, butterscotch, and orange peel. Not as heavy as the malty aroma suggests but still very big. Bitter, slightly hoppy gives it a cleaner impression overall, aiding drinkability. Only slightly less drinkable than other tripels. I usually dont care for barrel aged ales because the oak can be overwhelming but I thought this one had nice balance. Not my favorite but a nice twist on the style.

Wow.  What a beer!  In a bad way.  I had this one off tap.  The pour was slightly hazy.  The beer was bright yellow.  And, the aroma has a slight hopiness and spice to it.

And, then I tasted this beer.  At first it is clean.  And, then wam pow, wow!  Fresh oak and bourbon all over the place!  It is like a premixed boiler maker!  No thank you!  If I wanted overpowering bourbon, I would order it!

Kudos for experimenting.  But, this one is not for me!

hazy yellow color, no head, merest trace of lace.  nose is airy belgian yeast and jim beam barrels.  flavor is more promininently yeasty, fruity with bourbon barrel notes.  medium bodied, creamy mouth feel, dry finish.  interesting brew.  sampled at FoBAB 09.

Pours cloudy straw/yellow with an inch of white foam.  Tastes like a batch of 100% bret fermented beer that I had recently.  Smells like tart cherries and barn hay loft.  Sticking my nose in I get a whiff of alcohol.  Flavor is sweet hay, alcohol, tart funk, slight dough, slight hop bitterness.  Cool, but nothing like the Odyssey.
Cloudy yellow. Nice white head. Smelly like a pale lager aged in sherry barrels. Sweet and thick malty taste thats quite rich. Wooden finish and burn on the back of the throat.

A Mes rate. Bottle at Chris Os "Has anyone seen my stool?" tasting.Clean yellow gold with a thin white head. Full on bourbon and booze all round. Not something I would usually go for by any means but what little beery character there was poking through the booze and coconut was pretty decent. Light bitterness initially that is swiftly assassinated to death by a truck load of sweet warming alcohol. Sweet woody finish. As I was drinking this, a piece of ceiling maybe 9 foot by 6 foot fell down on the tasting. The noise was incredible and the entire room was filled with a thick dust cloud. As the dust settled, with no one daring to move yet, there appears Jan Fonefan like a Phoenix from the flames with one hand covering his glass and the other covering this bottle. Amazing composure. Not one glass nor one bottle was broken. There were a few cuts and bruises but generally it was a miracle that there were no serious injuries.
Very cloudy, yellow, good head.  Aroma of sweet, wood, and sourness.  Taste of dark spices with a recognizable taste of wood aging.  Finish has hints of citrus and tannins.

On draught @ Tap in Midtown.  Pale golden pour, almost opaque though.  Small white head.  Aroma was candi sugar sweetness, some earthy notes, yeast and a subtle hint of bourbon.  Nice clean flavors throughout.  Not as yeasty as I thought it would be.  Rich malt with a big bourbon presence in the finish, smooth as silk.  This is one of the most original triples I have tasted, very nice.

Cloudy orange-gold with a small foamy head.  This one has a mild, sweetish aroma, with fruit, yeast, orange, and icing sugar.  A little different for the style.  There is too much booze in the flavour, but the orange, banana bread, and barrel are all good.  Some hops at the end.  I suspect that the booze is cutting into the subtleties of this one.  Some age would help.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2011 Pours a cloudy light yellow and smells of whiskey, vanilla and flowers. Complex and inviting. Very soft carbonation carries the sweet malty backbone. Notes of cotton candy show, but are quickly overpowered by whiskey. A bit of pineapple and peaches in there as well. Leaves behind a heavy white lacing, alcohol burn, and fuzzy headed joy.

Hmm. Had this at the beer tasting in Boston this summer and I recall it being better than it is now. Pours with a large, foamy, frothy, cream colored head, that settles down to just a little cover quickly and no lace. Color is a slightly hazy amber with no bubble trails. Aroma is yeast, bread dough, and heavy caramel. Flavor is not as complex: mostly sweet, a little bubblegum, and some  tang from carbonic acid. Body is decent and carbonation is very good for this beer. Finish is like flavor with the tang lasting a while and some alcohol at the end.

corked and caged 750ml from November 2008.  pours a hazy golden color with a small thin white head. aroma: bourbon, bourbon and more bourbon.  sweet vanilla and caramel, some great fresh hop aroma.  taste: some sweet vanilla, brown sugar, and and roasted malt, then some bourbony booze that makes ya wanna scream,  great earthy oaky taste towards back of the tounge.nice smooth finish.
Another great beer from the folks in Portland. Very smooth. Far too easy to drink.

Lots of vanilla/smoke in the nose and across the palate. Looks like a tripel should. Not too much of an alcohol bite, but its there. Perfect amount of barrel aging. Not usually a fan of messing with a tripel but this one works.

Bottle. Delish! Pours a deep golden orange with a solid white cap. the bourbon barrels ae distinct in the nose, along with vanilla and port/wine. Rich and complex with fruits, wood, yeast and alcohol.. Well balanced and great tasting.
750 mL bottle.  Golden, slightly cloudy pour with a thin off white head.  Aroma of vanilla and slight hops.  Great smooth, creamy taste of yeast, faint citrus and vanilla with an even finish.
I dont really like triples cause of there driness.  Nose is all sorts of clove, yeast, and alcohol.  Mouth is tamed by the Jim beam.  Thats its saving grace.

November 2008 bottle.

Pours a clear golden amber with a huge stream of bubbles rushing to the top and feeding a bubbly beige head that recedes to a cap quickly and leaves little lacing.

The aroma has fruity esters, vanilla, apples and pears.  I do get a little vanilla and oak though the bourbon is subtle.  Also some earthy spiciness in the nose.

The taste has a smooth vanilla sweetness up front immediately following by some yeasty spiciness and sweet fruity esters.  The finish is the first trace of Bourbon which burns just slightly and also includes a dry oaky character.

The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy with the dryness lingering with some strong carbonation.

The aroma led me to believe there wasnt much bourbon in here but the taste brought the whiskey to the front.  An excellent use of barrels.

This brew is a fine example of what barrel ageing can do, it make a good brew even better. I poured a 750 bottle into a tulip glass and was greeted by a white head set on top of a honey brown colored brew. The aromas of the barrel make the statement right up front. It is fruity(grapes) and woody (oak) with a touch of spice and Belgian yeast to it.

I enjoyed the flavors as well the warmth of alcohol comes out first, but the flavors of fruit and candy sugar help keep it in check. I consider this a medium bodied brew with ample carbonation.

This brew has a kick, and drinking the bottle by yourself is questionable at best. So I say one glass a sitting is more than enough for me. I have revisited this beer on numerators occasions and was never disappointed.
Tremendous taste and a beer for appetizers or after a meal.  I would recommend this to anyone but particularly those looking for something a little different.
Bottle. Clear gold with a medium white head. Aroma of yeast, malt, a bit of fruit and caramel. Malt, apple, bit of booze and an oaky finish.

750ml bottle.  Pours a murky orange with minimal head that quickly dissipates.  Overwhelming aroma of bourbon.  Dry in the mouth with a subtle sweetness from the whiskey, but ultimately just a lot of booze.  Not a bad drink, but not worth the price tag.

Bottle at ChrisO "Im Trying to see the Stool" pre GBBF2010 tasting. The beer that brought the house down.  Thanks to Planky for bringing this one.  Barrel aged to within an inch of its life.  Just too much bourbon and coconut.

Draft at The Shack on 8/14. Pours an orangish gold with a white head that disappears instantly. Very sweet. Lots of sugar in the aroma. Flavor is vanilla, honey, and brown sugar. Very warm feel from the alcohol. Little bourbon at the end. Nicely balanced.
smell Wheat with oak barrel sent. Color is hazy, cant see through. Smooth ale taste. with whiskey accent at the end. Pallet diminished quickly does not linger.  However not my type of ale.

Had this on tap at the 3rd anniversary of Baileys Taproom in Portland, OR. Colour... cloudy gold with a thick head. Nose... hints of Bourbon but not much else. Palate... bitter up front with stone fruits and distinct hints of Jim Beam. Generally not as good as I remember (not sure why).

31st July 2010. ChrisOs Pre GBBF - Raise The Roof tasting. Hazy gold beer with a frothy white head. Light palate - rich malt - very oaky and with a nicely judged amount of whisky. Very nice. So good it brought the ceiling down. Really!

bottle thanks to TreborWhip, pours light gold with a medium off white head.  Aroma is strong oak and bourbon.  Flavor is rich pale malts, sweet bourbon, nice hop profile, very pleasant.  Barrel is not overpowering.

Bottle @ Chrisos pre-GBBF Raise the Roof Tasting 10 - the one that brought the roof down. A hazy, pale yellow beer with a fizzy white head that dissipated to leave a complete ring around the glass. Lemon and lime bright citrus notes with an earthy yeast, vanilla and the bourbon barrel coming through marginally. Creamy vanilla and citrus on the tongue, more from the oak and bourbon heat on the swallow. Good light hop and a welcome contrast from the barrel aging. A soft but quite spritzy mouthfeel, a light lingering warmth and an apparent but unobtrusive bitterness.

Had this on tap. Quite pleasant ruby, orange color. Hazy. Had a bit of a sour nose with some sweetness, sugar, lemon in the end. Didnt really notice the alcohol or the bourbon. Nice, easy to drink. Light. Nice summer beer.

Bottle, "bottled March,10", at chrisos pre-GBBF Raise the Roof Shindig 10. By the time I got to sample this, we were outside in the garden, our hair full of dust, giving thanks to our gods for our merciful deliverance. I was so pleased to be alive that this beer probably seemed more wonderful than it actually was. Hazy pale gold. Sweet aroma and sweet alcoholic taste. Sweet!

Bottle at Chris Os Raise the roof tasting. Ah yes, the beer I was about to have a sample of before Chris Os ceiling decided to cave in! Luckily this fine beer was saved heroically by Jan (of FONEFAN fame) after the (quite literally) dust settled we all repaired to the garden to start again. Pale gold pour with a white head. Malty, citrus nose. Some herbs in there too. The bourbon ageing shines through. Nice malt laden citrus flavours. Very nice alcohol burn. Bitter, malty finish. Good stuff.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2010 This Beer is what all beers should taste like.  I hate living in a state that does not offer this fine brew!  This Belgian Ale is flavored to perfection.  The color is a little light, but that means little as soon as you taste it.  This beer is in my top 5.  Highly recommend!

I had to rate this a 5 it is my favorite beer!

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2012 bottle at chris o pre GBBF ...golden yellow .. light lemon hop ... sharp lemon ... juicy ... light sweet ... really lemon... very nice 3.8
 bottle at home ... golden yellow ... thin white head ... soft zezty lemon ... ligh yeast nose ... sweet candi suger and yeast ... soft floral orange ... 3.8

Bottle 7/14/2010 poured a hazy dark yellow with white fizzy head.  Aroma of bananas, bourbon, and oak.  Complex flavoring of breaded malts, bananas, honey, vanilla, and light spices with a bourbon and oak finish.  Very nice bourbon barrel (Jim Beam) aged Belgian style ale.

Tap at the Sunset Grill in Allston outside of Boston. Less than fragrant aroma of oak and Belgian yeast. Too cold, I guess. Lemony oak, vanilla, honey, wine, citrus, butter flavors. Very boozy, with too much oak. Very nice, smooth, mouthfeel though. I was waiting a long time to try this revered beer, but was somewhat disappointed. Didnt seem to work all that well. Interesting, though.

2005 bottle. Pours a golden color with a white fizzy head. Nose is sweet, malty, vanilla, slight bourbon notes. Flavors are the same as the nose with some clove and banana flavors as well. The bourbon is not as strong as it is in a fresher beer and the alcohol is not as noticeable either. Not bad for a 5yr old tripel. I will have to re-rate it with a fresher bottle but still a good beer.

Appearance: Light Golden/Cloudy

Aroma: Almond, Cotton Candy, Candy Apple 

Taste: Hint of Bourbon, Creamy, Cinnamon, Melon

Palate: Smoooth, Full Bodied, Spritzer finish. 

Overall: Its like that curtain of glaze at Krispy Kreme that everyones fantasized about putting their mouth under - I could put my mouth under a waterfall of this beer and be in heaven. Its what beer is supposed to taste like.

750 ml bottle. 07.13.10
Pour was the color of watery black tea; a golden yellow with a hint of light brown. There was a small white head that quickly dissipated into itself and disappeared. Great amount of carbonation in this one. The nose was the usual tripel suspects; banana and clove mixed with bourbon (light hints), a little vanilla and oak as well. The taste is spectacular for a tripel. A wonderful banana and clove taste hits the tongue followed by the slight heat of alcohol, an almost burnt sugar taste, hints of bourbon, and vanilla as well as oak. I love that there is no bubble gum or peppery notes in this tripel. A complex beer that I will surely have to cellar every year. The mouthfeel is also extraordinary; a light and creamy body that benefits from the excellent carbonation. Wonderful.

06 Vintage, tap BT. Very cloudy strong yellow color with good lacing.  Tiny bit sweet at first in the aroma, some yeastiness, touch of booze and bourbon. Funky and cidery flavors, spicy and very tasty. Really like the faint bourbon.  Thinner palate with warming alcohol at the back.  Nice sipping brew.

Bottle - pours cloudy amber gold with a decent white head that lingers for a bit.  Aroma of oak, bourbon and vanilla. Nice complex flavor - bourbon is moderate, not overpowering at all, with some oak/vanilla in there too. Sweet, rich, yeasty finish with the alcohol well hidden - but it is there - trust me on that one.  Great brew.

All the kandi sugars of a tripel mixed with the oaky vanilla of whiskey casks. That sounds like an awkward mix, but the two blended together seamlessly, making for a beer that is dangerously drinkable. A stand out even among Allagashs fine repertoire.

Sampled at American Craft Beer Fest 2010. Pours golden with little head.  A light beer with a nice spicy yeast aroma, with notes of bread and citrusy hops.  The oak is there, but its not overpowering.  Thin texture, but still a good beer.

hazy yellow with a small head which makes a small white film over the beer. Obvious that this is quite sweet, loads of sugar in the aroma. Taste is sweet, with tiny hints of bourbon in the finish. Huge palate. Very good

Bottle from Warehouse Liquors in Spring Hill, FL. Pours a cloudy gold with a medium white head. Aroma is vanilla, caramel, and raw honey. Flavor is alot of honey and vanilla, some brown sugar and some wood. Medium mouthfeel, very drinkable. Overall this is a very good beer.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Smooth, light sweet, bitter, bourbon. Wonderful balance. Maybe a hint of butter in the aroma.

On tap at Sunset Grill. The bourbon barrel has changed this beer so much that it really doesnbt take like a tripel ... more like a dark Belgian ale. Pours golden blond with two finder head. Fairly spice with strong presence of the bourbon flavor infusion. Tripel taste is barely discernable underneath. Very nice.

Pours deep orange with white head, aroma is orange, lemon, bread, banana, pear, and some bourbon.  Taste up front is creamy, sweet from the banan and citrus components, balanced nicely by the bourbon and the slightly dry finish from the wood finish.  Excellent brew.

Bottle @ UDRM. The aroma has butter, grass, some malts and bourbon. Clear, golden coloured beer with a white head. The taste is sweet, some hint of wood and bourbon and butter. pleasant carbonation. Butter is unfortunate.

11% ABV Champagne bottle served in a tulip.  Pour was cloudy, tarnished gold with two fingers of sudsy foam on the top; there is also excellent lacing with this beer.  Nose is oak, light cellar, light smoke, dew, and just the smallest hint of bourbon.  Taste is oak and malt with light hints of butterscotch, caramel, and bourbon.  The brew is very light and crisp with a sweetness that lingers in the form of light apple into the finish; after this, it turns dry and the bourbon (lightly) and ABV become known.  This is a very good beer that I could enjoy time and again!

Draught. Boulder Strong Fest 2010. Yellow wit white head. Aroma of yeast, and a sweeter biscuit roll (weird, I know), banana, and big bourbon booze (mostly bourbon booze). Flavor is sweet bourbon, banana again, and wood dry in finish. Finishes big bourbon and odd hoppiness throughout.
Had this one @ Unofficial Dutch Ratebeer Meeting. Golden colored brew. Yeast and citrus dominating both flavor and aroma.

Bottle bought in 2006 in Philadelphia and aged until now. Pours almost orange, touch of gold. The fizzy head vanishes almost instantly. Nose of citrus & pineapple. First sip has subtle notes of bourbon, alcohol, malt, and a certain sweetness as it sits on my tongue. Viscous mouthfeel that coats, and a very smooth flavour. As the alcohol burn subsides it has a very clean, smooth finish. 11% hidden well. A total pleasure but left me wondering if the aging really helped this beer all that much. Would like to try a younger sample..

Bottle @ RB meeting by Joes. A clear golden colored beer, with a thick foamy white head. The aroma of fruits and malts with some spices. The taste is fruity, some citrus and orange. Malts with spices and a little alcohol. Some vanilla in the back. The aftertaste is bittersweet.

The label said bottled in September 2009 with 11%.  Just had it April 26, 2010.  Pale blonde with slight pink hue.  Cloudy but clean.  Medium to med high carbonation.  A light vanallia, creamy bourbon flavor, not too noticable, but blended well.  I like bourbon, so maybe I could not notice it aswell as others at this concentration.  There was a bit of cider in the flavor.  Long lasting white creamy head.  Crisp aromoas of vanallia, oak, and apples.  Hops are balanced almost not noticed.

Full of flavor.  Probably should have waited and longer before opening.

Thanks to DLucky for the opportunity to try this one! November 2007 batch poured into my Mad Elf Chalice.

A- Body is a very cloudy straw yellow color that pours with a 1 finger foamy white head. Head eventually fades to a thin collar but plenty of lacing is left behind in the glass. Cloudiness is thick and dynamic.

S-Nose is mild and balanced. Characters noted are a subtle floral hoppiness, a hint of sugary (perhaps bourbon) sweetness, oak woodiness, and alcohol astringency.

T- The presence of oak, floral hops, apples, and sugary sweetness mix up front with a subtle presence of spicy yeast and bourbon in the background. A hint of alcohol astringency and warmth comes through for the finish, which is rather clean and dry.

P- Low to medium carbonation and a smooth yeasty body with a hint of alcohol presence.

O- This is a wonderful, dry, classy beer. I am impressed that the oak and bourbon are such notable characteristics of this brew. It was a great opportunity to try this and the 11% seems more like 8%...which gets to be a little much for one person. Great brew that I would love to have again overall.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-18-2008 03:02:22

On tappe at la trappe. (I always wanted to say that). Pours a slightly hazed golden with a white heat. Aroma is weird bandaids on bananas barrel and booze. Flavor is band aid bananas on booze barrel. Strange brew not sure this works. Peanut butter and jelly it is not however you gotta respect peanut butter and pickles.

On tap.  Light golden color with a small white head.  Aroma is sweet with some citrusy hops, calm malt, and some vanilla and spices.  Flavor is light but complex.  Some fruity sweetness initially over the malts, more vanilla and spice from the barrels.  Finishes nicely - quite dry.  Really hides the 11% ABV.  Overall pretty good.  The aging is done nicely with the flavors from the bourbon coming through subtly without masking the taste of the beer.

Had from bottle - February 2010 bottling.  Orange/amber color with beautiful frothy head which dissipates to a nice ring around the edges.  Aromas of malts, sweetness, vanilla, and bourbon, with the slightest traces of alcohol.  Taste is complex mix of spices, fruit, bourbon, and yeast.  A very good blend of tastes that could easily overpower each other.  Track down this seasonal beer!

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2012 Bottle at Dutch RB meeting, thanks for sharing joes! Clear golden pour with a thin white head. Aroma of spices, alcohol, leather and malts. Flavor is sweet, spicy, slightly bitter, creamy vanilla and nicely full bodied. - 7/3/8/3/15 Re-rate 01-05-2012. Bottle. Clear golden pour. Aroma of alcohol, spicy, oak, woody. Flavor is bitter spicy, leathery, mild aged, very well balanced. Quite unique and interesting - 7,3,8,4,15

Tap, City Beer Store.  Beer pours a hazy but bright golden color with a nice white head that sticks around well.  The aroma is milder than expected.  There are some light stone fruit and caramel malt notes.  The oak note is one of the best parts but a bit too refined not to get pushed out of the way more than Id liked.  It also seems somewhat vinous, though its a bit hard to tell under the bourbon.  The bourbon is fairly harsh and theres too much alcohol heat.  The booze really hits in the flavor.  I think that I might like the base beer and I might like an aged bottle/keg, but this is too harsh for me fresh.
one of the best i ever taste and feel. not too much oak. Perfect, thats all.

Bottle - Had this at a tasting and didnt get the year. Pours hazy yellow with a small pillowy head. Sweet grapes and light sweet fruit commingle with light spice, yeast and oak. What a beautiful smell--it took me forever to sip it because I wanted to smell it all night. Taste is light and spicy, with some wheat and a bit of heat on the finish. Nicely carbonated with a medium bodied. I think the barrel-aging mutes the spicing that I usually dont like in a tripel, but this was very, very good. Sad that we dont get Allagash in WI anymore.

Jan 2010 Bottle.  Slight Sweet & Sour aroma.  Golden body with thin, lasting head.  I am not a big fan of aging in bourbon barrels, but this beer was well done!  The flavor of the tripel is still intact as the bourbon flavor is light and helps to provide a slight sour finish.  Overall a great beer that I will have again and will have to try aged!

Oh ale aged in bourbon barrels, how doth I love thee


Brilliant oranges and ambers shimmer under a soft haze of pithy foam. A steady stream of carbonation lazes its way up to the surface where they release a spiced wooden bourbon assault unto my nose; Im not complaining. Spice, wood, and bourbon warms from my tippy-toe to the tippy-top of my head. Boozy mango and oranges with skin soak in every last ounce of bourbon while marmalade, cinnamon sticks, and nutmeg compliment a dry woody nose. Whole coconuts sweet and earthy at the same time round the corner into raw honeycomb. Delightfully dry, spiced, and wholly bourbon, I lick wet lips and dive right on in. A thick mouthfeel sticks to the roof of my mouth and all porous surfaces, opening the way for bourbon to soak me to the bone. Amazingly she manages to be sweet, dry with wood and spice, and warm with bourbon all at the same time. Warmth immediately fills the back of my throat while mangos, oranges, and fresh chunks of coconut steep in a bourbon bath. Raw cinnamon sticks and nutmeg are scattered throughout while raw honeycomb sticks to my lips with each quaff; most detectable as a subtle undercurrent, she carries me through each quaff right back to the beginning and back again. Not overly complex but very tasty, the Allagash Curieux was a warm bourbon delight from start to finish. Its amazing how the time spent in the Jim Beam barrels changed the original character of their Tripel.


Why choose between one or the other when you can have both. A limited seasonal release, grab a bottle or two of Curieux while you can, and if you really wanted to have some fun, do a side-by-side comparison of the Allagash Tripel and the Allagash Curieux.

This is one of the few beers that Ive had in recent years that has really knocked my socks off.  The bourbon-oak-vanilla flavor marries perfectly with the sweetness of the triple.  Why dont more brewers do this?!  

An astonishingly tasty beer drinking experience, and a must-try beer for all Belgian ale fans.

16oz wide mouth glass, the aroma is very woody, you can smell the high percentage of alcohol, nice solid layer of foam bout 1/4 inch, Vanilla taste that stands out, amber, clear, frothy, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, slick feel, lively,  one thing for sure is that the alcohol  at 11% hides very well and it hits you good!       cheers!,

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours a cloudy gold with a frothy lacy white head.  The nose is a nice combination of bright spices and subtle bourbon notes.  Some of that bourbon is lost in the flavor and I would definitely like to see more of it.  A little sweet, pretty floral.  Has a slight crispness and a good easy drinking quality.

tulip at toronado in north park.. not gonna lie, was a little lite when I had this but it still stood out as a cut above the rest...Bright yellow color announcing itself and  the smell had overtones of bourbon and I LOVE all ales brewed in that style.. sweet overtone and couldnt even sense the ETOH.. I could taste a great array of sweet dried fruits, some vanilla and of course and punch of jim beam bourbon on the palate at the end..  Cant believe this beauty has 11% ABV, it hides it well..  This little thing is a lady in public but a role playing, toy slinging naughty girl in private... Great tripel

Bottle courtesy Nate, March 10 Tasting.  Pours golden with fizzy white head.  Brown sugar, whisky, vanilla and oak.  Vanilla and mild hoppy flavor, brown sugar, dry and oaky.  Cream soda-like, or a bourbon and water.  Just a touch too harsh at the end.
Draft at teresas. Pours a bright yellow body with slight haze. Aroma is delicious tart and some citrus fruit. Taste is a bit dryer than expected.. but extremely drinkable and delicious.
Bottle. Pours golden with a big white head. Flavor is sweet with fruit and vanilla notes. Finishes with a big Jim Beam flavor. Really nice Tripel.

Sweet abbey tripel aroma with notes of vanilla and pear, almost like a saison. It pours golden blonde with a huge foamy head. The sweet, smooth, delicious tripel flavor is followed by a bite from the Jim Bean barrels. But this bite finishes on the palate nicely.

From 2007 vintage bottle. Oak, honey, vanilla, sweet and velvety; bourbon. Great nose. Some raisins, too. Hazy amber clear with thin white lacing head. Medium-heavy body with medium carbonation and alcoholic warming. Sweet start to finish, weak bourbon and ginger ale taste. Dry finish with light chalky bitterness. Nice flavor that has mellowed a bit, warming at the end.

Allagash
Curieux
Pours pale gold with a thin white head and excellent retention. Some lacing on the glass. Aroma of Belgian yeast, cloves and alcohol. Smell is somewhat reminiscent of a good hefe, but with more booze. Flavor is cloves, alcohol, bananas and a slightly sour metallic finish. Pretty damn good. Like a bigger, better hefe.

Sort of a cloudy golden color in the glass.  Oak and bourbon aromas with a little bit of vanilla sweetness.  On the palate there are more bourbon flavors and a nice level of complexity overall.  Really unique and enjoyable.  I feel like some oaked beers easily go overboard with the oak, but that wasnt the case here at all.

On tap at Blind Lady Ale House (San Diego, CA): Pours out a hazy darker shade of yellow, with a white pillowy, resilient head. Nose is of pale malts, crisp grains, hay, desiccated fruit, and Trappist yeast. Flavor notes of whiskey and vanilla softness. Aromatic hops produce a spiciness from the barrel aging. Drinkability: Soft and slowly warming at first, then transcends into a full and bluntly spice sensation. Pairing: Lobster or creme brulee. Rebuy: Yes. #301 on 26022010, DG.

Room temperature from caged/corked bottle into tulip.  Poured a nice golden color with strong off-white head.  Rich aroma of alcohol with spice & vanilla undertones.  Bourbon is very apparent.  You can taste hints of the triple through the bourbon flavor with a light bitter ending.  Very lively in the mouth with a nice brandy-like warmth.
Christmas gift from Brandon. Poured a hazy golden color with nice white head. Aroma was oak and spices. Taste was better than aroma with oak and some mild bourbon flavors. Pretty good.

Poured a hazy golden color with a thick creamy white head. Aromas of lemon, spices and yeast. Im picking up on the barrel aging but it doesnt taste at all like bourbon to me. Flavor is like a really spicy tripel with low sweetness. Palate was too carbonated, almost tingly on the tongue.

corked and caged bottled January 2009. cork opened with a nice solid pop and it poured a golden in color with a one finger white head and steady visible carbonation. aroma has allagash house yeast, grains, light lemon, vanilla touches, and a bit of muted wood. mouth feel is light and it initially has some prickly carbonation. flavor is plenty yeasty, grains, light lemon, faint honey, custard, and light spice. everything here is well integrated and all the flavors work well together but the wood from the barrel is muted and as far as bourbon goes, I was looking but there is not much more than a hint of rye. very smooth and quite enjoyed.
glowing orange color, aroma of hops, wood, and spices. Flavor is a fizzy, spritey, light hop citrusy flavor. bottle from Knightly Spirits, Orlando.

750 mL bottle, Bottled May 2009, 11% ABV.  Bottle pours hazy orange, eggshell colored bubbly head that lingers, good lacing.  Aroma dominated by coconut, with vanilla, bread, honey and lemon.  Taste is nice and sweet, with just a hint of earthy funk, then a mild balanced bitter finish.    Good carb, medium body and a slight oily mouthfeel.  Overall, very complex beer and quite drinkable for the ABV.  Im not sure what the base beer is, but you can tell it was a great base.  The bourbon is far from overwhelming and I believe brings some great character to the beer (namely the coconut aroma and toasted oak mouthfeel)

pours rich amber with large white head. aroma is tons of apple, oak, bourbon, candied sugars, alcohol. drinks with lots of tart apples, sweet sugars, yeast, bourbon, light malt. lovely beer to put age on. have had different years, but find them all a bit hot fresh, and best if aged 2-3 years...if you can wait that long
draft at uber tavern. Nicely spiced in addition to hops and yeasts with a lot of pepper as well.
The bourbon finish is very subtle and pleasing.  Spicy belgian character is nicely balanced by the bourbon.  Im starting to think Bourbon barrels improve all beers.

Tap at Najas.  I thought this was Fluxus, but liked the beer nonetheless.  Nose was big with grain alcohol, dessicated fruit, sweet Trappist yeast.  Pleasant golden.  Flavor is slightly hot but very clearly a Belgian ale.  Nice aromatic hops make their way through in the flavor and their spiciness works well with the prickly barrel aging.  Slight sensation of a sour, but rounds out full and bluntly spicy.  Solid.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2011 Sampled at Barrios Sausage Fest 2010!  Tasty, but overpriced as always.  Lightly tart, but lemon, candi sugar, and vanilla yogurt.  Very enjoyable.  but dont really pick up the bourbon until the aftertaste.

Tasted a later vintage on draft at Chips - MUCH more bourbon character than I remembered.  Bready, and decent alcohol warming.
UPDATED: JUN 18, 2011 Pours a lacing off-white head with a deep golden body.  Aromas of grain, vanilla, yeast.  Flavors of yeasty bread, grass, some earth, vanilla.  Finish is zesty and a little dry.

Compliments of doboy at his last little soiree (Thanks Ed!), Aroma of banana, vanilla, yeast and a well balanced bourbon tones. Even the flavour was nice, vanilla, more banana, some faint spices ... almost like a sugar cookie. As it warmed, the bourbon started to muscle to the fore and take over. By the end of the glass, it still tasted like a sugar cookie, as if it had been dunked in Jim Beam!  Im not a fan of abbey tripels, but this one was exceptional.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Hazy pale golden, small white head of mixed bubbles. Creamy smooth mouthfeel w/ a big cushion of fine carbonation. Flavor is banana, sweet but not sticky. I cant really pick out what the barrel adds but this is definitely a beer that comes across mature and sophisticated. The mouthfeel especially is well developed and reminds me somewhat of the very best Unibroue has offerred over the years. The only flaw I pick up is a slight metallic twinge in the nose. Nothing is perfect but this is very good.

On tap at Dilly Deli in Cincinnati. Pours a cloudy golden orange with a rocky white head. Aroma is nicely sweet, a blend of sweet  bread, fruitness and some vanilla. Just a bit of spiciness is apparent along with some yeast. Flavor starts sweet and fruity before gaining a bit of barnyard. Gets just lightly tart along with a more pronounced citric character leading to a crisp but smooth finish and an awesome lingering bourbon almond taste. Medium rich body and a soft carbonation. Really tasty beer, love the finish.

golden color and flavor.  by that i mean belgian golden ale of course, but with a lot of bourbony-alchl character and even a hint of wood.  its easy to drink too much of this as it goes down easy for its high alchl.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2009 Pours golden brown with a light head.  It has a sweet smell that I didnt notice at first.  Tastes like keg beer to me.  I cant taste bourbon.  The taste was very nice once it warmed up a little.  This beer shouldnt be drunk ice cold.  It is strong so two glasses later what it taste like wont matter.  I would happily drink this again if offered.

Saved this bottle to share with DrBayern, Celticbrew, Brian the Beer Pimp, Uncle Tom and the Newbies, Lawyer Bob and The Boy Wonder Chris.
Has a sweet Aroma.  Pours a yellowish color, and was somewhat cloudy.  The flavor of the bourbon was light but nice.  You can taste the oak in this beer.

Bottle. Pours gold with a white head. Bourbony aroma, with yeast and apple skins. The flavor has a nice deep sweet bourbon presence, as well as notes of wood, yeast, and spices. Pretty unique and quite enjoyable.

From bottle. Very clear orange/golden colour with a thin white lace which clings to the glass. Medium carbonation. Crisp fruity aroma, citrus and oranges. Hints of malt and caramel. Flavour is sharp and acidic. A little sour yet has a smooth malt whisky finish. The beer settles to a rather pleasant supping ale. The bourbon seeps its way through to the forefront.

750->tulip: Purchased directly @ the brewery in Portland, ME.  Pours a huge, white, frothy head that exhibits excellent lacing atop a hazy, orange body.  Aroma of butterscotch and a bite of something that I cant discern.  Heavily alcoholic mouthfeel, medium body, a good bit sweet and a short flavor duration.  A very nice beer indeed.

A: It pours a wonderful reddish yellow color with brown highlights. There is a steady stream of bubbles to keep a half finger head present. Leaves behind a nice pattern of lace.

S: Oh yes, I held this one back for a special occasion and I have the feeling it is going to be worth the wait. The marriage of America and Belgium. Bourbon and Beer. Smoke, Vanilla, and Malty Fruity Sweetness. Oh my!

T: This is what I have been waiting for. WOW! This is one fine triple. If that is all we had I would be raving about it, then BAM, Smoke Oak, and Vanilla...Tennessee Bourbon Baby. Oh yeah this one is barrel aged and let me tell you the ageing did wonders. The bourbon taste makes this beer almost too complex to process. There is a perfect match of beer and liquor. It is absolutely AMAZING with the ribs cooked we over charcoal and hickory!

M: Drinks like a Triple kicks like a bourbon on the rocks. A perfect sipping beer.

Has a nice woody, vanilla aroma with slight floral notes.  This beer, being a tripel, stands up nice to the aging in oak barrels.  IT definitely takes on a nice woody character in the taste, with the whiskey notes coming through but it is not overbearing.  I am not huge on tripels as a rule but this one with the added dimension of the bourbon barrel aging is quite nice.  Moderate carbonation, nice mouthfeel.  Especially good with a nice cheese (bergeron fr. quebec).  Overall a good experience, nothing over the top but very good.
Smells of bourbon, has a small head and a light body.  Lots of tart apple cider and champagne notes.

On tap at Brouwers Big Wood 09.  Orange pour with a moderate white head.  Aroma is very much like a granny smith tart apple cider with a touch of something reminiscent of champagne.  The flavor is not as sweet as I would have expected from the aroma.  The apple sweetness still exists, but I get much more spicy yeast, bourbon, honey, and a very dry, woody finish.  Quite tasty, but I felt putting this in a bourbon barrel overwhelms the flavors of this tripel a bit too much for my taste.  Still, this has a nice complexity regardless of that.

Cloudy orange-yellow, lingering white head, good lacing.
Aroma is of apples, some sweetness, light yeast.
Flavour is very candish, quite malty, high sweetness, fairly smooth.
Finished long, light alcohol, sweet. 
Very candish but pretty good. 
750ml bottle.
Opened March 2009.
Bottled in September 2007.

This is another tripel that has gone become very vinous... this is the newer 2009 bigger abv version. Golden with white foam and chardonnay aromas. subtle wood, nothing citric, the body is light medium and its still very delicious but definitely not the deeper,more floral beer of past vintages.
Very good beer.  Great texture, clean finish.  Hints of sweetness with a nice bitter finish.   Would definitely drink again.

750ml bottle that was bottled in Feb. 2009.  Poured a cloudy orange with a thick tight white head . Aroma was wood, yeast, biscuit bready and earthy.  Some slight bourbon hints on the nose that really came through in the flavor.  Very smooth beer with a lot of complex flavors.  Very nice.

750 ml cork and caged bottle shared by EDA right out of his cellar, the sickest cellar I have ever seen might I add. Poured a slightly hazed nectar golden body sitting underneat a smaller foamy white head. Aroma starts off with lots of fruit (white grapes, pears, greeen apples), old fermenting honey, wood and slight alcohol. Flavors of oak, honey flavored wax, grains, vinous chardonnay notes which is odd because this was aged in Jim Beam barrels and not wine barrels. Medium body with lively carbonation for a barrel aged beer and noticeable alcohol heat but not too much for an 11%er. The aroma is the strong part of this beer and unfortunately the flavor drops off slightly.

Pours a muddy yellow with a nice white head that stays around and laces nicely. Aroma is earthy yeast bread like with a hint of whiskey and wood. Flavor is sweet on the front with some spices. Back end is whiskey and some of the wood. Finish is delightfully warm and dry on the throat begging for another sip.

A deeply complex ale here. On tap at Blind Tiger. Pours a nice, hazy yellow with a thin white head. Aroma of yeast, alcohol, some spices and fruits. Flavor has a diverse character, with notes of vanilla, bourbon and some coconut. Nice, warm mouthfeel. A good bit of sweetness on the finish.

On Tap at Ashleys in Ann Arbor. Pours a yellow cloudy color and a small white head. The aroma is yeast and mild fruit ctirus notes.  The flavor is excellent, there is a good palate and robustness of this drink.  Highly enjoyable.

Unclear pilsener golden with a small, off-white head. Rather neutral aroma - mainly of alcohol. Full and markedly alcoholic body with the bourbon flavours slowly but splendidly unfolding warming your palate. This is almost zen! The finish is pure bourbon.

Draft at 3 Penny Taproom - Poured a pretty golden yellow in color with a small white head that faded to thin covering over the beer.  Aroma is very fruity with bready yeast.  Flavor is thick with bready yeasts, fruits (green apple), light citrus, slight alcohol and floral hops.  The bourbon/vanilla from the aging process is just the barest hint in the flavor profile.  One of the best Tripels Ive had... excellent!

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2009 09 bottle thanks to KGAGNE (BA)!Hazy yellow-gold, thin white head. Sweet nose of bourbon, wood, and lemon. More bourbon in the flavor, also light pepper, banana, and lemon. A little thin and hot. Not bad, but I think the bourbon kills off most of the tripel and what remains is an odd collection of sweet barrel with light, grassy citrus.

Wow, this is a huge beer!  This one will knock your pants off if youre not careful.  I drank it on an almost empty stomach, and felt its effects just about right away.  This tripel pours a cloudy light amber color with a minimal head.  But the head lurks with some stickiness around the edges of the glass.  The nose is full of fruits, light bread notes, yeast, alcohol and bourbon.  The body is generally smooth, but the flavors beg you to carefullly sip.  The flavors are very strong and upfront.  I tasted notes of orange peel, bread, yeast, alcohol, light floral hops and grass.  The flavor I enjoyed the most, though, was the bourbon toward the back end and in the finish of the beer.  The bourbon mixed in really well with the other flavors, even bringing out some of the fruit notes.  One of the fruit notes that was really brought out was the oranges.  The flavors reminded me of enjoying Grand Mariner, but with a carbonated feel.  I really enjoyed this beer, even if it kicked my butt a little.

Pours a hazy copperish golden yellow color with a 2 finger creamy white head that has good retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap that leaves sporadic spots of soapy lacing.

Earthy oak/wood aroma with crisp light fruit and citrus notes. The bourbon presence is there but doesnt dominate and is actually quite subtle.

Smooth medium body which was very surprising considering the high ABV. Very flavorful and not too hot. Alcohol is excellently masked making it very drinkable.

Sour earthy oak wood flavor with some sweet crisp light estery fruit notes, mostly apple and pear, slight citrus peel notes and again a nice bourbon presence. The bourbon flavor is well integrated and doesnt overpower the other flavors. Very well balanced with some more bourbon flavor coming through in the oaky dry finish.

750ml bottle Bottle 5/07 11% ABV 11/3/09 (Binnys Naperville)-Pours a hazy yellowish golden with a small white head. Aroma of bourbon, belgian yeast, brett, and slight vanilla. Taste of bourbon, vanilla, yeast, and alcohol. This full bodied brew is very well balanced and quite tasty. Well done.
bottle, golden color with sweet fruit and wood aromas, flavors has some buttery oak, banana, apple, spices, lasting finish

Tap at Toronado SD ($7).  Pours an apricot-like brownish yellow with thin layer of off-white head.  Aroma of floral bouquet, lemon, pear, wood, and sweet malts.  Flavor is sweet but smooth.  A malty sweetness merges into an earthy woodiness.  Spice and a light bourbon flavor emerge as well.  Interesting finish that is sweet, slightly bitter, and quite woody.  Very quaffable for an eleven percenter!

Bottle. 25.4 oz. (2009) Pours hay colored, murky golden with a medium, pungent, white head. Incredibly unique aroma: strong vanilla, wheat, breadd, hops, and, oddly, warm butter. Medium body for such a high ABV, which it hides very well. Nice lacing throughout. Extremely long, crisp finish. Excellent tripel.

sample draft at Waywood Beverage!!  pours an opaque honey color with a very thin white head...retention could be better.  outstanding aroma of blood orange and herbs with a hint of vanilla slight breadiness.  flavor has light vanilla and bourbon with some mildly spicy hops up front and the end is dominated by oak notes.  mouthfeel is creamy at first but gets a bit watery in the finish.  still has an oaky, dry lingering finish.  very nice beer...i defintiely had seconds!

Bouteille de 750 ml. Arômes de bourbon et de chêne, la levure fruitée transparaît également. Robe blonde cuivrée, effervescence active et belle mousse. Très légèrement mieilleuse, la bière possède une très belle texture, soutenue par la belle effervescence. On retrouve des notes de bourbon et de chêne, ainsi quune belle touche de levure fruitée. Finale légèrement sucrée et astringente. Lalcool est présent, mais agréable.
Bottle. Cloudy yellow pour with a small whitehead. Aroma is clove, coriander, orange. Flavor is white pepper, herbal, spicy yeast, citrus, slight bourbon. This beer was decently hot.

On tap at the Gingerman in Ft. Woth.  Clear, look golden in color, nice lacing white colored head.  The smell is very heavy wood, fruits, pepper, spices, bourbon, and alcohol.  The taste is very heavy alcohol, wood, sweet, fruits.

Very Woody, boozy, oaky, vanilla aroma with notes of coconut and fruits, not very yeasty... Flavor follows suit with the bourbon notes coming through... Surprisingly not overly full bodied, especially in the finish, very nice on the palate, very very very complex, a definite winner... Amazing beer...

Clear orange pour. Little head. Smells of sweet fruit and light citrus. Slight bit of grape feeling after the aroma warms a bit. Tastes like a tripel with a bit of harsh taste. Feeling of burning on the way down. Sweet upfront that quickly turns to rough hell.
On tap at the Gingerman Fort Worth.  Light yellow pour.  Aroma is spicy with lots of clove.  Lots of alcohol in the taste.  Banana and pepper too.  Harsh spice aftertaste.

Medium golden body with a big collapsing white head and thick strands of lacing.  Aroma is yeasty with a good earthy quality backed by hints of lemon, flowers and wood.  Smoothly blended, rich and filling with a faint trace of alcohol.  Starts sweet and finishes with a hearty kiss of whiskey.  Fermented fruits with a citrus backdrop followed by light bread and a mild nuttiness.  Plenty of Belgian yeast flavors to keep this in check.  Wonderful drink, and it was in great form.

bready, yeasty, slightly fruity aroma, seems like there is some honey sweetness in there as well. Flavor is bold, jumps on the  tongue, there is a sweetness initially, but a tartness and sour apple thing get going mid taste. This is a very unique beer, strange, but very enjoyable.

08 Bottle @ Isaac Newtons. Golden pour with very small white head. Slight sweet, oak , almost wine aroma. Flavor is alcohol heavy, bourbon, oak, and sweet. Would like to see this mellow with some time.

Draft at coopers. Poured a golden colore with a nice big off white head. Aroma is of sweet belgian sugar and some oak. Taste is hige on the alcohol with mild oak and sweetness through out. Not bad but needed more time.

750 mL into a pint glass.  The aroma is mainly on the abbey side - lots of sweet esters with just a hint of wood and alcohol.  The flavor is a good combo - sweet malt, candy sugars, esters, phenolics, and vanilla and wood.  A bit of alcohol burn and pretty high carbonation round it out.

On tap at Gingerman.  Pours a cloudy, light orange with a white head.  Nose is of orange, wood and alcohol.  Taste is of drinking a fruit parfait or orange dreamsickle with wood.  Mouthfeel is sweet and dry with alcohol and some carbonation.

On tap at the Peekskill Brewery.  Pours a hazy yellow gold with a medium white head.  Almost sour barrel notes, light bourbon, apple, pear. Fresh and complex.  Lemony, smooth, light bourbon, wheat.  Finishes dry with some light lingering whiskey notes, and a touch of banana yeast. Really tasty.

A: Poured out of a 22 oz bottle into two tulips. Good-sized, white head that stayed around for most of the drinking (which took quite a while). Very decent lacing on the sides of the glass. The beer was quite cloudy, and a nice, orange-yellow color. Sediment was left in the bottom of the bottle.

S: Wow, theres a lot going on here. Quite a good amount of yeast, and definitely some orange in there too. The alcohol comes through, but not too strongly, and the oak is quite present as well.

T: Just as much going on as in the aroma. Starts off tasting orange and slightly bready, from the yeast, followed by the warmth of the alcohol in the back of the throat (not overpowering, but its definitely there). After a few sips, the bourbon-flavor starts to come through. Finishes ever-so-slightly dry, and the flavor lingers for quite a while.

M: Medium-bodied, and very creamy... feels extremely nice on the palate. Average carbonation balances it off perfectly.

D: This is an awesome beer to sip over a long period of time... the high alcohol content keeps it from being chugged. Definitely to be savoured with someone else who is likely to appreciate it.

Bottle. Moderate malt aromas all around withgrain for the malt, lemongrass for the hops, mold of the yeast, with notes of pineapple, cask wood, corriander, vanilla and a faint hint of bourbon. Head is average size, white, with good lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is murky amber. Flavor starts moderately sweet and acidic, and finishes lightly sweet and moderately acidic and bitter. Palate is medium, oily with a lively carbonation and finishes lightly astringent and dry. An Abbey Tripel with some good weight to it, yet still manages to be refreshing, with great balance to boot.

A contemplative elixir masquerading as a strong brew.  Oaky and earthy and promising more burn than what it actually delivers.  Smooth, like a good whisky-- but wait, its a beer!   Initial opening of the cork strongly reminds one of honey, first and foremost, and then other things....many things.  Whatever you want it to be.   Better than a good wine.

If youve ever wondered where bourbon gets its flavor, heres the answer. This beer, aged in bourbon barrels smells perfectly whisky-ish. Theres a touch of bread in the nose, maybe a hint of orange-flower, but basically, this is the soul of bourbon turned into a beer. 
Best for contemplative, after-dinner drinking.

07 Vintage, pours cloudy amber gold, nice puffy head that wains after a short while. Wonderful complex flavor, bourbon is faint, not overpowering at all, with some oak/vanilla in there too.. Yeasty, slightly sweet, rich, nice long finish. Alcohol well hidden, but I felt it right off. Wonderful smell, mild oak and bourbon with some bakery shop aromas. Wonderful balance, I really like this one.

Sample from 22 oz. bottle.  Pours gold, just a tad hazy, with a small white head.  Aroma of citrus, bourbon, fruit, sugar, and a touch of soap.  Flavor is even better, with bourbon, citrus, butter, booze, and a pinch of vanilla.  Warming alcohol and a slightly sticky mouthfeel.  Still doesnt seem like 11% ABV.  Light to medium body.  Dry, fruity finish.
Ill have to try this one again, but currently ranks as the best beer Ive ever had. Well see if it holds up after more tastings.

Bottle on the patio at Rupununi in Bar Harbor, ME.  Pours cloudy gold with fluffy off-white head. Tons of fruit aroma with some spice. Flavor was banana and apple. Full bodied if not a bit syrupy. Finished dry. I didnt get much from the barrel aging, for better or worse. For me, it was just a great beer as it was. Really enjoyed it.

This was good, and a pleasant twist since typically bourbon barrels are not applied to this style.  I think tripels can often be good, but are also often quite similar.  The barrel effect imparts pleasantly unusual flavors and shows that we can go beyond bourbon porters.
Pleasant crisp yeasty buttery notes in the aroma. Hazy yellow color with a thin white head. Flavor is spicy Belgian yeast. Smooth.
Julios Belgian Beer Festival. Sample. Sweet, strong and citrusy. A good tripel though too strong for my tastes both in alcohol flavor and effect.

On tap at flying saucer. Pours a cloudy orange golden with a medium frothty white head. The aroma is citrus and yeast. Medium mouthfeel with a sweet sugary yeast taste with a nice dry finish. A good tripel from allagash.

February 2007 22 oz corked bomber bottle. Pours cloudy peach-orange with a fizzy white head that dissipates to thin splotch. Tangy citrus and tart pear aroma with good banana notes as it warms as well as some woody, vanilla notes from the barrel aging. Tart and sour with prominent alcohol notes balanced somewhat by softer bourbon notes on the finish.  Medium bodied, highly carbonated - very prickly. Not bad, but I find that the belgian tartness conflicts with the bourbon a bit.

(750ml bottle thanks to ballewblake, bottled June 08) Pours a dark yellow with good head and coats the glass nicely. Nose is oak, sour cherry, alcohol. Taste is oaky, slight bourbon on the finish, nice carbonation, and well balanced hops. Spicy/biscuit yeast profile and loving how it finishes. The regular tripel from these guys is better in my opinion though.

Bottle pours semi-cloudy amber color with white head.  Aroma is yeast, butter, vanilla, and alcohol.  Has a buttery, creamy mouthfeel.  Flavaor is yeast, butter, alcohol, some vanilla, and finishes semi-dry.  This is a good beer.  Just not great due to the diacetyl.  Bottled March 2009.

Notes from Seattle International Beer Festival. Smells like bananas. Tastes like bananas. Unfortunately I drink enough Belgians to know be much more specific than that. Tastes yeasty, but thankfully no metal. Poured cloudy orange.

Picked up this rather expensive brew from Greens on Ponce De Leon. 25.4 oz. bottle. Haze brown/yellow/orange color. Nice fluffy head that sticks around; damn good looking tripel if you ask me. Fruity/sweet aroma. Not extremely pungent. I am gonna let this warm up a wee bit...Fruit and yeast become more and more noticeable as the beer warms up. Not so much on the wood I must . Slight banana aroma as well. Man that wood flavor is immediately noticeable. Very nice subtle wood at first then some yeast/banana/fruit flavor. As the beer warms the wood is still very slight in terms of aroma, but aroma is still nice overall. This beer is awesome. Really love the wood mixed with the fruit. Very smooth. Just an amazing tripel if you ask me. One of my favorites, if not my favorite. I believe this is due to the wood aging. Nice ABV too!

courtesy of Allen - clear golden-blond colour with an elusive white foam; very estery and fruity aroma with notes of alcohol and wood; full-bodied and quite sweet, residual sugars in a long fruity and spicy finish with robust warming alcohol notes - very good beer

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2009 Shared with oobawa (of BA fame) tonight.  Nothing particularly wrong with this one, just not worthy of the 15.99 price tag.  Not much bourbon on the nose.  Beautiful pour, would be a 5 if there was a little more lacing.  Flavor is pretty solid, but its hard to notice the bourbon till it starts to warm up.  Very subtle and extremely drinkable for the ABV.  Should I up the palate to a 5?  Possibly... but no.  Wouldnt mind drinking this again but I wont be buying.
Poured golden yellow, CO2, apricot, citrus, citrus rine, yeasty, little bannana, little alcohol.

Reviewed (Draft at Brouwers, Seattle, TX):

Pours a somewhat cloudy body, very pale yellow. Fluffy white head creamy and lasting. Sweet sour aroma, light. Sour taste, pretty sweet. Not rotten, or acidic-ly sour. Relatively smooth. Refreshing. Fruity tasting. A little dry on the aftertaste. Tasty.

Cloudy chestnut brown color, medium creamy khaki head. Light-medium malty aroma. Very smooth, creamy texture. Alcoholic but not overdone. A little heat, bourbon. Medium sweetness. Not your usual tripel, but well made, tasty. Followed up with some chocolate nutty cheesecake..
poured cloudy golden with a head that faded quicly to give good lacing.  smelled like bourbon barrell and tasted about the same with a little fruit flavor mixed in as well.

On tap at Hollingsheads.. Pours a cloudy golden with a thin white head..Aroma was belgian yeast and maybe some grapes. Didnt pick up any bourbon in the nose, maybe it was too cold coming off of the tap.. Tasted like your typical tripel (yeah that rhymes).. Good beer but I wouldnt pay the $10.95 for a 12oz pour again.

Tap. Poured a cloudy gold with a white head. The aroma consisted of the alcohol notes from the Jim Bean which mixed quite nicely with the undertone of fruit and citrus notes. The flavor was sweet and the alcohol was present but by no means over powering.

From the 750 ml. bottle bottled March 2009 from one of 630 cases bottled.  The pour is a fairly cloudy golden-yellow with a quickl rising, bubbly head that diminishes almost as quickly as it starts.  Lacing clings throughout the glass.  The aroma has a hard liquor scent to it along with yeast.  Medium to good mouthfeel with lively carbonation on the tongue.  The taste is also yeasty and kind of sour, tart, and like hard liquor that cuts through my sinuses.  Very true to the style.

Pours a straw color with nice off-white head which lasts.  Aroma is quite a lot of yeast, bourbon, vanilla, lots of booze.  Flavor is more of the same, but almost has a champagne like taste to it, very boozy - Bourbon, vanilla, and yeast.  Finish has a medicine quality due to the alcohol presence.  My first Allagash, not a fan of this style of beer.  Give me a bourbon stout instead.

Draft @ Capones:  Poured a gold color with a big head.  The aroma was sweet, citrus, banana and malt.  The flavor was big, thick, bready, malty, citrus, banana, and of course Bourbon.  Overall, I thought this beer was Dee-lish.

Pours a hazy peach with a super thin white head. Aroma is loaded with citrus, complex yeast spices, and bread. Flavor is an in-your-face manifestation of lemon, grapefruit, banana, and vanilla bourbon. Alcohol is present and noticeable; I like it. Sharp but not overpowering; pronounced but not stifling. Definitely one of the better tripels Ive had to date. Palate is Very smooth with a subtle prickling carbonation. Finish is extremely dry. Delicious.

poured golden yellow/orange with thick white head, Aroma of bourbon!, oak (barrels), vanilla traces. goes down strong and tastes like a tripel infused with whiskey! this is a new one! and quite possibly a brilliant beer, i must say ill be purchasing another, even at 15 bucks a bottle!!

Bottled in Feb. 2008. Pours a fairly clear gold color with a lasting white head. Aroma is sweet and sticky - butter, vanilla, and alcohol. Taste is the same plus oak and bourbon. Im not a fan. High ABV + barrel aging = bad beer in my opinion, and this is another example. Lousy taste and smell, this is not drinkable or enjoyable. Drain pour.

golden pour with a fizzy slight head.
vanilla, touch bourbon, some oakiness but not overpowering.  little bit of alcohol.  syrupy mouthfeel, defined vanilla, woody tones, a bit boozy, little bit of bourbon in the finish.  really nice sipper that has obviously been mellowed well

750 ml. Bottle dated feb. 2009. golden orange pour with white head. Aroma of bourbon, oak, vanilla. Flavor is lightly sweet but well balanced with the bourbon barrel.  Notes of oak, vanilla, lightly booziness in the finish. Mouthfeel is nice, with a dry finish. Absolutely awesome take on a triple.

Bottle, 75cl. Pours a golden beer with a white head. The aroma is vineous with wood and bourbon. The flavor is sweet with notes of bourbon, vanilla and fruits. The palate is dry. Overall a great beer with clear notes of the woodaging.
UPDATED: MAY 13, 2009 Hazy golden in color, white head abides.  Citrus, spice, and bourbon nose.  Oak, sweet citrus, bourbon, vanilla.  Crisp finish.  Quite hard to drink slowly.

Perfumy nose, golden brown color. A whiskey-like component that is interesting and enjoyable. The wood, which plays rather nicely with the dry, spicy character of the beer, does detract form the overall complexity of the beer.

Still yet to find an Allagash beer I like. Rather unfortunate.

THis one poured a big fluffy head, with an orangy body, with a red hint.

Smell was very lightly of Bourbon with not too much else.

Tastes too strong of Bourbon. The Tripel flavors are just too delicate to hold up against the hotness of alcohol and the bourbon tastes.

Tastes liek watered down bourbon, rather disapointed.

February 2008 bottling.  Pours golden with a white head that dissipates into a lace.  Aroma is yeast, oaky, almost saison like with spice.  Palate is medium, higher than average carbonation.  There is a significant amount of oak in the flavor, as well as alcohol/bourbon in the finish.  Has the bread triple flavor but BAM in your face with oak and alcohol.  I can tell its a triple but I thing the bourbon is a bit much.

From a 750mL Bottle, December 04 Vintage.  Mostly transparent, golden yellow colored pour with a tall layer of well sustaining, fizzy white head.  Estery aromas of lemon rind and bready malt spiced with some mild, earthy pepper.  The bourbon characters lurk sufficiently behind the base beer, emitting vanilla tones while cold (40F), becomming increasingly boozy and brashingly oaky as it warms.  Pear esters add a soft, soothing contrast to the bourbon.  Medium-light bodied, moderately carbonated mouthfeel with a soft, malty texture.  The body is nice and light, but has a texture that indicates a high starting gravity.  Bready malt and pear ester flavors up front on the palate, followed by a white pepper brightness.  Starts to warm a bit in the middle, with some vanilla tones softening up the spiciness of the alcohol.  Finishes rather bourbony, and increasingly so as it warms, with a grainy, oak tannin harshness lingering in the finish.  The tripel character is pleasantly evident beneath the barrel traits, but I find the bourbon (as opposed to the straight up oak) aspects to be slightly over whelming.  Still, in all regards, this is a well executed, enjoyable beer.

Im not much of a bourbon drinking, in fact the stuff makes me quizzy, but this is one interesting beer. I was three sheets to wind when I had it but heres what I recall. The smell was very oaky with bourbon (of course). Though the smell of bourbon was definitly in there, the taste was a little less than I expected, which was actually a relief. Definitly a sipping beer. Nice and smooth and comforting.

750mL. Bottled November 2007. pours clear and golden with small white head. aroma is sweet with bourbon a little vanilla and a hint of alcohol as it warms. mouthful is smooth with a nice malty balance that is a little on the sweet side. this is an easy sipper at 11%. nicely done.

750ml bottle from Lone Hill Liquor.  Pours a clear sparkling golden with a thin white head.  Aroma is fruity with some vanilla and metallic notes. Hints of bubblegum and a little spicy, doughy.  As it opens up Im detecting some alcohol.  Flavor is sweet and spicy, a little bit bready, fresh fruits like pear and apricot, and a very nice mellow alcohol heat.  Im having a hard time picking out any barrel characteristics, some vanilla is about it.  Finishes sweet with a touch of bitterness.  Would like it a little dryer as the sweetness lingers a bit too much, like Ive been chewing bubblegum.  Full bodied and somewhat sticky with generous carbonation.  This is very nice and extremely well balanced.  A very easy drinker considering the 11% ABV.

Pours with thin creamy white head and carb bubbles. Faint smell of alcohol and woody cream. Carbonation hits pretty strong and tastes very boozy. Slight hints of vanilla. Has very creamy texture and lacking in complexity. It might be one to leave in the cellar a little longer. Great creaminess, but leaves you breathing quite a bit of heat.

Had on tap at the Brick Store Pub in GA. Hazy yellow pour, large white frothy head. Sweet aroma of oranges and bubblegum. Flavor was sweet citrus and vanilla. And an ever so slight tartness on the back. I did not taste the alcohol at all, which could be dangerous, as this was very tasty!

Draft at Map Room. Pours a darkish yello-orange-brown with a dissipating head. Nose is super spicy, like pink bubblegum. Cloves come through, as does the vanilla and oak. I dont get a bourbon bite, which is nice, just the pleasantries of the barrel. Pretty one dimensional, unfortunately, though very drinkable. Okay, but a bit too much bubblegum for me.
hazy apricot color. incredibly complex. super pineapple and fruity. so summery, so appropriate. flavor is like a fruit smoothie. though upon bourbon suggestion it is there. very very sweet. awesome.

on tap at Ginger Man NYC
Poured gold with a thin head. Apricot fruit and alc aroma.
Sticky mouthfeel, more apricot fruitiness and some citrus. Bready malt. 
Thought that the alc was a bit rough, maybe it was too fresh and needed some time?

11.5 oz on tap at Chef Pauls.  3-6-09- dinner after a very tough day...Moderate yellow in color, head is just a thin layer on top.  The faint aroma is primarily of alcohol.  Heavy grapefruit flavor right away- citrus and booze very present in the middle that fades to a very malty sweetness- too sweet for a tripel?  Interesting finish- picked up just faint whiskey/bourbon smoke and bitterness right at the very end.  Lots of layers and complexity here.  Swings a bit wildly across the spectrum for my taste.  Nice beer overall though.
Nice beer, pours a golden color.  No head.  Bourbon and wood aroma.  Fruit notes and bourbon taste, would have again.

Bottle - aged one year.  Looks light and has the hazy straw color that tripels have.  The nose is fruit, oak and burbon....not a big shock.  The flavor is sweet and fruity up front with lots of vanilla and a woody hint of whiskey in the finish.  Great beer.  I need to try some fresh to see if the balance and smoothness was from the age or if its just this damn good on its own.

Bottle shared by mentor, thanks Paul.  Poured a clear golden-yellow color with hints of orange and a thin off-white head that faded to a ring.  Aroma of fresh rye bread, some light bourbon, a soft vanilla paired with some faint spiciness, and some undertones of soft fruit (orange and tangerine).  Smooth, sweet entry with some soft, light fruitiness (orange and light lemon) paired with soft hints of vanilla that led into a light bourbon with some spicy undertones coupled with some dry oak on the finish.  Soft carbonation and light on the palate.  A very delicate beer that seems to balance the base beer and the barrel well.
Pours an orange/ amber with no head.  Aroma of spice, bourbon, and wood.  Flavor of spice, bourbon, fruit, and candi sugar.  Really nice!

Bottle. Pours light metallic gold, with a few bubbles racing to a thick, white head. Wafts of bourbon and cinnamon are present, but not overwhelming. Honey, cinnamon, and a touch of Jim Beam embrace the mouth, and finish smooth and dry, leaving a bit more bourbon and sugar. Its like someone poured just the right amount of Jim Beam into some La Fin du Monde and made it smoother. And the 11% sneaks up on you if youre not careful, a la Duvel. Definitely recommended.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2009 On tap at Uber.  Pours golden amber with a thick white head.  Nose is slightly sour oak, candi sugar, and spicy yeast.  Nice balance in the taste between the whiskey and the sugary malt and spicy bread.  I was surprised that the tripel was all still there.  Full mouthfeel and sweet malty finish.
Draft @ ginger man. Poured an orangey amber with little head. Woody and fruity, pretty clean.

On tap at the Blind Lady in San Diego. Hazy yellow in the glass, with a thick sticky foam of a head.  Nose is sweet and spicy. Oak and booze.  Taste is sharp and yummy.  Spicy, some fruit, and clean yeast.  Thinkin about the 2year old bottle in my closet...

(Feb. 2007) 75 cl bottle at Hopheads´ tasting 30.01.09 (Trygve). Golden/amber color, fine white head. Aroma is sweet, bourbon barrel and has hints of alcohol. Flavor is sweet and fruit - complex, lovely!

750 ml bottle, 2007 vintage. A cloudy dark golden beer with a quite small, though persistent white head. The aroma is powerful and with a certain degree of complexity. Enough maltiness, light citric hops and many woody oaky notes and much bourbon. Perhaps not balanced, too woody aroma, but in a way I like. The flavour has a strong sweetness and a mild acidity, Again oaky and vinous, again not totally balanced, but tasty, Some spices in there. Only medium body, lively carbonation, long finish with light to medium bitterness, some warming alcohol. Once again a great Allagash beer.

Another success like most things Allagash.  Cinnamon in the aroma and very light bourbon.  Light orange color.  Flavor has sweet candi sugar and Belgian yeast with mild bourbon.  One of those rare bourbon beers actually done well, but I probably would have liked it better without the bourbon anyway.
An interesting beer, would classify this as a bourbon bomb.  Musky aroma, with some wood. Flavors of bourbon, oak, vanilla, clove that finishes boozy. Nice mouthfeel, overall a very well made beer.

Allagash curieux ale aged oak bourbon barrels - on tap at Zot in Philly.
Appear 4
Aroma 7
Taste 8
Palate 4
Overall 15
 Unbelievable lacing - cloudy gold amber and creamy head.  Aroma is sweet with lots of oak scents.  Taste is smooth also with unbelievable amounts of oak.  This is the oakiest beer I have ever tasted.   In the end too oaky.  Decent but a bit extreme.  Did I mention that its oaky??

Sllightly hazed golden pour with creamy white head and lace. Light spice but not much of the bb but a hint. Clovish flavor with a hint of light bannana and a pretty warm abv. Palate and carbonation are solid as a dollar. A nice fruity after taste followed by the nice abv warmth. Very nice beer.

~Pours a hazy orange with big fluffy white head.
~Nice fruity aroma, banana, clove, and spicy bourbon alcohol. 
~Spicy flavor that has a nice bourbon finish. Can taste the oak.
~Clean medium feel.
~Complex brew. lots of spice and yeast.

MN Ratebeer Winter Gathering, January 10, 2009.  Courtesy of Skyview.  Gold color with a thin head.  Light spicy nose.  Really interesting flavor profile here... Starts with a light bourbon and oaky vanilla.  Turns to coconut.  Finshes up with banana and yeast.  Pretty sweet.

Hazy golden golden. Very big bourbon notes with some oranges, buttery notes and chalkiness in the nose. Big, buttery, boozey and bourbony with some underlying spices. Bourbon lovers indulge. Non-lovers no need to try.

Bottled March 2008.  Dark golden color with a very tame whitish cover.  Bourbon smoke and wood aroma with undertones of tripel yeasty spices.  Taste is even better, nice vanilla oak barrel mellowing on top of a potent spicy tripel.  Hints of smoke and alcohol warming in the finish.

Bottle from Wades Wines in Westlake Village, CA.  I thought the Jim added a sweet and full flavor to this Tripel, while the oak smoothed it out.  There were also distinct flavors of pear and apple.  Great palate, great taste, very filling...  Great brew.

[Bottle] Pours a cloudy gold with a medium whitish head. Aroma is lots of wheat malt, some oak, and a little bit of bourbon. Flavor is quite tart from the wheat malt with a bit of sunscreen type flavors and some vanilla from the oak aging. Really wasnt expecting to like this beer from the oak aging, but it was actually quite nice. It earned itself some style points.

Received through Secret Santa and shared  at the MN Gathering II. Pours a semi-hazy golden pale brew with a nice off-white head that leaves behind some spotty lacing and a thick white ring. Aroma of bourbon, sweet pears, citrus zest, a touch of coriander and vanilla. Taste is almost full bodied with flavors of golden grain malt, candi sugar, yeast funk, pears, a hint of cloves, coriander and, of course, bourbon. Finish has a nice vanilla and bourbon aftertaste with some alcohol warmth.

Bottle from Wades Wines somewhere in Ventura County, CA. Poured a gold color and smelled of sweet malts and fruit. Tasted of a little bit of apple and pear with a hint of bourbon. I was very impressed with this brew. Just wish is wasnt so expensive at 15.99 for 750ml bottle.
Sampled out of the big bottle. Full of strong malts and loads of bourbon afternotes. A excellent brew.

On tap at OBriens Pub 14th Anniversary Barrel-Aged beer night 1/15.
A- Pours a light orange hue, off white head is mostly dissipating, minimal lacing
S- Brandy and oak dominate, subtle aromas of sugary sweet fruits, some malts and vanilla as well
T- Oak and bourbon notes ride in first, subtle molasses and alcohol warming in the midsection, finishes dry and sweet
M- Medium-bodied, oily texture, mild carbonation
D- Interesting blend of flavors with a strong wood presence, however most of the tastes dissipate quickly leaving not much in its wake, underimpressed with this trippel
Tinged gold pour into a sample glass.  Funky yeast aroma hit me right away, but it enhanced the flavor which was had notes of oak and rum.  Very good!

On tap at Three Floyds and served in a snifter.  This beer poured a lightly hazed golden orange with a thin head of slowly fading off-white foam that left some even lines of lacing down the glass.  The aroma was made up of candied oranges and pears, light clove and coriander, and also just a hint of bourbon.  The flavor was bright and full of sugar-coated oranges, pears, honeycrisp apples...all tinged with a mellow bourbon note.  Quite delicious!  The mouthfeel was full-bodied and lush.  Moderately carbonated.  I love Allagashs tripel, but the bourbon barrels add another layer of flavor to a great beer.
UPDATED: MAY 16, 2017 On draught at Birreria Paradiso.  Cloudy straw colored, aroma of yeast and orange peel.  Flavor of coriander and citrus.  Malty finish well balanced with hops.  Nice one.

Draught at The Reef.   Opaque gold with a big white head.   The aroma is sweet, floral, woody, very bourbon tinged and alcoholic.   The flavor is mostly bourbon, which is nice, but covers the tripel up almost completely.   Rich caramel and wood leading to a pretty dry, slightly alcoholic finish.   Medium bodied and quite drinkable.   Interesting and a great sipper, but the balance is squarely with the barrel influence.
Theres not much Allagash cant do. The Bourbon hints spotty - strong here, missing there - but it makes each glass an adventure. Its overall very good, but not GREAT.

Poured a hazy effervescent amber with a tall fizzy/frothy white head.  Aroma is sweet and spicy with notes of peach and pear, cinnamon, a bit of alcohol, some floral notes.  Flavor is somewhat sweet with some notes of cinnamon and nutmeg spiciness and some apple and pear, a bit of bourbony oak, leading to a semi-dry finish.  Well-made as usual for Allagash, but didnt blow me away with originality.

again, another surprise from superdave70... 2008 batch.

pours an orange shade of orange brown (yup, thats what the notes say. i MAY have been a little bit d-runk at the time.) with a whitish head and slight spots of lacing. 

the aroma is intoxicating... lots of mellowed bourbon with notes of vanilla, orange, caramel, peppercorns, spicy wood and a touch of smoke. 

the flavor profile contains a tart sourish funky barrel note with a ton of vanilla, tannic woody notes, caramel, light yeast and a spicy finish. medium body with a smooth luscious mouth feel.

notes say "this is special. i want to pour this in a gigantic snifter and sit in the hot tub while it snows on top of me."
8/3/8/5/17/4.1

Cloudy, even dirty, gold in color with a small noisy white head that remains as a thin layer of tiny white bubbles.  The second pour out of the 750 brought a big thick head of 2 inches.  Aroma of alcohol,, whiskey, and spice.  Flavor is similar with some funkiness, clove, and honey.  The bourbon was a bit overdone.  Feel is very smooth.  ABV is not exaggerated!  This is a super beer on so many levels.

750 ml bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Pours a hazy golden color with a small white head.  The aromas bourbon, oak, spicy sweet malt.  The flavor is much of the same bourbon, moderately sweet malt with a spicy edge, honey, and an overall smooth quality from the wood.  This was an interesting beer.  The 11% came out a bit as it warmed.  Finish was dry.

Bottle courtesy of superdave70 shared at hellbilly*s holiday tasting. Spicey bourbon aroma. Hazy gold body with white head. Spicey, clove and sweet bourbon flavor. Mabe little to much on the spice side for me. Thanks Dave.

Aromas of bourbon, tartness from the oak, somewhat spicy tripel-ish aroma. Light sweetness, hay. Golden orange pour, nice bubbles, and a nice head too. The flavor is pretty full of bourbon and booze up front, some oak notes subdue the underlying base of yeast, spice, and fruit. Some candy sweetness, and perhaps a little bread. Lots of noticable booze from the 11%. Carbonation is soft, the body is smooth, and oak dryness lingers.

750ml bottle. Pours an opaque honey-orange. Lots of foamy head. You can definitely taste the barrel aging here, not just in the bourbon but also in the tannins present in this one. Pretty sweet, but this sweetness is balanced by the tannins and bitter notes from the casking. Wow - after 1 hour after drinking this I am completely toasted. Wow. Just wow.

750ml bottle. Pours golden orange with a nice foamy white head. Aroma of fruit and sweet malts. The sweetness continues on the tongue, along with bread, vanilla, wood,  and a nice bourbon alcohol burn at the finish. Very good beer despite the high price. Thanks Dad!
